reviewText:
Aesthetically this game fits the Warhammer 40K universe more then any I've ever come across. it looks like 40K and the voice acting is amazing.
As a game, I believe Battlefleet Gothic Armada accomplished what it set out to do, It captured the feel of the original Table Top game. And while many may argue about the implementation, and the balance, the majority of players agree that it is fun.
One challenge new players might have is the different factions. Remember that each faction has it's strengths and weaknesses, which means each faction has different play-styles that fit them. You will need to learn how to play each faction that you wish to use, and you will lose some battles in that learning process. Be patient, learn, and remember: sometimes a faction just might not fit your play-style.
The only problem I have with the game is that sometimes, it's easy to forget that you're commanding ships that are miles long. these are not small vessels. yet there's so much going on so often that you just don't have the time to zoom in and enjoy watching your space cathedral floating along.

reviewText:
Before starting the review, I want to get two points out of the way that those giving this game a negative review usually complain about:

Difficulty
The game isn't that hard, simple. The problem is not the difficulty, but the players themselves. Too many are playing this game on the highest difficulties when this is their first time playing a game such as this one. Not just that, but this game had in mind an old school difficulty, where hard REALLY is hard unlike most of the games nowadays. Easy and Normal modes are there for a reason, for you to use if you struggle. For you, to IMPROVE. Many on the forums and the reviews are spoiled by gaming nowadays, they want it all and they want it NOW.

They don't want to spend hours to learn and improve their skills, and that's the issue. And the beauty of this game is the fact that in the campaign, even if you lose a battle, is not game over. You obtain XP and rewards and you can still overcome whatever the game throws at you.

Micromanagement
Seriously? Most of the time playing this game you control a bunch of ships, usually at the beginning a mix of 1-2 big" ships and a couple smaller ones. Is micromanagement really a problem in an RTS that is about commanding a bunch of ships? If you think so

reviewText:
This review will be constantly updated so please provide comment and feedback if you wish to add your own experience or correct me on certain details. Thanks in advance!
Pros:
* Authentic-looking, kilometers-long, badassfully manly space churches
* Immersive and destructive space battles
* Free DLC once for early adopters
* Customizeable ships (aethetics/appearance, abilities, skills, upgrades and crew)
* Gripping prologue and characters with excellent storytelling and voiceovers.
* Constant flow of events in battles require second-by-second change in tactics and inevitably develop ships and captains with their own colorful history.
* Responsive devs (hoping this will continue since this WILL BE a crucial selling point)
* Satisfying AI and control layout (shortcuts, pathfinding, auto-activating abilities available, engagement possibilities and tactics)
* Races (four currently: imperial navy, chaos, ork pirates and eldar corsairs) feel individually unique with potential for personalized warfare.
* Rewarding combat especially for truly brilliant tactics and strategizing; losing doesn't even feel bad.
* Great multiplayer potential
* Campaign holds excellent replayability potential and losing battles does not necessarily mean game over but rather tougher battles in the future.
* Key points in the game along with accomplishments in certain battles will allow Spire to change the whole course of the 12th Black Crusade and change certain details in the original storyline of the tabletop game lore.
* Can run with high graphics even on mid-level specs
* Great price, especially with 10% pre-order discount
* Fun classic ship-of-the-line battling and tactics: tacking and ramming (in space) amongst other things.
* Clear sense of multi and singleplayer segregation. Players have separate single and multiplayer fleet profiles that are progressed exclusively from each other. You don't need to be online 24/7.


Cons:
* Controls could use some user specialization and customization while some annoying problems occur. Abilities and commands have hotkeys and shortcuts but are not displayed even on tooltips, requires constant returns to the control options menu unless you memorize it all. Minor, but very tiring.
* Game modes may get repetitive depending on map variety and story content.
* Ships will blaze through minefields if you have overriding move orders.
* Current maps are cookie-cutter: space with random asteroid, station and cloud layout and background though this is to be expected, space isn't always necessarily creative.
* Soundtrack is fine, but nothing memorable so far (personal opinion)
* Lack of map/scenario editor reduces replayability (devs could've saved some funding since players would've done their job and uploaded new maps, themselves)

You won't find the word in the title but this is the universe of Warhammer 40000. The only constant is war, compassion is weakness and red things 'go fasta'. You are Captain Spire, the soon-to-be admiral of your own fleet. Danger looms over the endless horizons of space as duty calls for you to lay down your life for your Undying God-Emperor on His Golden Throne. You are but one of many, but yours is a role that will send waves and tremors across the vast reaches of the Gothic Sector. Your crew look to you for orders. They will not find you wanting. They MUST not find you wanting. Welcome to Battlefleet Gothic, admiral.

Now, for an in-depth detailing of pros and cons, I am deep into chapter 4 and have seen enough to give some solid feedback. Take note, however, that their may be a spoiler or to in here. First, characters, scripts, gameplay and storytelling remain outstanding. Cutscenes are used sparingly and, much like the exterminatus you will see in-game, are exacting, powerful, well-timed, grim and very, very, badass. Elements remain true to the grimdark machinations of the Warhammer 40K franchise. Battles can get tiring, but in the way that you must constantly adapt and counter every move your foes may make, lest you suffer crucial losses, or a decisive defeat. Pathfinding could use some fine-tuning, such as ships ramming space debris without care as well as an annoying problem were I can use the 'S' and 'D' keys to scroll across the map but leave the 'W' and 'A' keys unresponsive, though this may or may not be an isolated problem.

With regards to replayability (possible spoilers) certain game choices will allow you to alter history and deviate from the original warhammer lore. An early point comes whether or not you are able to keep two certain artifacts (mentioned at the beginning cinematic with abaddon) from chaos forces. You can also defy typical Imperial behavior and actually heed an eldar's warning. Then again, it is entirely up to you. Take note, that this will have crucial impact on enemy strength and races you go up against. Siding with eldar, for example, will ease their attacks and may stop them entirely.

For more cons, while game modes remain repetitive, there are enough variation and randomization that it doesn't get all that tiring, though objectives remain boringly linear: keep x from reaching y, go to a, keep b from stealing c, and so on. Ultimately, the battles main selling point is not the end of the journey, but how you get there, namely how you're gonna triumph against enemy fleets whilst keeping yours intact, on the way to accomplishing your objectives. The maps could use some more loving, but it's space, and other than some fancy looking backgrounds, you're not gonna find anything more besides rocks, space debris, and giant space cathedrals.

On the multiplayer side, most of the campaign experience carries over, save for the lack of a story and general direction. Ultimately the goal is to have fun, pitting yourself against human foes in, at most, 2V2 fights, though that experience in itself may see its own hiccups as automatic match-making can never really gauge tactical skills in order to truly pit a genuine novice against his own breed. You may find yourself fighting a strategy veteran, despite the fact that your levels are the same. In hindsight, though, that should be fun in its own way and trust me, 4 people against each other will be complicated enough. Still here's hoping for bigger fights, bigger maps, and even more ships in the future.

So, final thoughts, the game is spectacular considering its price, and while the campaign is as well told and as manly as they come, BGA's real attraction lies in human player pitted against human player. I honestly think you'll be spending the majority of your time in the multiplayer lobby while the campaigns potential for replays offers a substantial distraction. Progression in both multiplayer, random skirmish and campaign is linear, with branching elements restricted to individual ship specialty (maneuverability, firepower, etc.) with corresponding choices in terms of crew and upgrade loadout and distribution. And the real question: is it worth the price tag? By the Emperor, it is. Now if we could just take care of those minor cons.

Verdict: 40K/10 will ram with space cathedrals again.

P.S. The issue of the space marine DLC is in the end a matter of perspective, but comparing it to the fact that the first Dawn of War game had a basic four race selection (Space marines, chaos space marines, orks and eldar) it certainly seems fair enough by my standards. Ultimately, naval engagements are predominantly left to the imperial navy in canon warhammer lore, though that does not necessarily mean the space marines are pushovers (there's a reason they have 'space' in their name), it's just that the imperial navy are the space posterboys and would have a priority in being included first. Again, that's purely my opinion, so perhaps we should just be grateful the space marines WILL be coming soon, and with no extra charge at that, provided you buy the game soon.

reviewText: My Imperial armada of 2 battlecruisers and 3 light cruisers up against 7 Eldar ships. I sent over a boarding party the first chance he came too close and managed to knock out his engines, but right before then he fire a volley of torpedoes right at me with the little amount of time I had before he could regain power to engines I aggressively maneuvered my ship on his starboard side but not before taking a couple of torp blows to my rear. After getting in position I gave the command for my ship to go FULL SPEED AHEAD MAX POWER TO ENGINES!!! The Eldar ship managed to regain power to engines but it was to late!!! My ship slammed right into it dealing the final blow to an epic battle!!! GLORY TO THE EMPEROR!!!!!

reviewText:
TL;DR - If you like 40K and want to manage a space battle, buy this game. If you don't know what 40K is or you're one of those insufferable people that demands a video game play exactly like its board-game inspiration, skip this.


1] The game oozes 40K. If you like the 40K theme, the developers did a very good job staying true to the source material. Tech priests, commissars, and navigators have voice recordings that feel right. The ships are all very pretty. The developers can recite the Imperial Hymnal, and it shows...

2] There is an amazing amount of depth to upgrading and managing your fleet. Understanding your own play-style is key to doing this well because you simply will not be able to upgrade each ship in your fleet to do everything. Opportunity cost is everywhere.

3] The game makes you feel the impact of your decisions. Fail a mission? You get less reknown for a mission. Reknown is used to upgrade your ships. Choose poorly in upgrading your ships/fleet, you will feel the impact of those choices in upcoming battles. Lose a ship in battle, and you lose access to it for a number of rounds. Although you can recover from any mistakes, it takes time and reknown to correct those mistakes.

4] The game difficulty scales reasonably well, (1-4). On 4, I win about half of the time. On 3, I win about 80% of the time. Easier difficulties and you can feel like a tactical genius. You can play at whatever difficulty suits you.

5] The game is 2D naval combat metaphor, and not 3D space combat. People will whine about this, in a post-Homeworld space RTS world. However, there are enough other things going for this game, that I'm willing to overlook that aspect of the game.

6] The detail and pretty videos you see on YouTube are great... except, I don't really spend any time managing my fleet zoomed in like that. It's a perfect way to lose my battle. In a sad/unfortunate way, so much wonderful detail gets lost/ignored when playing the game.

7] The game runs well on my 6th gen Core i7 with Nvidia 970M gfx, which is saying it runs well on the latest and greatest laptop with discrete gfx. It was barely playable on a laptop that is 3 years old.

[updated review]

I've seen a few complaints from other reviewers that are worth addressing.

8] Reviewers that write, It's too hard. [faction] is too hard on [mission] types
date: are not playing correctly. If the Chaos Space Marines are outrunning your Imperial ships in an assassination mission, stop using large and slow capital ships and use light cruisers. If the Orks keep destroying all of your Imperial defense platforms, then properly group your ships into a massive clump concentrate fire on a single ship at a time so that at least one platform survives. If the Eldar keep destroying your fleet, then use light cruisers with lots of frigates. Every complaint about the game being too hard is due to the player not understanding the victory conditions, their ships strengths/weaknesses, or their enemies' strengths/weaknesses.\n\n9] Reviewers that write, the mission types get boring/repetitive" do have a point. There are only a handful of mission types: cruiser clash
hoursPlayed: convoy

reviewText:
The mission: Blow up a Chaos Space Station to recover an artifact that could have important implications in the future.

The ships: Go all-in, bring a badass Overlord pattern Battlecruiser, two beefy cruisers and a light cruiser.  Escort ships? Who needs 'em?  The Emperor protects.

My four ships (and our one ally controlled cruiser) roll up on this space station thing starts plinking my ships from the very edge of our range - and I had range extending upgrades on most of my ships.  I volley a few torpedoes out and start casting some of my special bombs while navigating along a nearby space cloud to conceal sensors.

Chaos light cruiser and escorts show up so I abandon the cloud and just send everything in.

Station meanwhile sends out fighters and blows up damn near all of my torps.  Damn.

Station has immense shields while it's rapidly depleting the shields of my first cruiser.  Ally just hangs back and ♥♥♥♥♥ around with the Chaos scrub ships.

<Time passes>

Deplete station void shields sustaining major damage on one cruiser, moderate on the battlecruiser and remaining cruiser.  Shoot station with Nova cannon, blows up station weapon.  Send 3 lightning strike teams aboard, teams wreck more weapons and generally tear up the place.  Warp first cruiser before it gets blown up.

Before I can get the kill shots in, it's immense void shields reactivate.

♥♥♥♥ this.

Take light cruiser, aim at station.

Hit 'All Ahead Full' (aka TURBO) button.

RAM CHAOS SPACE STATION INTO A MILLION PIECES!

Win mission, recover artifact.

3/4 ships in repair yard with heavy damage.

Still 2 deployments left on my turn.

FML.

10/10 Would use Imperial ships as glorified space battering rams to purge the heretics for the immortal God-Emperor.

reviewText:
I was really looking forward to this, but I cannot recommend this in its current state. It's going to need some big changes to improve, changes I don't see them moving to make. The 2 big problems are micromanagement and grind.

Micro management hell:

In order to give it the RPG elements that seem mandatory in every game these days, each ship can be upgraded with tons of special abilities, all of which have their own separate hot key and button. It's common to see ships with a DOZEN ability buttons each. Many of these are ridiculously powerful (nova cannon, stasis bomb) and tend to overshadow the basic guns. The game ends up resembling an MMO style ability cooldown management experience rather than a naval maneuvering game. It doesn't feel like you're fighting with ships so much as you're controlling dueling space wizards casting spells. It would be one thing if all these special abilities were limited to support style ships, but EVERY ship gets the SAME spells". A light cruiser can "cast" the exact same stasis bomb as a battleship.

Speaking of the upgrades in general
date: there is no strategy to choosing them because a couple are obviously useless (+5 degrees/sec turn speed when instant turn maneuvering thrusters are already practically free?) while a couple are obviously better (almost any of the damage/gunnery skills). You end up seeing fleet with 90% the same skills (oh hey another stasis bomb).\n\nAll of this is made worse by the default speed being way too fast. WAY too fast to be managing what amounts to controlling 2-6 individual MMO characters. You can activate a "bullet time" mode (tactical cogitators) which effectively pauses the game
recommended: but it's jarring having to do this constantly. If you really want to be serious about your micro
hoursPlayed: you'll rarely let it run at default speed for more than one second at a time
voteText: having the announcer scream "TACTICAL COGITATORS ONLINE!" every single time you pause (holy hell will you get sick of hearing that). Pausing is limited in multiplayer
helpfulPercent: like a chess clock. However this isn't very fair since some races (Eldar) rely a lot more on micro than others.\n\nThe speed also causes large groups of ships to crash into each other constantly. In the tabletop
votesHelpful:
it assumed the distance between ships in space was big enough that collisions were only possible if one ship was intentionally trying to ram. In this game you're going to have ships constantly bumping off each other like pinballs unless you use your annoying and precious pause time to avoid it.


The grind:

Holy hell the grind. You start off only being able to use a single light cruiser and a couple of the smallest escort ships. It is very boring playing with just these. To unlock more
votesTotal: you must grind battle after battle to gradually earn xp until you're "allowed" to use whatever ships you want in a battle. It's so slow and obnoxious that it feels like a F2P unlock model designed to make you go "screw this" and fork over cash to skip the grind
votesFunny: except this is a full price retail game you already paid for. This unlock model would be fine in the single player campaign which plays out like a long term RPG experience

reviewText:
Battlefleet Gothic: Armada  fits the Warhammer 40K universe more then any I've ever come across in the last few years. it looks like 40K, it plays like 40k and the voice acting makes it sound like 40k should. It plays like a Tactical RTS and is quite enjoyable in both solo and multiplayer

Full review:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WFwUKlJLQs4

Summary:
As always, a textual summary can't convey the information of a full review video - See the video for the best impression

The games main gameplay loop, the various battle are both it's main strength and weakness. If you like the more methodical and planned gameplay of picking fleets, customizing ships and assembling your armed forces, then this is a great title. The ship customization, the various races with their unique aspects as well as the large variety of visuals and ships make it amazing.

But the downside is that ship combat is Slow. Ships take a long while to kill and battles can drag on for longer then enjoyable. This difference between the two aspects of the game will either make it great, or not so great for your personal enjoyment.

The game's performance is fine, it's voice acting is insanely good and the story, while not amazing"
date: fits and works within both the game and the lore it is set in.\n\nOverall
recommended: i can FULLY recommend the game to any 40k Fan OR/AND anyone that enjoy tactical RTS gameplay."

reviewText:
This has become one of my favourite strategy games very quickly.

The fights themselves are fun, quick and requiring micro but not to the extend that it is simply about who can click the fastest. The battles are very tactical with the deciding factors being about who can get the best use of ships rather than economy management.

Both the multiplayer and single player are based around building up and levelling up a fleet of ships that you then use in battle. The mission you play in both single and  multiplayer are randomly picked from, Cruiser Crash, Escort, Assassination, Data Recovery, Planetary Assault, Breakthrough and Space Station Assault. In Single player they are also custom crafted mission that show up about 1 in 3. The missions never feel like a grind to me because they are fun to play. I play the missions for them, not the levelling up.

There are some balance issues that still need to be worked out, each side plays very differently and although this is a good thing it dose make it hard to balance out, also some missions are harder than others for the attacker. The point system means that if lower level player meets a high level they still can't use bigger ships as each player has the same number of points to pick. Some people have stability problems but I have had only one crash in 22 hours.

All in all an excellent game.

reviewText:
Pros:
+ All races have distinct gameplay strategies.
+ Ample customization possibilities for your ships.
+ Decent mission variety.
+ Nice visual and sound design, ramming heavy ships into each other feel as impactful as it should.
+ Excellent campaign cutscenes and VO, these really make the game feel alive.
+ The AI, while not brilliant, is up to the task.

Cons:
- Limited options for custom battles. (davs said it's slated for improvement)
- Unusual persistent multiplayer fleet system might be offputting to some.
- Balance isn't quite there as of this writting, with Eldar in particular either dominating or falling flat on their face vs dedicated counters. (rebalance promised in upcoming patch)

Overall a fun game and a good use of the WH40K license.

reviewText:
(Updated)

I'm only recommending this game on HOPE that they will fix it.

Pros:
- Great concept
- Great mechanics
- True to the lore
- Good voice acting and cutscenes in campaign.

NEEDS FIXING! :
- Multiplayer is totally unplayable:
- Matchmaking (I'm lvl 2 with a Cruiser and a light cruiser got matched against someone lvl 8 with a Battleship AND a cruiser)
- Occasional bug that prevents all your ships from using any abilities unless you set them on autocast.
- Occasional bug that makes you immediately lose the game and says that you capitulated from battle.
- Co-op vs. AI was implemented in last update finally, however I was really dissappointed. Instead of both players having full deployment points it split the points for one player by half (at maximum you can have 350 pts) and there is no progression, meaning that instead of making the skirmish progress experience more enjoyable with a friend you basically have a testing range with half points. I really wonder if the devs understood the reason behind Co-op vs AI.
- Balance: Yes all factions have their unique style and yes all factions are playable. But Orks are blatantly overpowered.

Cons:
- Campaign has the occasional unique mission but 80% of the time it's the same thing over and over.
- Without fixing the issues mentioned above, there is no reason to play this game for extended amount of time.

reviewText:
In the short time that I have been playing Battlefleet Gothic: Armada (since two weeks ago during the beta stages of the game) I have fallen in love with the mechanics and the gameplay. It is probably the best game that I have played in quite a while and I've found myself always coming back to it within a few hours of closing it. The multiplayer has so many options and there is so many ways to customise and tune your ship to certain situations. If you are a fan of Warhammer 40,000 as well, then you are in for a treat as this ties in with the lore as well as telling the story of the 12th Black Crusade of Chaos against the Imperium of Man in the Gothic Sector.

By far, my fondest moment in this game is trying to take down an enemy vessel, during an data recovery or an assassination mission, while it is charging up their warp engines. Watching the little blue bar climbing, higher and higher, towards the end of the 'charge-up' bar makes your heart beat, your hands sweat and a surge of fear and zeal strikes you as you realise that this is the make it or break it moment and determines whether you win or lose. My second favour moment so far in the game is hiding my 'admiral' ship inside of an asteroid field during the very same type of gamemode and using my other ships to lure the enemy away. Not once have I seen someone that has been able to figure out this tactic until the last moment when I micro-warp jump my 'admiral' ship into clear-view and then activate the warp-engines and quickly escape the battlefield and bring myself to victory.

I completely whole-heartly recommend this game to anyone that is interested in an RTS game that just WORKs. It has leveled itself with my favour RTS game (Sins of a Solar Empire: Rebellion) and there is still more to come from it in the near and distant future.

Buy this game, it is worth it.

reviewText:
I've never bothered to write a review for anything before. I liked this game a lot and I believe it deserves more attention...

I held off buying this game at first thinking I was going to wait for a steam sale. Then I watched some gameplay videos on youtube and decided it was worth giving a shot just to be able to play the arcade matches and maybe some multiplayer even at full price. It definitely lived up to my expectations.

What I wasn't expecting was how good the campaign would be. Voice acting is on point and it was a pretty gripping story, however what really suprised me is how they captured the feeling of 'everything going to ♥♥♥♥' rapidly really well. The point where I stopped and thought 'this was really worth the money' was when I found myself with at best 3 planetary systems I could save, the other 5  would have to be ignored and allowed to fall. And it was even worse the next turn and worse the turn after that. It genuinely felt desperite and hopeless, somehow without feeling frustrating.

That moment and when I realised that ramming chaos and eldar ships is a legit tactic. What's that, you have a shiny nemisis battleship you're bringing to battle that's killed millions of people. Wouldn't it be a shame if someone ... I dunno ... rammed into it from 3 different directions... :P

TLDR: If you like warhammer 40K, you will probably like this game. If you're unsure, if it's ever half price or less pick it up.

reviewText:
So I've played a lot of 40K games, and this is the first that plays like the table top game it represents. From deployment zones to fleet points it accurately represents most parts of a BFG game while not being turn based (which would have turned me off even though Table top is turn based). For someone who wants a real taste of 40k this is the game for you.

The game modes are fun, the ships are fantastic looking, and it satisfies an itch for a space naval combat game that Sons of a solar Empire didn't quite scratch. The videos and voice acting are good and really give the Warhammer vibe. The campaign is fun and is a good telling of the Gothic wars.

The downside of this game are the bugs, which aren't to prevalent but I routinely have the game crash with a graphical or other fatal error. While I'm upset the comp stomp mode with friends isn't implemented yet, the developers have said they are working on it so that's not a true drawback anyway.

Overall I'd recommend this game to anyone who wants a space combat/great 40k game.

reviewText:
I really really wanted to like this game as a huge fan of the table top, but I'm massively disappointed.

Pros
Thematically it’s perfect, and if you are fan of the 40k universe it’s a real treat, and will definitely increase your enjoyment of the game. Graphics and sound are really good also, the combat feels visceral and the general look and feel of the game is great. At times it can be really fun to play, especially 2v2 with a friend.

EvensMost matches will about 5 minutes. You level up admirals to build the fleet, you dont have free control to pick whatever you like whenever you like (as in the table top). Campaign is okay (I've not played a lot yet) but it seems to mostly be a string of skirmish missions in essence. When playing online you don't have control over what map or game mode you play, or points size, its all random.

Cons
It’s not release ready, buggy with frequently crashes. It’s missing major features at release; team chat, AI battles with friends, fully open skirmish modes, fully fledged match making and ranked matches. There is a road map[forum.battlefleetgothic-armada.com] to deliver some of these features but they may not be arriving for months. It also looks like the Space Marine DLC will be late.

If you are expecting massive fleet engagements as shown in the trailers, or even something more modest like 10 ships a side – don’t, you will be disappointed. In a 2v2 game unless you want to spam escorts, you will have about 3 ships per player. The points limit is crushingly low, and apparently[forum.battlefleetgothic-armada.com] it’s not going to change anytime soon.

The game is so simple, the gameplay is so so shallow. The table top was a naval engagement game, which allowed detailed control of weapons, movement and abilities. This plays more like a battle arena game. There is no real negative aspect or risk to using abilities, and there is no resource cost, so you just spam them as fast as possible. There is limited control over weapons, they just constantly fire. This means for instance you can’t time your weapons for increased effectiveness.

You control ships with point and click movement, but ships take wide turns to get to places so you never really know where your ships are going. Units don’t maintain formation (a la Total War games), and there is no control over speed. This means it’s almost impossible to move your fleet in a concerted manner, i.e. escorts will always arrive in battle before your cruisers.

SummaryThis game was released a month late, and it feels like it still needs a few more months. If you like 40k then you may like this, otherwise I would pass.
voteText: 24 of 28 people (86%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Battlefleet Gothic: Armada is still in it's early stages, but is a solid game all around in the way it's mechanics and gameplay feel and perform. Like most games it is still having teething problems with bugs and errors yet to be weaned out of the equation, and some balancing still needed.

The gameplay can be a bit rough at first, but once you are accustomed to the game it's quite enjoyable. The campaign is well worth taking time to play through, and although multiplayer is still rather buggy when it works it works well.

Overall I would say, the game is new and still needs work in the stability department, as many games do in such situations. But technical issues aside, the gameplay is fun and intuitive and the campaign interesting for the player.

If you are a Warhammer 40,000 fan, or even better a Battlefleet Gothic fan, I think you'll get your fix out of this game.

If you're a hardcore RTS gamer who wants to test yourself on another playing field, I would say the game isn't ready for you just yet. Wait a little for the bugs to be cleared away and the matchmaker to improve.

And if you just want something fun to do and are willing to put up with bugs and errors, I recommend giving the game a fair go.

Whatever you choose, good luck Admirals.
~Alexi

reviewText:
I love the 40k universe and this game presents is spectacularly. The art design nails the cartoonishly grim feel of the universe and the campaign presents it in a similar way as Dawn of War II (in all the right ways). The actual gameplay feels like a refined version of the naval battles from Rome total war, and the additional abilities and general number of ships you're commanding at any given time makes it generally more enjoyable and more of a tactical experience. The developers basically nailed the amount of persistence and customization to give the ships, both making you feel invested in upgrading ships and miserable when you make a mistake and let one of your prized battlecruisers go up in flames, while still maintaining some amount of balance for players who are just beginning the game. The factions are very assymmetric and this leads to some favored matchups depending on which mission is being played. While the basic cruiser clash is quite balanced, things like convoy missions are much easier with the Eldar than say the Imperium, due to differences in ship speed and strength. This is still being worked on by the developers and in a few patches I think it will be really quite good, but even as is, the slight imbalances act more as quirks to work your strategy around, rather than straight up flaws that make the game unenjoyable.
While there are complaints about the 2d layout of this space game, it does make sense from its tabletop origins and after several matches I stopped questioning why my mile-long flying-space-cathedral had a design that was somewhere between Admiral nelsons flagship and a roman ram ship. You will often hear people whining that there aren't more factions, do not take this as a foul cry against this game, but rather know that people love this universe deeply and want to see their favorite races in the game. However when they do come out with the (I hope) inevitable dlc that includes the Necrons, Tau, tyrannids, and other factions, I will be buying that without a second thought.
This game is fun. It's very niche and has a bit of a learning curve, but it is thoroughly and completely enjoyable to play and I'll give props to the developers for letting me ram space cathedrals into floating ork rustbuckets. Do them the favor and give them your money, they've earned it.

reviewText:
Being the wrong side of forty, cough cough, and having played the original GW game all those years a go.  I bring ancient, ahem cough, wisdom to this short review.
Spaceships and factions are all very well rendered with the unreal engine bringing them to life in very dark and atmospheric ways.  The various missions conform for the most part to the original game.  The campaign cut scenes are engaging and moving.  Unlike the turn based original,  all the action occurs in real time, with a bullet time option to slow things down giving you time to zoom in to the action and behold the carnage.  Of course this also gives you time to issue new orders when things get crazy and put together tactical plays.
The empire ships feel spot on and just as I imagined from the original turn based game.  Slow but purposeful with strong fire power good armor and exceedingly slow speed.
Chaos seem a little weak on long range firepower relying heavily on lances and suffer from weaker armor but have faster speed than the empire.
The Orc ships are well presented but are heavily reliant on micro warp jump and taunt to close with faster more manuverable ships ie everyone else !
If you love pressure and extreme micro management then the Eldar are your fleet of choice.  They come with some very strong firepower but lack armor and are extremely fragile.  The holoshields their ships hide behind require that the player keeps them on the move.  The faster they go the harder the eldar corsairs are to hit.
With space marines just around the corner and another yet to be announced new fleet in the works this game is full of potential and so far goes a long way to realising that BFG itch that resides in the hearts and minds of the GW faithful.  It's also a pretty fine two dimensional ship to ship combat game.  What more can I say ?  WAAAAAAAAAAAAARRRRRRGGGG !  Blood for the Blood God ! and in the name of the Emperor enjoy !

reviewText:
Deleted to updated and renew the Review whilst deleting the downvotes of Trolls from the community forums when helping users and the angry users who shows no interest of the game but to attack the Warhammer 40k Licenses of Games Workshop. If you feel like something is wrong, please don't hesitate to make a comment for clarification.

++A perfect lineup and worthy for the Warhammer 40k License/Franchise.

+Battlefleet Gothic: Armada or BGA is a RTS Micromanaging Space battle where you command you fleets of the different factions with careful tactics and placement whilst also you must choose the correct fleet to send into the battle.
+It has quite an Immersive and destructive space battles even when you get up close to see the damage and bombardment especially ramming onto each other.
+Satisfying AI which can actually destroy you on the field if you are not careful.
+Each factions has a unique feature and fleet with their own strength and weakness example the Orks have powerful full customization ships with great ramming but poor maneuverability or the Eldar thats quick, fast and stealth like but very fragile and less likely to mutiny.
+Has Great Multiplayer and no worries about the lag or so that I've encountered.
+Graphic is stunning and beautiful with very high detailed fleets and space itself is just atmospheric.
+You can level up your Fleet and Admiral to further customize the fleet and upgrade your abilities and Crews.
+The Fleet combat uses water physics which is interesting.
+Multiplayer is actually fun when playing with a friend on a 2v2 while 1v1 on the other hand isn't all fun since its a small battle.

-/+Control Layout is perfect and well placed though could be improved with more information.
-/+Skirmish while not only it is good, the AI can be cheating.
-/+Greatly difficult to master and skillfully play like on a Demon/Dark Souls level but its up to the users perspective.
-/+Again on users perspective is the price but its a well deserve price for a Great game.
-/+Easy to ragequit but its expected on Warhammer 40k.
-/+Multiplayer is currently server buggy and there is no proper/custom lobby to invite and play against friends but you can invite 1 for a (friend and you)2v2(Strangers)
-/+Despite named Armada, the max battlepoints is 700 so you really have a small limited choice of choosing your fleet that really didn't make up for a big battle especially on a 1v1 as you constantly get the weak escort ships.
-/+Currently Multiplayer is being Plague by Eldar due to frustration of their hit and run if its a 1v1 match and overpowered Imperial+Chaos Combo team in a 2v2 as Imperialism Favour summons Cobras to hit and run while Chaos does the long range harssment.

-Tutorial is actually quite lacking and bare to new players to the Warhammer 40k.
-There are some minor bugs and a bad launching/loading screen when you bootup the game.
-Only minor bad optimization for some which not really a problem unless otherwise.
-Currently suffers some bad Optimization that was found and reported to the technical forums. Some issues has been reported and acknowledge since beta but was never resolved.
-Many reports despite having a good Rig/Laptop, there has been crashes on Prelaunching the game and while playing in a game that becomes unstable from heavy battle effects and physic.

Bonus Screenshots

How recommended should you get this?
++Very recommended if you are a Warhammer 40k Fan/Love.
+Recommended if you like playing Space RTS that provide great difficulty.
-Not Recommeded for Heretics and Kids.

reviewText:
I had already given up hope on Games Workshop licensed video games when Battlefleet Gothic: Armada dropped on my proverbial lap. It may be due to my low experience in tabletop Gothic or my sufficiently low expectations, but I actually found myself surprisingly enough enjoying the game.

It should be stated that the game is real time, which does mean it works very differently from the turn based tabletop version. However, unlike many other Games Workshop licensed video games Battlefleet Gothic: Armada manages to capture the spirit of the original -while- also providing mechanically solid game.

Matches are fast paced and typically last about 5 - 15 minutes depending on fleet size. Customizeable battle fleets and some half a dozen scenarios with different winning conditions mean that no match plays out quite like the last, though it has to be said that at the moment certain scenarios feel a bit lopsided, and the matches may get repetitive as nearly all of them seem to involve both players boosting to the middle and grinding it out. The winner is often determined by which one has the better fleet composition, faster reaction speed and greater control over their fleet.

Despite the repetitiveness and certain level of lopsidedness Battlefleet Gothic: Armada does have good frame on which to add features that increase the strategic depth, and even if those features were not added the game is still an enjoyable tactical space brawl game, although admittedly on the lighter side of the spectrum.

Is it Battlefleet Gothic the board game in video game format? No, it is not.
Is it an entertaining little space brawl game faithful to the spirit of the original? Yes!
Can you shout WAAAGH!"

reviewText:
Short Version: If you like Warhammer 40K, get his game.

Great game, especially if you're a 40K fan. This might be the best representation of the space ships of Warhammer we've ever seen. The game is extremely faithful to the 40K lore, from the writting down to the ship visuals, weapons and locations.

The one down side is the nature of some of the skirmish missions (which incidentally are the same missions you'll encounter in the campaign). Some of the mission objectives are incredibly frustrating and the randomized nature of the maps and enemy composition leads to difficulty spikes that sap some of the fun from the game.

That aside the game is a lot of fun with an enjoyable progression system and the ability to play as 4 (later 6) factions in skirmish and multiplayer, all faithful to the 40K universe. I would like to see more cosmetic customizations and would really like some additional campaigns from the other factions (currently the Imperium of Man has a campaign).

reviewText:
This review is to reflect the current state of the game and I will change it pending a much needed patch
Broken pieces that need to be put back together

Battlefleet Gothic: Crashing Armada - where do i begin...

The current state of this game is playable however unless you have actually put decent time into this game unlike many others who review this with a thumbs up or thumbs down, you probably have realised this game should not have been released in its current state. This review is also mainly about multiplayer which does include 2v2 (Partner invite) - I have played the single player campaign, it is enjoyable however this will be focused on online.

As someone who had access to the beta, I can assure you I was not 100% content that this game should have been released as a finished title. There are many issues that are still plaguing this game and without naming all of them I am going to point out the larger ones that have made this game almost unplayable for me.

Critical errors and crashes to desktops and bugs - This is the biggest issue for me and for many others who I have been in contact within the forums. Whats even more strange is the fact we never had this issue in the beta (not me anyway). This game constantly crashes in all modes, but more particular in battles where there are more ships such as in online 2v2. This alone breaks the game for me, there isn't a worse bug out there then a CTD and this is something you would expect in beta, not in a final release. (Edit) - I forgot to mention that ship abilities sometimes just do not work within battles and now a camera bug that see's your camera pan to the other side of the map and the only way of getting out is by alt F4.
Match making - Oh god where do i begin with the match making, this game is not optomised well for multiplayer and it seems that the problems are not as bad in 1v1 but within 2v2 its terrible. An example is me and my partner (Both level 3 admirals) versing two Imperial Admirals with Battle Cruisers and a Battleship. Rightio? I don't know if anyone has played MMO's like WoW but its like walking into a pvp zone as a level 60 and a horde level 100 just stops in to say hello. Its not good - and to those people who say its not unwinable its not the point, it breaks the game from a progression stand point. Another big issue is that even if you come against a higher level admiral and your say level 3, they can only bring as many points as you can (300 typical for that level) however the ships they bring in can be higher level. This is completely rigged as a level 8 light cruiser with full upgrades will decemate one without them. Match making is horrible.
Servers and Connection errors - The worse thing about joining a game that takes about 2 minutes is to find out your partner is also Russian and the game completely lags out and dies. Many times people are getting stuck on the Admiral show case screen (before you can select your ships). I am Aussie and constantly connecting with people in Europe where their latency and myself have been within the high 800's. Even if you manage to get past the ship sellection screen you wont be able to play more then 2 minutes until someone crashes due to latency.
Instability - The game runs pretty poor and has some real ugly textures up close, not only does it struggle on even high end cards such as an 980, I have heard horror stories with people with Radeon cards are getting fried. It doesn't seem like this game should be struggling but it might have something to do with why so many people are crashing. Something has happened between the beta and release that is causing this game to melt computers, so be warned.

This is already going on long enough so i'll stop here. All people have to do is look at the forums before purchasing this game and search for any of these issues, you will find a boat load of them. Its easy for people like IGN who shove a review on this game 4 minutes after release and its another for someone to actually put TIME into this game after release and then write a review with concerns.

Don't buy this game as of this moment until it is patched, its fairy cheap compared to many others out there.. however in its current state it's not worth your hard earned dollarydoos.

(Edit) - I have just been messaged by someone who I am gathering thumbed down this review who I will not name, plus I don't really care but I will point out this lovely young fellow also posted  a thumbs up review of this game with less then 30 minutes of gameplaying saying Buy this"

reviewText:
Battlefleet Gothic: Armada. First things first, do I recommend it? Wholeheartedly yes!

Now that's out of the way, on to my thoughts about this game. I will be say that I've decided to base my review on the feel and atmosphere of this game, it's faithfulness to the feel of the Warhammer 40k universe, especially with an eye to past 40k games. I won't be reviewing it on the gameplay in depth simply because I do not play enough RTSes to feel qualified to make an assessment either way.

Is this game faithful to the 40k universe? Very much so I feel. One of the most striking things personally was listening to the soundtrack, the background music, the dialogue, and finding a welcome familiarity about it. It's as if the people in charge of the music at Tindalos Interactive had sat down to listen to all of Dawn of War II's music and dialogue. Some of those ship captains sound like they could be voiced by the Lord General in DoW2: Retribution. The music, with long mournful organ notes and soaring choral performances, is eerily reminiscent of DoW2: Retribution too. This helps the game feel a strong connection with previous 40k titles from Relic.

Set against the backdrop of the 12th Black Crusade, the story thrusts you into a pivotal role in fighting against the various enemies of mankind. The weight of expectations lends a tension to each mission, even though mission types are picked from a standardised set. Despite that you do feel a sense of progression and each battle feels unique. The levelling up of ships and your admiral, and the amount of combinations for ship builds, gives you that additional sense of progression, and the motivation to want to win every single battle. Add in epic clashes involving ships of tremendous infamy such as the Terminus Est, and you feel a firm sense that you're right at the heart of the 12th Black Crusade.

I personally also love the difficulty scaling. I think it's perfect. Easy is just about right for casual players like me, normal is challenging, and hard and heroic are perfect for those who're bored easily if they're not juggling 9 chainsaws on fire. Something for everyone, just the way inclusive gaming should be.

Conclusion: for any 40k fan who's been bemoaning the lack of any serious 40k titles over the last few years, this is the answer to your prayers to the God-Emperor/Ruinous Powers/Gork & Mork/Greater Good or whoever it is you pray to... heretic. I would recommend it even at its full price, and I hope that more content is to come. The foundations are there for this to be the big spiritual successor to DoW2, and I hope Tindalos Interactive seizes that opportunity with both hands!

reviewText:
Our thoughts light the Darkness that others may cross space.
We are one with the Emperor, our souls are joined in his will.
Praise the Emperor whose sacrifice is life as ours is death.
Hail his name the Master of Humanity.

Battlefleet Gothic: Armada is a sublime recreation of Battlefleet Gothic, a now sadly defunct Games-Workshop board game set in the grim-dark universe of Warhammer 40,000. You take command of a fleet of ships and traverse a 2D board with your vessels having to take careful notice of their manuevering and alignment with enemy vessels and all while avoiding (or using to your advantage) various environmental hazards (such as debris fields). The game takes careful notice of finer details such as momentum and these details can even influence your tactics during battle. A great (and dramatic) example being the ability to sail a ship into an enemy vessel; ramming them with your own spaceship. Aim well and use the correct ships for this tactic and it can be very useful for dispatching tougher foes.

Every servant has his place, no matter how lowly or modest. To know it is his greatest comfort, to excel within it is his greatest solace, and his master's contentment is his greatest reward.

As the commander of your fleet you get a choice of many different ships, this selection expanding as you fight in more battles and yourself gain experience, that can grow with the gaining of experience during battle. This then allows you to fit them with skills, upgrades and customise their crew priorities. These features might seem slightly overwhelming at first but with a careful understanding of the game mechanics they can allow for quite a lot of tactical customisation in a fleet.

Contact with alien races always renews one's faith in humanity. It is my belief that foreign travel narrows the mind wonderfully.

In both Singleplayer Skirmish and Multiplayer you may command one of four discrete races: The Imperial Navy, Chaos, Ork Pirates and Eldar Corsairs. Each race is very distinct in the ways that they play and the tactics they favour. They are far from simply different skins on the same ships. Both Orks and Eldar can prove quite challenging to play, with the game recommending the Imperial Navy and Chaos for beginners. I second this notion!

The universe has many horrors yet to throw at us. This is not the end of our struggle. This is just the beginning of our crusade to save Humanity. Be faithful! Be strong! Be vigilant!

The Space Marines and another, yet unannounced fleet, are yet to be added and buying the game early means you can get these DLC for free on release bringing the total number of playable factions to 6. I'm personally interested to see how the Space Marine fleets and the Imperial Navy differ tactically.

All ahead full and damn the torped...--

There are bugs, there are imbalances in multiplayer and the races can be quite different and difficult to get used to both fighting as and fighting against. Will this stoke a heavy competitive e-sport scene? Unlikely. If you're looking for a fun stratagy game set in Warhammer 40,000's deep universe then this is a great choice full of flavour, solid gameplay and a long single-player campaign with promise of an OK multiplayer experience.

reviewText:
Can't recommend this game enough.

- Customisable ships including factions which affect skins and traits
- Engaging gameplay with a lot of room for all kinds of playstyles
- It's a 40K game through and through, nothing feels lacking in that area
- Well-told campaign narrative with very nice art (though I've not yet finished it at time of writing)
- Imperial Navy porn for days
- Able to shove the prow of your ship down the throats of xenos and heretics alike
- Great voice acting

It's not perfect, there are slight issues such as balancing and other things mentioned in other reviews, but honestly none of them take away from the game all that much. At least not for me personally.
- Favours could do with some adjusting (some are obviously better than others)
- Chaos is at a disadvantage quite often
- Don't go online until your skirmish admiral is an ♥♥♥-kicker and you know your ships, because chances are the opponent you end up facing is pretty good and has shiny ships

9.5/10 - would make the Emperor proud.

reviewText:
Hello, welcome to my review of Battlefleet Gothic Armada.

This is a tactical ship battle simulator on a 2D plane with a limited scope. It is mostly 3 or 4 ships you control. You can level up your Admiral (player avatar) and get more ship slots to a maximum of 1 battleship, 2 battlecruiser, 3 Cruiser and 4 light cruiser slots. Your ships get xp in battles and you can customize them with upgrades. Light cruiser have 1 skill , cruiser 2, bc 3 and the battleship has 4 skills. It plays like your generic 18th hundred line ship battle simulator. Manovering, broadsiding and entering enemy ships, you know the drill.

In the story singleplayer campaign you have a star map to decide which mission you take. The planet systems are not animated but some dots with lines between them, to represent shipping lanes, but you never actually drive around in your ship. For each chapter there are main story missions you have to do before going on random missions. In the singleplayer campaign you play as imperial navy.

For each chapter there is a comic cutscene not a video but static pictures with limited animation.

The story is average, the babbel between different characters is quite nice, the atmossphere is good and warhammer40k like. Mostly it is about evil chaos trying to steal artifacts and you the good" guys trying to stop them. Imperials are a bunch of theocratic space nazis
date:
so they are not really that good.

There are 5 edit: 7 mission types:

1. Cruiser Clash: Fight between two fleets or more.
2. Assassination attack/defend: You have to detroy a target ship before the time runs out and it manages to escape.
3 Breakthrough attack/defend: You have to destroy some defense platforms and then escape with your line ships to    the other side of the battlefield
4 Data steal attack/defend: You have to board an target ship and steal data. Then you have to escape with the data on your ship.
5. Planetary attack/defend: You have to fly your capital ships to a target zone in time. You get a point each time you reach a target zone in time. You have to get 3 target zone out of 5.
6. Space station defend/attack: You have to attack or defend a space station.
7. Convoy escort defend/attack: You have to defend your convoy transports or destroy them as the attacker.

The difficulty is really hard even on easy. The ai ships fire their skills with pin point accuracy and it is really hard to get anything done in the campaign. The random missions are a little easier until you have to fight orks in cruiser clash or eldar in data steal or assassination. Then it gets really ugly. Tindalos did not bother to implement difficulty settings for the ai
recommended: it is playing at full potential in every game. Not that the AI is intellligent or anything. reviewText:
Ok so I have a few hours on record playing this game. I jumped onboard this particular bandwagon back when it was just the chaos and imp fleets during the beta. I put a few hours into the beta (65 odd of my current total) and the rest into the single player campaign.

I should point out, i am an AVID fan of the 40k universe. I play practically every tabletop game that is made by games workshop and even the rpgs etc made by fantasy flight games along with having read just about every book set in the 40k and old world universes. So i feel i have a reasonably good knowledge base within which to set this review.

I will also point out, that this is my first proper game review. I am usually more of a watcher and a waiter when it comes to beta/Early Access games, but this one in particular caught my eye. Firstly it is due to my love of the old Battlefleet Gothic tabletop game. I played that game endlessly with friends and family. I love the idea of piloting a half dozen lumps of ceramite and plasteel 5+ kilometers long into HOLY BATTLE WITHT THE BLIGHTED HERETICS!!! ahem..... its exhilirating... and so is this game.

I feel that this game has kept particularly true to the tabletop game in regards to its play style. it feels simliar to me. When i moved my ships around the table and tried to line up nice dual broadsides or a choice torpedo spread, the sluggishness of those gigantic hunks of metal moving around the void is extremely similar to how i feel when im trying to turn my battlecruiser abeam of another vessel to unleash the EMPEROR'S HOLY WRATH UPON THE FOUL XENOS!!!!!! .... sorry... caught up in the moment.

My point is that the games feel very similar and i like that. Even the other races have a feel similar to playing them on the tabletop, excepting that a battle can be over in a matter of minutes if you maneuver correctly and pincer your foe, or corner them (in the case of a data retrieval or assassination mission). however, i have also had engagements that lasted over an hour as my opponent and i tried desperately to out turn or out thrust one another and bring down their last ship (with my last light cruiser on 100 hp and busted ♥♥♥ shields/guns/engines..... (speaking from experience on that one).

Ok since i feel like im blabbing on a little much, i will attempt to get back on track and wind this novel up.

So Pros:

- Nice graphic effects,
- I like the sounds and music (very gothic)
- The gameplay is fun and challenging if a tad repetitive
- Replayability (4 races with a view to more and many different ship configs) is great, i never felt bored, usually i would log on thinking hmm id really like to try eldar today and see if i can get the hang of keeping those damned holofields up all the time"... or something similar. there was usually always something i wanted to do in the game.
- The campaign is fun and varied - i was pleased to note that there are a bunch of non standard mission types mixed in with the "standard" complement of missions (cruiser clash
recommended:
assass etc) it keeps the campaign feeling new and not TOO repetitive.

Pros:

- Price. The cost is kinda high
hoursPlayed: but i also kinda feel its worth it... almost...maybe slightly less.... but then ive ALWAYS thought that... about basically everything GW has ever put out... so why should this be any different :-P - ever bought anything from Forge World? case in point.....\n- Bugs. As ive seen mentioned and experienced myself
voteText:
there is still a couple of bugs that carried over into the main game and a few typos and tooltips that need to be corrected to show the data for the race that you are playing... eldar dont technically have "lances" etc...


TL;DR

I like this game. ive played it a fair bit. i dont mind games that have a bit of a grind in it

reviewText:
'Battlefleet Gothic: Armada' is a laudable attempt at sincerely recreating the now long and lamentably defunct tabletop wargame, 'Battlefleet Gothic' produced by Games Workshop as part of their old Specialist Games range. A spin-off of their iconic Warhammer 40,000 universe, this new iteration of the game perfectly captures the atmosphere of the 41st Millenium as envisaged in Games Workshop's famously grim, dark future where mankind's vast and crumbling stellar empire is beset within and without by physical and spiritual peril, the likes of which split the very stars themselves asunder.

The three core elements of the game, fleet management, campaign management and actual combat, are all redolent of the original tabletop experience. Fleet management harkens back to the RPG elements of Game Workshop's earlier titles, and whilst some might initially find the micro-management a little overwhelming, it becomes surprisingly intuitive and the various information panels (both static and pop-up) do readily clarify the player's various options, neatly and succinctly. Campaign management ostensibly provides chained systems of planets, which are a familiar staple of Science Fiction RTS games, however the player will more often than not find themself directed by the narrative to particular deployments of note, although it is worth noting, there is some degree of oversight in fully explaining the campaign interface and players should keep an eye on their deployment points, so as not to end turns prematurely and waste opportunities to claim systems not tacitly mentioned by the narrative. Players should also make regular return visits to Port Maw, to upgrade and re-equip the vessels available to them, as they earn reknown (the game's currency equivalent)

Actual combat will not be to every gamer's taste, as the game endeavours to remain faithful to its tabletop roots, thus whilst action notionally occurs in 'real time', heavy use of a 'bullet time' style mechanic is necessary to not only allow players to better manage combat, but to plan ahead and perform more elaborate manouvres, switch between various firing options (such as fore or broadside), utilise special abilities, make best use of certain weapons (such as ensuring torpedoes' trajectories take them to where a target *will* be, rather than where they *are*), and target specific systems on larger vessels moment-by-moment. That being said, this does allow for a decidedly tactical level of gameplay, provides immense satisfaction when strategies are successful, and is conducive to maintaining the atmosphere of the player as an admiral responsible for conducting every key facet the intricate ballet of void warfare between massive, kilometre-long vessels designed to utterly annihilate one another.

The most notable and annoying absence in the game however, is the lack of replay feature for individual battles in the narrative campaign. Whilst veteran players may appreciate this degree realism, and the fact that the campaign appears to adjust accordingly (failures losing you systems or assets), less experienced or more casual players may find this a frustrating oversight, as it appears one lost battle can significantly alter the character and progress of the overall narrative campaign and this can be especially disgruntling in situations where the player may feel their loss was more to do with the nature of the scenario and various unknown variables it was impossible to 'out play', rather than any failing on their part. Many such scenarios would still prove no less challenging if replayed, but the player would at least have the opportunity to try out different fleet compositions and strategies, and not feel cheated of battles that are arguably unwinnable unless one happens to chance upon the winning method straight off the bat. Hopefully, this is an issue which will be addressed in future updates.

That being said, if you are at all familiar with the Warhammer 40,000 universe, were lucky enough to enjoy playing the original tabletop version of this game, or are currently playing one of its many spiritual successors as part of the current renaissance in tabletop gaming (such as Star Wars: Armada, Dystopian Wars, Firestorm: Armada, Halo: Fleet Battles or Dropship Commander), then this is an absolute must as, small niggles aside, you will not be disappointed: Especially with the promise of further development to come, and the possibility of future DLC including other iconic races and forces.

In the God-Emperor's name...

reviewText:
I'm going to make a few things clear before I start.

1: This review only covers the single player/skirmish modes - I've not played and therefore have no opinion on the multi-player aspects.

2: I bought the game outright after playing the early access and was hopeful of so much more, so my opinion is coloured by the lack (essentially) content/depth that could have made this an outstanding game in addition to the other issues I shall expand upon.

I am something of a 40K afficionado, I have I suspect if not -all- the novels, short stories and audio titles, then probably very close unto. I used to play various GW table top many (many) years ago and have numerous fond memories of doing so. When this game was announced I was thoroughly excited, and the early access whetted that appetite.

Sadly though, the end product as delivered is a significant let down. The campaign mode is unforgiveably shallow, being probably 90% rinse and repeat of the same few mission options time and time again. Escort, blockade, assassination, extermination (or Cruiser Clash as they've dubbed it) and what essentially passes for a flavoured Escort mission parameter with the 'Data Courier' missions. To be clear, I persevered through to the end of the single player, just to be thorough. But time and time again was sadly dissapointed by the entire game.

For a franchise that is so very very rich with content; both canon in nature from GW and Black Library, and non-canon from everywhere else - the Black Crusades should have provided an expansive canvas upon which the developers could have done so so much. This is not the case however.

Content aside, there are numerous issues with the game itself.

* The UI in the map-mode is overly large and clunky, the ship lab UI is often un-responsive and often unclear. Especially the upgrades, requiring an overly large amount of back and forth between the few hull types to see quite what each option really gives you.
* Over all ship types are actually quite limited, and nothing like the scope there could have been to really make a pattern of hull your own; and the upgrades system for crew, ship modifications and extra abilties feels like a veneer.
* The game mode also sufers from scaling issues, the max zoom-out level puts me very much in mind of the original Dawn of War so what you can see with any sense of relevance is far far too limited. Indeed at the larger end of weapons for the Imperials, your ships are firing on targets that your unable to track effectively or sensibly.
* Game audio is also painfully unlevelled - the story missions with their unique audio snippets are often drowned out by the music that is otherwise quiet when you're playing at any other time - especially in the last mission in fact where I quite literally couldn't hear a word that was being said and had to rely on the text boxes as given.
* The campaign mission parameters and limitations are ludicrious, possibly even antiquated; rarely did I have more than 3 or 4 ships on the field at any given time, often only 2 in order to have some escort ships; and sadly this same limitation is carried over into the skirmish modes.
* The skirmish mode is a direct clone of the campaign modes with no expansion on the idea what so ever; making it seemingly impossible to do anything more involved - again, a limitation for no reason that I can discern. GIven the immense success of the Apocalypse mod for Dawn of War, I'm amazed that GW licensed developers haven't managed to work out what most of the player base actually want from GW games...
* Missions are timed for 20 minutes, but whether it's my play-style or not, I rarely had any fight that lasted more than 5 minutes. The data-runner missions especially.
* As mentioned already, the upgrade paths for ships feels only skin deep - and in truth most of the abilities I never used at all.

All in all, I honestly wish I'd spent my money elsewhere - I appreciate that they've probably built the game in mind hoping to build an active multi-player community and I wish them luck with that; but as we've seen with so many games over the last decade, single player feels to have been an after thought - and in this case a very poorly executed one at that.

reviewText:
A lovingly recreated tabletop game turned into an RTS. Game is all about micromanaging a fleet of giant spaceships but remember that the game is based more on ship of the line combat than space combat and as such there is no 3D plane. Players coming from the tabletop will notice that the game has added skills, these range from bombs and sensor disruptors to probes and boost refuels. There's a total of 4 factions as of release:

Imperial Navy, the jack of all trades featuring highly armored prows and mighty nova cannons.

Chaos, a long range fleet that focuses on kiting the enemy and features lots of carriers.

Orks, slow moving ships that loadouts are highly customisable, also expert rammers thanks to the Big Red Button" which gives them a massive speed boost but pretty much locks them to go forward until the boost runs out.

Eldar

reviewText:
There is two types of adaptations for games based on the Warhammer universe. The bad ones and the one we are hoping for. This one is of the second type.

It's done with a deep understanding and love for the background, it's done with a few ideas to improve the original boardgame it's inspired by, and avoid being a basic translation of it in video game.

Online multiplayer is a bit off, as Eldar came in late and destroyed balance, but developpers are reactive to players feedback so far.

I highly recommend this game. It's a good game for anyone who's looking for a science fiction version of tall ship combat. It's a great game for anyone who loved Warhammer 40K at some point in his life, and was looking for something else than a poorly done, cheap game.

reviewText:
Yes, another beautiful space game in Unreal Engine 4! In the Warhammer universe no less!

So far, I really like the game, though it doesn't come close to rivalling Homeworld Remastered. But it's not really meant to. It's literally taking the table top game and making it something you can play on the computer with nice visuals and effects. I like the campaign, though my cutscene audio stutters super hard and lags behind the artwork.

I also like the depth of customization, but I usually wind up spending most of my time in the shipyard deciding what to upgrade. Battles feel short, definitely shorter than the 30 minute - 4 hour matches I'm used to in Homeworld. There's a lot of ship-to-ship micromanagement, which makes me feel kinda ripped off if I lose a big fight.

All in all, worth a buy, though maybe at a cheaper price.

reviewText:
I wouldn't recommend this game at this time.

There are quite a few bugs left from the Beta, and some new ones to spice things up for you heh. For example I have had to give up playing the campaign due to a Fatal Error occuring frequently in mid-mission, which is when you can't save, the frustration can be felt quite strongly when you're doing one of the longer Story missions and just as you were about to win, Fatal Error. There is another frustrating bug that still occurs from Beta, where you get a UI option over a ship to Execute a captain that is routing from the battlefield, but the button is not clickable. This occurs so often that it feels like there is a dice roll to figure out if your allowed to click it. There is also another quite annoying bug in multiplayer, where you will spend Renown to get your ships back, but quite often the connection times out forcing you to force close the game, when you get back the Renown will be spent, but your ships will still be damaged, as if you hadn't spent it.

Speaking of UI, it is quite clunky, where you have to individually place each ship down while deploying, and if you want to redeploy, you can't just drag a box around them and select where you want them to shift over to, you have to click the UI button over each the ship to tell it you want to redeploy that individual ship. Which can be frustrating when your stuck using a majority of escort ships due to most of your fleet being stuck in the warp or too damaged to fight. There is also no way to lock fleet formations, so you'll likely have ships going at different speeds towards the enemy, even if you put them in a Selection Group (Ctrl+1, 2, 3, etc), as well as have them line up in a generic horizontal line if you do a group move order anywhere, which will lead to some ships deciding to cross into each other's path, causing crashes. It can also be quite frustrating since in the campaign, they suggest that you group your small fleet close together to cover one another, but it's quite difficult to do that without a lot of unnecessary micromanagement. If you're stuck doing a Transport Escort mission, good luck trying hide them in the center of your fleet, without your fleet abandoning them.

If your ships either get lost in the warp or destroyed, or even heavily damaged and kept out for several Turns" (they basically 1:1 used the same mechanics as the turn based campaign for the multiplayer)
date: you'll likely just enter missions with the minimum cruisers
recommended: and as many escort ships as you can get

I really feel like this was a bad idea and leads to you not wanting to bother actually playing missions until you have enough of your ships returned to service.\n\nAnother issue I have is the map

reviewText:

reviewText:
I really like this game and I won't leave a big long review for it.
On the whole I recommend this game. It is fun and engaging.

It however has several large issues. The only really good and fair mode to play in the game is Cruiser Clash (Deathmatch)
The remaining modes are all lopsided for one side to win.
Convoy: Easy win for attackers. Destroy super squishy and super slow transports.
Data Recovery: Easy win for defender depending on faction, Start in one corner and then just run across the back of the map. Warp out, you win.
Assassinate: Refer to Data Recovery, Except a wee bit harder since you have to blow up the enemy Flagship.
Planetary Assault: Defender's favor. 4 extra defense platforms plus your ships. Attacker has to split up fleet to have a hope of reaching objectives in time.

Lot of people complain about blockade but I honestly find that one to be pretty balanced. Platforms aren't very strong if you focus them and then just leave all but one Line ship behind and bee line for the other side. The difficulty is in breaching the enemy ships and blowing up the platforms.

Stay away from Multiplayer for now. Just don't do it. Bought this game and convinced my brother to buy it so we could play together. 3rd match we were paired against 2 players who brought level 9 Battlecruisers (Tier 3 ships) to the fight against our light cruisers and escorts. Needless to say we got wrecked hard. With no ability to ping on the map it becomes extremely difficult to coordinate movements.

reviewText:
When the game works, I enjoy most aspects about it. The ship combat is fun, and maneuvering around to avoid rams and firing arcs mid fight is a pleasure. I can't really comment about balance, but to find something that works requires experimentation and maybe the patience to read through the game's wikia after playing for 10-15 hours.

As for the bugs, it's a little obscene. I've been playing 2v2 with my friend and that seems to be where the most bugs are.

One game right from the start, I couldn't see what faction one of the enemies was and it was displaying the other enemies faction as something he wasn't. When we get into the game, it still displays incorrect factions when placing our ships. We get into the game, and the fight starts off well despite me choosing poor ships for the fight. Then after the first ram or two (I play orks), my camera jumps to the far side of the battlefield and refuses to move. The game auto-capitulates for me. During all of this, my friend sees the correct factions, doesn't have the buggy camera, and sees the enemy as capitulating. I got a defeat while my friend got a victory.

Other than that awkward game, I've run into two instances of fatal errors, two matches where I can't use thrust, three or four games where my friend can't use any abilities whatsoever, and two or three games where the improper factions are displayed... in 32 hours of play time.

I want to like this game because I've had a lot of fun in it despite some game mechanics I've found annoying. Frequently, ships try to leave battle early and if they're destroyed, you have to play a couple games without them while they get fixed. Often, you get matched against players with higher level admirals than you, and those are usually losses. The game puts you into random game modes where the only one I've enjoyed is cruiser clash. And because of the way the factions are set up, some games and some game modes are automatic losses or wins depending on your faction. Luckily, the games are usually under ten minutes.

If the bugs were fixed, I think I could recommend this game, but it's important to know what kind of game mechanics you'll be playing with.

reviewText: While I haven't played the multiplayer, and thus am unsure of how balanced that experience is, I have loved the singleplayer so far. The AI is competent and the graphics are gorgeous. The campaign is a bit short and is only from the perspective of the Imperials, but the cutscenes are absolutely beautiful. They really immerse you in the 40k universe. Be warned though, as the game has some features that are still unreleased, as well as balancing issues. Hopefully the developers will fix these problems with patches.The devs have said that they'll fix some of them in future updates, so check the discussion page. Overall, it is an enjoyable game that feels like 40k. If you are on the fence about it, wait until a steam sale or until the problems have been resolved.
