reviewText: I only played the single player, but I have to imagine some amount of this translates to multiplayer as well. I was also only playing on normal, which was the second out of four or five difficulties.\n\nThis game is incredibly frustrating, at least with the imperial navy (The only playable race in single player). Every faction is notably faster than you. This would be one thing, but a large number of mission types require you to catch and either board or kill another enemy ship in an extremely small time window (2-3 minutes). In either case, the target ship will do nothing but run from you, even if they're orks. It will take well over a minute just to reach their side of the map, even with your lightest ships with all possible speed upgrades, but being able to do anything meaningful in under half of a minute is very much based on luck. If your objective is to board the target ship, you may really only have a 30% chance to succeed in the board. If you fail, you just lose. If your objective is a kill, you have very few options to deal large amounts of damage quickly. If your enemy for either of these mission types is eldar, then your chances of success are even further diminished because of the eldar ships are *many times* faster(10x? More?) than you, and any attempt at a chase is immediately obviously futile. These are only the worst examples. Any mission that isn't a straight up firefight or that can't be turned into a straight up firefight, which is most, feels heavily weighted against you. The cost of defeat is also pretty high. A heavily damaged ship takes one day to replace, which is 2-3 deployments (missions), and a destroyed ship takes two. The amount of ships you have is very limited, so every ship that gets taken out of commission for any length of time is a huge loss. Even retreating a ship before it becomes heavily damaged has a chance to have your ship become lost in the warp" and be out for several turns. There are also further penalties for losing missions on top of the damage your fleet sustained

a lot of promise but ultimately a shallow, repetitive, and infuriating RTS. reviewText:
As it stands, this game is a monstrous disappointment. I'll edit the review in a few months if the devs get their ♥♥♥♥ together by then. I'm not going to hold my breath, though.

- the Admiral system is a nice quirk in the campaign, it can even be fun in skirmish/MP fights, BUT it becomes an unnecessary and annoying restriction when that is the only way you can play (there's no way to get around it and play a custom game with whatever ships you want to throw together).

- the addition of 'ship abilities' to personalise and specialise ships was a very nice idea which I gladly approved off when I first learned of it in beta. As it stands, though, it's been so horribly implemented the game feels more like DotA than an actual strategy game in space. Once you're past the low levels with your Admiral, you begin facign bomb & taunt spams in almost every fight. This is about as fun as passing a kidney stone the size of a football, coated in chilli sauce and ground glass. Instead of having a game focused on maneuver, it's devolved into a clickfest. Especially when you consider that the maximum points level is 700, with most games being at 4-600 points (that's 3-4 cruisers per side - SUCH FLEET< WOW).

- for some inexplicable reason the devs refuse input from the community, all the while saying how they love to communicate with us. Escorts are single ships (not squadroned) and without any limit. They gave almost all ships 5k detection range, while almost all the weapons in the game have 6k range, many of them going out to 15k (that's 2 and a half times their sight range). There is one upgrade that increases detection by 2.5k, but taking that you're gimped compared to close-range fighters who just take weapon upgrades to kill you even faster. Critical systems can be critted just like in the bgame (yay!) but for some unknown reason they can't be repaired. At all. Ever. So if you get your engines critted at the start fo the game, that's it, that ship will be a slow-as-molasses brick for the rest of the fight.

- balance is crap. Eldar are the biggest community pet peeve, with their ungodly powerful pulsars in the right hands, but at the same time all their other weapons are garbage. The latest patch, called a 'major update' by the devs, has had no balance changes at all. I suspect the devs are too stubborn to let go of their special snowflake ideas such as pulsars being an activated ability rather than a regular weapon and are thus stuck in how to balance it to be good in the hands of most players rather than broken in the hands of some.

- also regarding balance: all the ship upgrades, favours and skills increase ship points cost by exactly ZERO. So a ship with a whole bunch of upgrades, skills and favours will cost the enemy just as much as your freshly acquired version despite the fact that it will easily mop the floor with you.

On the positive side: the campaign, as much as I've played, seems nice and fun. Most folks I've talked to were happy with that, at least. The music is nice (but nothing extraordinary) and the graphics, as can be seen in the screenshots, are absolutely gorgeous. The UI looks good, though it works kinda clunkily, and the devs do love the universe, which can be seen even in the upgrade names and tooltips.

Frankly, my only sliver of hope is that some time in the next couple of years a good mod team will pick apart this game and do it right, otherwise it will be my biggest purchasing regret since Payday 2.

reviewText:
The game has a lot of potential. but at the moment its kind of buggy, and anti-cheat wasn't even put into the game until a week after launch, the factions are still a little unbalanced and the UI still doesn't work properly.

The campaign is playable (and indeed enjoyable) if you scumsave, since there are many missions where the enemy will just run from you for 3 minutes or just speed right past you giving you window of a few seconds to attempt to win. but you can always just save save save and retry retry retry. eventually the AI will kill itself by flying into mines

my biggest problem with the game is that the AI cheats its AS OFF.  on any difficulty above normal the AI receives extra ships ( up to 50% MORE ships than you have), early upgrades and early favors ( favors are faction endorsements, mechanicus, adeptes astartes,etc) several rounds before you are even allowed to purchase them. and for some reason the devs have included several missions where an AI 'ally (who will ram YOUR ships
date:
etc) gets half your deployment points. so on hard there are several missions where you are basically outnumbered 3 to 1 and are expected to somehow destroy all enemy ships or keep their biggest one from running away while you ally waste half the ships the player SHOULD have gotten. the ally AI (not the opponent AI of course) is also fond of flying around in circles doing nothing.

Multiplayer is fun at the lower levels. but once you start getting to the middle ranks you will frequently be pitted against players of a far higher level (which means that have MUCH bigger ships that are fully upgraded vs you tiny ships with only 1-2 upgrades)

trying to play with friends is currently a nightmare as you can not form parties or private lobbies.

all in all im a huge fan of the series and have high hopes for the game. but at this time i can not recommend it to anyone for $40. maybe after a few months of the devs doing all the things that should have been done BEFORE release we will start to see a AAA game emerge."

reviewText:
The best Warhammer 40,000 game in a long time, if not of all time.

The main gameplay loop of battles with small numbers of customisable ships with many abilities, and different mission objectives is just so much fun, so satisfying, and endlessly interesting to experiment with.

The level above that is the fleet management - the fact that ships can be disabled in battle, and you will lose them for the next few games, but that you can at any time voluntarily withdrawn any or all of your ships is just brilliant. It turns every game, which otherwise might be a self contained skirmish that doesnt mean anything, into part of a larger picture where you're not just thinking about this battle but the next two or three as well.

The visuals are beautiful. I found the voice acting and characters in the single player campaign to be the most engaging of any Game Workshop computer game I've played (and I've played most of them) - striking the best balance yet between rediculous melodrama, funny moments, and swashbuckling epicness!

Tthe single player campaign allows you to win or lose any individual battle, giving tangible benefits or penalties for doing so, but not *too* much so (it seemed to me) always possible to continue despite constantly feeling overwhelmed in the middle part when every faction is against you. I feel like this is a massive improvement over other games where you *must* win every battle, and I really enjoyed it - I'd encourage anyone about to start the campaign to play on Iron Man mode, so there's no temptation for save scumming, the result of every battle is permanent - it really adds extra tension to each battle.

The multiplayer experience so far has been equally positive, and carries over the persistent qualities and ship leveling from the single player, which is great. The one thing I would like to see improved is to give players a multiplayer game mode where they can completely choose both their fleet (without leveling) and the mission type. A practice mode essentially.

Further development of the game is also looking awesome with Space Marine, and Tau fleets confirmed to be on the way, and a Tyranid fleet is also a future possibility.

I have no hesitation in recommend people buy and play this game. Choose your faction and join the fight amoungst the stars. But remember, the Universe is a big place and, whatever happens, you will not be missed...

reviewText:
Wow!  Most excellent game.  If you like Warhammer...and if you like RTS...and of course, some giant space simulation battles, then this game is for you.
Every aspect of the game is just very well made.  And I will be playing this for a Very Long Time.

Pros:
Amazingly rich IP (warhammer 20k universe)
Great voice acting
Visually stunning backgrounds
Detailed and beautiful models
High degree of customization on ships/fleets
Multiple factions to choose from (and more on the way!)
Simple controls and interface, with seemingly limitless possibilities
Fantastic Campaign mode!

Cons:
A few bugs in gameplay

This game really has made me very happy.  I haven't had so much fun since Dawn of War II.  There are a few bugs here and there, and usually this is something that breaks a game for me.  I kid you not, I couldn't care less about little bugs here and there based on how awesome the rest of the game actually is.  And I'm sure that these will be ironed out in the future.

Well worth the money.  In fact, if they unleash more races in the future (Tyranids, Tau, and/or Necrons), I will loose the rest of my life to this game.

reviewText:
It is the 41st Millennium. For more than a hundred centuries the Emperor of Mankind has sat immobile on the Golden Throne of Earth. He is the master of mankind by the will of the gods and master of a million worlds by the might of his inexhaustible armies. He is a rotting carcass writhing invisibly with power from the Dark Age of Technology. He is the Carrion Lord of the vast Imperium of Man for whom a thousand souls are sacrificed every day so that he may never truly die.

Yet even in his deathless state, the Emperor continues his eternal vigilance. Mighty battlefleets cross the daemon-infested miasma of the Warp, the only route between distant stars, their way lit by the Astronomican, the psychic manifestation of the Emperor's will. Vast armies give battle in His name on uncounted worlds. Greatest amongst his soldiers are the Adeptus Astartes, the Space Marines, bio-engineered super-warriors. Their comrades in arms are legion: the Imperial Guard and countless planetary defence forces, the ever-vigilant Inquisition and the tech-priests of the Adeptus Mechanicus to name only a few. But for all their multitudes, they are barely enough to hold off the ever-present threat to humanity from aliens, heretics, mutants -- and far, far worse.

To be a man in such times is to be one amongst untold billions. It is to live in the cruelest and most bloody regime imaginable. These are the tales of those times. Forget the power of technology and science, for so much has been forgotten, never to be relearned. Forget the promise of progress and understanding, for in the grim dark future there is only war. There is no peace amongst the stars, only an eternity of carnage and slaughter, and the laughter of thirsting gods.

reviewText:
This is what happens when you make a video game and heavily base it off of a board game. A board game with an incredible concept. If you ever played Battle Fleet Gothic table top, then you would have already bought this game. If I wrote about all things that are great with this game, you would be reading this for hours, so I will break it down into the overall concept.

There are no bases, but in between multiplayer matches, you will manage your fleet, you earn points and levels, which allow you to get more cruisers of different classes. Personally, I don't really like this system, and would prefer if you didn't have to grind to get more ships. You select which ships you bring into combat, and the mission is randomized. You have your main cruisers which are your main focus generally, and you bring along smaller frigates. These frigates lack fire power but have speed and meneuverability, they are great for scouting, getting behind the enemy cruiser where it can shoot without fear of retaliation, but another interesting purpose is intercepting ordinance. For example, an enemy cruiser just launched a bunch of assault boats to board one of your cruisers, your cruiser alone won't be able to destroy them all, and as such will take critical damage, but if you keep a frigate close, you can send it over to intercept the bombers, the turrets on the frigate will shoot them when it's close enough. The same can be done against torpedos.

Your cruisers are slower, but durable, and it is so interesting the things you can do with them. In a convoy escort mission, you can use your cruisers to sit between your frigates and an enemy ship. the enemy projectiles will physically hit your durable cruiser instead of the fragile escort behind. You can use your ships to ram others, the bigger the ship relative to the ship it hit, the more damage it will deal. Imagine using a light cruiser to pit meneuver another cruiser that is chasing one of your ships. All these things are possible.

They also added an upgrade system in the game, which has some nice upgrades, and some stupid ones. Like taunt, which is just silly. there are things that help you detect and identify enemy vessels, and certain offensive weapons like bombs, and statis bombs. The latter freezes time for all the ships caught in it for 15 seconds, leaving them vulnerable to lance fire. it may seem like a long time, but you must understand, in this game, it takes several minutes to kill a cruiser, unless you absolutely muder it, catch it in a bad position and focus fire on it, then it can die in 30 seconds. Except for the Eldar which will die in 10-15.

The balance between the ships so far seem fair, with the exception of the Eldar, as of now they are too weak, because of their stupid shield design, as long as they move they take less damage, but the problem is, it doesn't prevent lighting strikes. As in a cruiser teleports a boarding party onto the enemy ship. You can't prevent that unless you get lucky, you get  in range to shoot and they will lighting strike you, no matter what you do. If you lose a sail, you lose a portion of your speed, which means your ship is screwed, it can't escape so it will die. They really need regular shields like all the other fleets
_____________

I am rambling a bit, but there is just so much to this game I can't fit it all in this review, bascially, the mechanics in this game are very unique, the game is fun, and the strategies numerous. Which people seem to have problems with. So I will name a few to help you out.
_____________

When fighting the Imperials Always assume they have a nova cannon in their fleet, spread your ships out as you approach. make sure they can't identify your frigates, those are easy kills for a Nova Cannon.

When playing as Orks, make sure you have a few Launch bays, you can send boarding parties far away, weakening the enemy ships to finish off later. When fighting orks that do this, make sure you keep your frigates near your cruisers, your frigates have to intercept them.

When playing as Eldar, the running silent order only really works with them, because they are so fast, you can have one of your ships distract an enemy, while the others stealthily move behind for a surprise attack. Also as Eldar, never cluster your ships, already spead them out, your enemies will never be able to catch them and allows you to attack at any angle if they turn their back on one of your ships.

When defending a convey, always make sure your cruisers stay near the Transports, don't leave them with out a guard, if you do, your enemy will ram the ships which will kill them in seconds. If you keep your cruisers in the way they can't hit your transports. When doing convoy escort as Eldar, you can't keep your ships near your transports, because you can't soak fire. spread your tranports out, and have your warships hound your enemy as they persue the transports. Get behind them and shoot, they can either turn around to engage you, but then your transport gets away, or they can accept it and chase the transport as they get gunned down. It's pretty bad no matter what they do.

Torpedos aren't just for damaging your opponent, they are great to deny area(cutting off escape routes, etc.). You launch many torpedo salvos in an area, your enemies can't go there now. Torpedos are really only effective if deployed in mass.

reviewText:
Battlefleet Gothic: Armada is an RTS about space battles between huge amazingly designed spaceships.
There's no base building or resource management, only spaceship battles.

I haven't played much multiplayer (mostly because I got destroyed there), so I'll focus on my singleplayer and skirmish experiences.

The game puts you in the command of a space fleet.
You start with a couple of light cruisers - they are relatively fast, but have light weaponry and are quite squishy.
You'll gain XP, level up both your ships individually and yourself.
Leveling up ships will allow you to upgrade their skills, level up crew (that'll boost ship stats), and install new ship skills.
You won't be able to get all upgrades, so essentially you are forced to specialize your ships for variety of roles - from long-ranged snipers to close-quater assult ships.
Leveling up yourself will get you more slots for more ships (thus allowing you to have a wider roaster with more specializations) as well as to get higher class ships - cruiser, battlecruisers, etc.

Campaign is built in a very XCOM-y manner - you can win or lose missions, but the campaign will continue.
And the result will depend on winning or losing key (story) missions.
In addition to story missions, you'll get invaders who try to capture your worlds.
Losing worlds would mean losing bonuses or getting debuffs.
And, of course, there's no way to reclaim all of the worlds - so you'll have to pick carefully.

The combat mechanics are somewhat unique as well. You'll have to angle the ships to get the best shot.
You'll have to speed up or slow down your engines to evade enemy fire or align properly for that best shot.
You'll have to use your skills and maybe even run away to keep your ships safe.
Combat is pretty fast paced - it usually takes about 5-10 minutes of real time per battle.
But if that's too fast for you - there's always a way to slow down time to carefully think your next move through.
In general, it's a pretty enjoyable experience for a casual RTS player like me.

Talking about the downsides - so far I'd only had a few crashes after alt+tabbing too many times. And that's about it really. Game runs at solid 60fps, no bugs were encountered.

Watch my first impressions here:
https://youtu.be/QpnAwLQ43Sw

reviewText:
If you're a fan of the 40k universe, rts, space ships, or all of the above like myself, you will almost certainly love this game. It provides the intense moments of adrenaline filled close-quarters fleet combat, as well as the opportunity to set up intricate strategies and ship formations. The progression in this game is phenomenal also.

TL;DR Buy this game if you like rts or 40k

9/10 The Emperor Protects

reviewText:
Inexcusable.

Forget the 40k license and don't let that buy forgiveness here.  The campaign is not so much difficult as it is mean.  If you lose two battles, then you get punished by only being able to declare one battle per turn - which means the enemies gain ground twice as fast.  It's an instant death spiral, and there is no retry" button when you lose.

Hey
date: but you're here for the multiplayer right?  That's the real reason someone wants this game - to play with their friends
recommended: or maybe competitively against random strangers
hoursPlayed: or even dream of league play.  Well
voteText:
none of that is going to happen at all.   I'll list this out very specifically:

1. You cannot invite a friend to a 1 vs 1 game.  Period.
2. You can only play 2v2 against 2 random opponents if you invite a friend.
3. You cannot ever choose who your opponents are.  So you'll never fight anybody you know.
4. There is no comp-stomp cooperative PVE.
5. You cannot choose what points limit of battle you're going to play - you always play maximum size for your level (which there are 8 ranks).  So
commentsCount: etc...  You'll always play top tier
column16: and have no choice in it.\n6. Balance - don't even consider that the four factions will be in any semblance of "balance".  Even in the tabletop that doesn't happen.  However
column17: GW compensates for this by letting you have 1000 points to spend and you buy units and abilities from that pool.  Overpowered things cost more
column18: so it sorta balances out.  Here
column19: my cruiser costs 100 points
column20: and so does everybody else.  And it doesn't matter if I have rank 1 or rank 8 upgrades on it
column21: still 100 points.  So
column22: good luck with that.\n7. Multiplayer connection problems are fierce and constant.  2v2 games rarely complete without one of the four players getting dropped.  There's a particularly nasty bug where even in 1v1 you can have the camera snap to the corner of the map and none of your key or mouse inputs work - yet you're still in the game.  There's also no protection against alt-F4 logging out if you're losing either
column23:
so I never know if someone quit because I was winning or they got bugged up.
8. If Tindalos doesn't get their act together QUICKLY then this game will be a ghost town in 2 months or less.  Look at steamcharts for the population of their previous title Stellar Impact:

Month 	        Avg. Players
Last 30 Days 	        1.8
April 2016 	        1.9
March 2016 	        1.8
February 2016 	1.9
January 2016 	        2.6

There is some hope here
column24: if they fix this thing.   The player base has been 100% the nicest folks.  Everybody says "gg" after a match.  Nobody has been a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ about losing or gloated about winning.  Mainly we discuss bugs
column25: or compliment each other on a tactic that worked.  There hasn't been a lot of "cheese" since the big nerfing that went on in the first patch.\n\nLook
column26: I don't expect that my Orks are ever going to be competitive against Eldar because they're super fast long range and I'm super slow short range
column27: so they can just kite me all day from beyond taunt radius.  I'm fine with that
column28: because it can be fixed in due time.  The inability to play with your friends and inability to play a match to completion due to disconnects is going to break this game's back before it has lived long enough to get fixed.\n\nTindalos still has Stellar Impact priced at $10
column29: while it has ZERO player population.  It's not a horrible game
column30: but even the best game is worthless if nobody is playing it.  Why aren't they wise enough to drop it to $2 or even go freemium with it and pump the population back up
column31: and then make money on DLC?  If they're not saavy enough to see that writing on the wall
column32: then I have zero faith they're going to do right by this title either.\n\nThe 40k license buys a lot of forgiveness about balance
column33: because 40k never had any balance in any incarnation.  But it makes us double sensitive about quality - and you gentlemen are squandering that carelessly.  This game needed 6 more months of closed beta patching before you let it hit the street.  Now it might be too late.\n"

reviewText:
So yea, I love a good strategy game, BUT there are VERY and I mean VERY few games in general that I have played that I find to be both frustrating as all hell, but just so damn FUN. I love the idea that position pretty much is everything in this game instead of just roll on uo and start blasting everything away. And when the intro videos for this game say mistakes will rarely go unpunished, well it wasn't kidding. You make a wrong move and 95% of the time it'll bite you in the ♥♥♥. I've only played this for about 11 hours or so for right now but my first run into multiplayer and I was up until 4 in the morning because I lost track of time playing this game. I deffinantly recommend this.

But enough praises time to whine and complain about some stuff.

1: The matchmaking could use some work, I play as the Eldar and I did a cruiser clash against some Orks in I think a 600 point game or something around there. Well, my level at the time didn't allow me to use Battlecrusiers yet, but the Ork had TWO plus a cruiser or light cruiser. I've had this situation happen several times and I'd get destroyed.

2: I find it slightly irritating how long it takes for a ship to officially die". Once you drop a ships health to zero
date: it takes about 2 seconds for it to actually explode and count as dead. I've lost several assassination matches to this.\n\n3: Nova cannons
recommended: not sure what the issue is but I'll repeatedly get insta shot by a Nova cannon volley with almost no time to react even with the time freeze active. Lost over half my fleet once.\n\nAnd lastly just something funny I find is how you can actually lost but still have a projectile or torpedo out and also kill the last target
hoursPlayed: so it's like a draw but since you either got zeroed first or got them to zero it won't be a draw."

reviewText:
Very fun game, I thoroughly recommend it to space rts players and those who are interested in the lore.

The atmosphere is the best done in a 40K game to date by far, the universe feels fantastic.

The tactics are deep and interesting, and each race plays differently to give you good variety. Torpedoes, ramming attacks, carrier tactics, and line tactics are all present and more.

Singleplayer campaign has an XCOM vibe, and you can alter the story by winning/losing certain missions that in the lore went a specific way, essentially changing the way the Gothic War plays. Also included is a single player skirmish mode, a custom game mode, and of course multiplayer with a progression system.

All this PLUS the fact that the devs are giving out the DLC Space Marine faction they are working on right now for free to anyone who buys the game before its released (plus a mysterious second DLC).

So the sum it up we have a great game that does 40K from a good dev and publisher. Overall 9/10

reviewText:
So. Battlefleet Gothic Armada. A game based in the Warhammer 40k ip based around the interstellar naval combat part of the universe. Based on the tabletop (kinda). Ad a 40k fan this sent me into a frenzy worthy of an ork warboss, enough to buy it in beta.
So let's get the good things out first. The game looks very nice. I like the design of the ships, they fit each faction fairly well and pay respect to the tabletop models. The mechanics are pretty good and keeps me on my toes trying to make sure I get torpedo strikes off at the right time and managing shields properly while making sure I don't get absolutely wasted. In multilayer I have played the imperium so far and I have to say that everything is pretty polished. The nova cannon still seems a little inaccurate for such an expensive point cost but whatever. I have yet to Crack into the campaign so I will not comment yet. There are also some bug fixes with the most recent patch that I liked as well, my imperial battleship not having all its abilities because of my mechanicus favor was annoying.
Now unfortunately we must get into the bad. Oh boy.
So the fact that my friend was hard crashing constantly while trying to play 2v2 isn't good at all to start with. A little confused how that made it out of beta. Speaking of Making it out of beta it feels like a lot of this game was rushed for release. There are match ups where I can't even control my ships' abilities because the game won't let me click on them. Also who the ♥♥♥♥ thought it was a good idea to put the tactical cogitators into multiplayer? They are abused so heavily to troll people by letting the timer bleed down, and My well timed torpedo strikes keep missing because every time the enemy hears a torpedo launch he outmanuvers them in slow motion.
Speaking of outmanuvering, who thought it was a good idea to let Eldar kite around the map for MORE THAN 15 MINUTES WITH 2 SHIPS LEFT. Battles happen in almost a minute or so and now because the enemy is a troll I have to wait 15 minutes so that some jerkbag to realize 2 light cruisers have enough health to tank his ♥♥♥♥ longer then he can keep firing torpedoes for me to avoid.
So yeah the timers need to be adjusted very badly and tactical cogitators need to be removed from multiplayer. Also ships of the line need a bit of buff or the orks need a bit of a nerf because I keep seeing ork escort spam decks that are just rolling over people and no one I've played with seems to be able to help counter them.
Basically to put all my complaints in a tldr format: Some ♥♥♥♥ made it out of beta that really shouldn't have and the game should have sat in the oven a little longer. People should not just give the game a positive rating because it's a 40k game.
All in all 6/10, needs improvement. I hope you can take this as a valid criticism and not a salt filled rant, as I would like to see this game improve.

^^That was from my reddit post. I have a new complaint. HOW THE HELL DO YOU PLAY WITHOUT SHIPS?!  WHO THOUGHT THAT THE REPAIR TIME WAS A GOOD IDEA FOR MULTIPLAYER!? WHAT IS WRONG WITH THIS DEV TEAM?! HOW IS 40K BEING HANDED OUT TO SUCH BAD DEVELOPERS?!

YOu should wait to buy this game. It is not in a finished state, nor is it balanced. I'm rating this a 4/10 at best.

reviewText: Played through the beta and enjoyed it very much. I spent a lot of my time on the skirmish mode and had fun playing online as well as the campaign but my favorite part is skirmish and custom. I enjoy lvling up my fleet and how I have to earn higher point games. The random enimes are fun and the fleets are actually more diverse and the strategies are interesting and need to be thought out based on your fleets strengths and weaknesses. Auto helps to limit micromanaging in most of the factions (except the eldar that are in a league of their own.) But is not required. The story for the campaign is based on the 13th black crusade, and is so far only played from the impiriums point of view. They plan to bring out more factions and I look forward to the new additions. I hope you try this game and look forward to battling you if you do.

reviewText:
This is a Warhammer 40K game in a 40K universe more than any I've seen in other games, the single player story feels like a constant battle. I played a little of the table top game in my youth and this captures its essence perfectly while taking elements of computer gaming as well. It feels Immersive and as if your part of the space battles. From what I can tell as well certain choices in the single player campaign have effects later on in the game which different parts of the story told differently.

Each faction plays differently and has its different strengths and weaknesses which may for interesting games. It has some nice customizable options aesthetics and appearance with some RPG elements such as abilities, skills, upgrades and crew. I would have to say it’s been a while since I’ve enjoyed a single player experience while not feeling a complete grind, not to long and not to short (just right).

However I would have liked some hotkey options for some of the abilities as this might have sped gameplay up, but overall these are minor issues. I would give this a thumbs up!

reviewText:
In the 41st millennium, there is only war, and plenty of dakka to go around.

Battlefleet Gothic is a great RTS for those who are interested in void combat.
While not completely balanced, the game itself boasts plenty of customization and upgrades as your ships gain experiance and technically renown.

Play as the balanced Imperials, boasting medium to long range combat, with the ability to ram into someone in a jiffy such as trolling the orks by counter-ramming into them then release a large amount of dakka at their face.

Chaos Fleets generally specialize at long range while keeping at a distance

Orks are Orks, its either you know what you are doing, or your an idiot who just decided to be comedy relief as canon

Eldar, those legendary arrogant space elves are back and dancing around the battlefield is fun while enraging your incompetant opponent. Legendary dancing, hit and run and crazy pulsars (Please nerf) (Jk)

While the grind may be too much for some, please be assured that it is always up to the player's skill, attention to enemy ship classification and of course adaptive capability to win a game. It is sometimes not fair but in the world of 40k, not everyone gets to die as heroes.

reviewText:
A wonderfully focused game- they kept development on scope and decided to do one thing and do it really well. This game is nothing but fleet based space tactics. They resisted the urge to shoehorn in other game mechanics like so many other games do these days, and it feels great for it. No crafting systems or basebuilding or companion gathering where it feels tacked on.

And this approach, this focus, pays off big time- that simple idea of fleet to fleet combat is executed beautifully in this game. It's easy to pick up the basics, but you can spend dozens of hours learning the intricate details of strategy here because of the depth of the combat. Ships take compartmentalized damage, various systems can be destroyed, and crews can mutiny- it's your job as a commander to figure out how to induce these problems for your enemy and how to adapt to overcome them when they happen to you.

Each of the factions feels completely different from each other, both in presentation (which is beautifully true to 40k lore) and in gameplay style. The presentation of the game never ceases to impress, even the menus and GUI feel so perfect for the 40k setting, and the graphics are gorgeous.

Overall, a must-buy if you're a 40k fan, and even if you don't like the setting you should give this a good hard look because it's one of the best real time tactics/strategy games in years

reviewText:
This is my first review in 20 years of gaming, which is worth noting on its own. I'll be brief and to the point.

This is a rather fresh concept, adequately implemented. Techically it's an Real Time Tactics game, where you field the fleet of several spaceships, which fights it out with an opponent's fleet of spaceships. The gameplay, widely speaking, consists of three major elements - building your fleet, choosing a fleet for battle, then fighting the battle.

The game is so-so for single-player, and will give you maybe 10-15 hours of SP campaign (which is essentially a series of scirmish battles in neat packaging) plus 20-30 skirmishing Vs the AI, if you enjoy that kind of thing. The AI is not very bright and as soon as you get the hang of it and learn to build your fleets properly, you will never lose a match again. That's about it with SP. The developers promise to release new fleets in addition to the existing four, so every fleet will take maybe 10-15 hours to totally max-out in the future.
Where BFG:A really shines however, is the multiplayer environment. The games are extremely enjoyable and live opponent far outstrips the AI. Going against other players, adjusting your fleets to the tactics and misconseptions or stereotypes, surprising the opponent with unexpected and awesome moves and choices is all the pleasure of this game.

Buy it if:
Hardcore PvP gaming doesnt scare you.
You're ready to learn and be on the losing end while you're at it.
You enjoy the thrill of an intense live skirmish AND you enjoy coming prepared
You're just looking for a calm PvE game with not much fuss (that's what it is Vs the AI)

Stay away if:
You are really annoyed by even minor bugs and crashes (the game has it, though not a lot)
You hate losing to an opponent, who is stronger then you
You don't enjoy investing time into preparation and planning of your force

reviewText:
I recommend this game to all Warhammer 40.000 and RTS fans out there because:

- Unquestionably one of THE best games that evoke the grim dark future feel.
- You play as the imperial navy in campaign (and other factions in MP) so its in space, and a good change from the usual SPEEHS MEHREENS
- Gameplay is well polished, easy game mechanics but hard to master them
- Persistant (?) fleet multiplayer (when a ship is destroyed or heavily damaged you have to wait for it to be repaired or spend in-game currency* to get them back)
*Don't worry there is no microtransactions
- Soundtrack is very good, it just feels right
- Campaign gameplay is inspired by Total War games
- Beautiful cutscenes
- Great voice acting
- If you purchase the game from steam or other official retailers" in two months after release you get the first 2 DLCs for free
- Very well optimized (i have a Core2Quad Q9400 2.6Ghz CPU while the game's minimum is Intel Core i5-2500 (3
date:
3 GHz) and yet it works very well at High and a few Epic settings)
- Maps are procedurally generated which means that you will avoid the situation of getting stuck replaying that one good map out of the horrible 8 total maps the devs made over and over and over again.
- You can execute the coward captains
- AI smart enough to make you feel threatened (at least on the difficulty i played which is Hard)
- Battles (in SP and MP) are not just Deathmatches (many other gamemodes)
- Frequent game updates (bug fixing
recommended:
balance improvements...)
- Balance seems good... at first

However as it is the case with everything
hoursPlayed:
the game has some flaws:

- Balance becomes a joke when Eldar fleets start equipping Pulsars (i'll remove this when they fix it)
- Some players report frequent crashes (personally i only crashed twice up until now)
- You only play as one faction in campaign
- You can play with a friend in 2v2 but no co-op
voteText:
compstomp or custom games where you can play against friends (strange i thought such features would be default for any RTS game by now however Devs promised they would add these features)
**EDIT**: The devs held their promise and added custom games where you can invite a friend to play with (vs AI) or against
- No replay system (which means that you can't rewatch your glorious victories in slow motion :'(
- Not enough dakka

In conclusion the game is fun

reviewText:
Short Version: An solid RTS with a good campaign and enjoyable multiplayer. Excellent immersion into the Warhammer 40k universe with cutscenes that will have you roar 'For the emprorer!' as the goosebumps on your neck reach maximum goosebumpiness. The game has issues but will provide at least 20 hours of enjoyable entertainment and I reccommend it to all RTS or Warhammer 40k fans

Long Version:
The campaign is very, very good. It extended strategic thought from individual fights to the wider campaign maps, forcing you to accept losses and priotise various resources over others whilst trying to please numerous factions and make game changing decisions. There is a clear, narrative curve, the game introduces you into world, mechanics and characters as briefly as possible, then the game throws a seemingly irreversible situation in your face. Your losses mount beyond your control and you cannot reverse this, merley stem the tide. However, the game never seems unwinnable, you are never left questioning what the point of it all is, it gives you a sense of deteremination to push on, in the name of the imperium, and hold with your every growing battlefleet and I shall mention much else for fear of spoling the experience, but the campaign is definitley the best part of the game.

The ships themselves deserve their own section. I personally love the imperiums ships (which you use exclusivbley in the campaign), they pack the weight to ram the enemy but retain the manuverability neccessary to escape botched rams or ambushes. I love the light cruiser the most because of its versatility, but the battleship is a close second, an almighty floating cathedral to the Emprorer with the guns that make heretics the universe over wet their pants at the thought of their firing (as you can tell I am now really into the universe). You also have access to upgrades, allowing you to supellement their abilities and imrpove in areas you feel require it, allowing you to create a fleet that matches your playstyle and make you think (Thats not a fleet, thats MY fleet).

Level design is mediocre at best really. The various missions presented in both the multiplayer and singleplayer are fairly basic and can easily be beaten when you work out some sort of strategy. Equally, the AI is not challenging enough at normal difficulty, it fails to prioritise targets, focus fire or keep its ships together, i felt i lost more ships to my own mistakes than enemy skill. True, its only normal difficulty, but a small spike in AI difficulty would immensley aid the sense of fear at the beginning of the game. The maps are dotted with small enviromental features which sometimes come into play (but usually don't), however the skybox (spacebox?) are always gorgeous really make you take a second look and just mutter 'wow'.


The multiplayer sees you creating a character within 4 possible factions:
The imperium (jack of all trades, master of none)
The Orcs (Tanky brawlers)
Choas (long range, overwhelming firepower)
Eldar( fast moving, hardhitting)

but it is plagued by balance issues i personally feel. Certain ork setups (i.e two heavy cruisers with tractor beams) and Eldar fleets are incredibly powerful and typically ROFL stomp oppenants into submission, the choas are very difficult to play well are can often be crushed but even a comlete newbie, the Imperial Navy will generally hold its own. I should mention everything I just said in regards to multiplayer is opnion, every player will be find their most like faction, or the one they can 'work' the best, and will likley disagree with me in what I have just said. But, the multiplayer works and is fun, it in now degrades the overall package.

I have probably missed some stuff but I do reccommend this game ferverntly. As an RTS fan but also a grand strategy buff, this game managed to work the shaft AND cup the balls in a way few games can, the campaign is immersive and intresting, bringing me back time and time again to push on to victory, the multiplayer isn't my thing but it rarley is. Again, if you like a good campaign, a good RTS, a good Warhammer 40K game or anything else i have mentioned, stop reading and get the game, you probably won't regret it!

reviewText:
Very fun and well-crafted RTS. The campaign has a so-so story but good enough mission variety, and reacts to how you're doing, so you can actually fail a mission and the story goes on, albeit it's going to have consequences. The campaign is hard, however, so don't start on a higher difficulty.

Gameplay takes some getting used to, but once you learn how to use the various ship types it's very fun. The sheer number of abilities and upgrades allow you to customize your fleet in a pretty significant way. The gameplay is fairly fast-paced but you can slow it down in single-player.

It does have a few bugs (such as some hiccups sometimes) and isn't that well balanced however. The campaign has a few difficulty spikes. Some mission types hugely favor one race over another; if you need to destroy or board the enemy flagship against an Eldar opponent, you're screwed since their ship is way faster than anything you have, for example.

Multiplayer also has poor matchmaking. Your level 1 ships might be matched against level 5+ ones in the hands of skilled players, that will just annihilate you effortlessly. So I would avoid multiplayer until a few patches down the road.

reviewText:
This is my first review in 20 years of gaming, which is worth noting on its own. I'll be brief and to the point.

This is a rather fresh concept, adequately implemented. Techically it's an Real Time Tactics game, where you field the fleet of several spaceships, which fights it out with an opponent's fleet of spaceships. The gameplay, widely speaking, consists of three major elements - building your fleet, choosing a fleet for battle, then fighting the battle.

The game is so-so for single-player, and will give you maybe 10-15 hours of SP campaign (which is essentially a series of scirmish battles in neat packaging) plus 20-30 skirmishing Vs the AI, if you enjoy that kind of thing. The AI is not very bright and as soon as you get the hang of it and learn to build your fleets properly, you will never lose a match again. That's about it with SP. The developers promise to release new fleets in addition to the existing four, so every fleet will take maybe 10-15 hours to totally max-out in the future.
Where BFG:A really shines however, is the multiplayer environment. The games are extremely enjoyable and live opponent far outstrips the AI. Going against other players, adjusting your fleets to the tactics and misconseptions or stereotypes, surprising the opponent with unexpected and awesome moves and choices is all the pleasure of this game.

Buy it if:
Hardcore PvP gaming doesnt scare you.
You're ready to learn and be on the losing end while you're at it.
You enjoy the thrill of an intense live skirmish AND you enjoy coming prepared
You're just looking for a calm PvE game with not much fuss (that's what it is Vs the AI)

Stay away if:
You are really annoyed by even minor bugs and crashes (the game has it, though not a lot)
You hate losing to an opponent, who is stronger then you
You don't enjoy investing time into preparation and planning of your force

reviewText:
Well oddly one of the most disappointing games I've played so far and before you disagree this is my opinion of the game (but Im still gonna rant about it though).

I will start off on the campaign and skirmish- the campaign has beautiful cut scenes which really get you into the mood of the game, as for the actual story its decent however i quickly became board of it,  I just felt like the game types off multiplayer were just implemented into the campaign and they tried to spice it up a little with different formations of asteroids or maybe a stupid crippled ship or something you have to protect, I think a good campaign is key for any game and it just didnt really work with me. As for the skirmish well what can i say you can build a fleet fight another ai fleet, hard to go wrong there but again is just boring after like two games maybe.

The multiplayer- it just sucks in my opinion, if you want to start off on a admiral and get a feel for a different faction well too bad you will get your ♥♥♥ kicked by other players who have already gotten battlecruisers and your three light cruisers have no chance. I think there could be a better filtering process to play with people closer to your level and also there needs to be a more random game type process because i swear to god all i play is cruiser clash and the very rare session of convoy and thats about it. As for the gametypes there needs to be more as it just feels lacking and eventually boring.

The ships- look beautiful, cool guns and sounds and thats where it stops, there is a complete lack of variety in this game with the ships and the weapons, there definitely needs to be more ship classes and types as well not just light cruiser, cruiser, battlecruiser, battleship, i just dont find that enough ship variation in a game revolved around ships. There are like three types of guns that kind of says it all really, some obviously suck compared to others.

Core gameplay- felt pretty good initially, cool new game and all and i waited quite a while for the game so there was an element of hype but the finished product (nah dont buy), it becomes boring and repetitious really quick, like within my first 8-10hours of the game I already felt bored and trust me i love these type of games so its not the genre i have a problem with its the game. Your ships are usually always clunked together, ramming is alright but not enough to redeem it. Theres a nice few little addons like skills and other things which are nice just not enough of them and you (like me) just cant be arsed getting them.

Theres a load more to rant about like how it presents it as being a awe inspiring 3D movement (not all flat on a board which completely sucks and i dont care if it was based off a board game it just completely sucks out the skill or fun of the game, beings stuck on a flat surface is just soooooooo boring and showing these great battles on trailers is just wrong especially as they are utter BS) and awesome battles, but really they are boring battles with like 5 ships on your supposed FLEET (in caps because it doesnt feel like a fleet at all) and well in conclusion the whole experience is just underwhelming.

If you want a decent warhammer stratergy game get total war warhammer

reviewText:
I’m a huge Warhammer 40K fluff fan (I read many of the books, and play the more widely appealing video games like the Dawn of War series and Space Marine/Eternal Crusade).

I love RTS games, too. I’d describe Battlefleet more like a Real-time Tactics game. The singleplayer campaign has been absolutely destroying me. Haven’t even had time to touch the multiplayer. I am on Turn 6 of the campaign, which is about 10-12 missions played.

You maneuver these giant space ships on a flat plane in space. The ships are super huge, so you need to account for some kind of space physics when executing the different thrusters, whether you are dodging some area-of-effect ability thrown by the enemy ships, or trying to line up torpedoes, or even committing to a last second ram.

In the singleplayer, you can slow down time to a crawl, but it’s a binary switch, either real-time or bullet-time. I feel like it doesn’t help tremendously during certain situations unless you’re having a lot of trouble managing all the thrusters of every ship in your fleet.

Launching torpedoes feels great. Ramming stuff feels super awesome. Teleporting a strike team onto an enemy ship as its shields are down and on fire in order to prevent it from warping out is awesome.

But man, the computer opponent, even on normal difficulty, is extremely brutal. If you like challenge in your real-time tactical stuff, if you crave micromanaging of a slightly different variety than StarCraft, this is it. The computer plays to the objective ruthlessly. I had to replay a mission five times before I got it.

In one mission, I needed to teleport a strike team onto an enemy cruiser to get data, but if they took out my shields and teleported their own dudes onto my ship then they’d steal that data back. So I needed to execute a bunch of stuff flawlessly and choose my fastest and most damaging ships, or the enemy would either be able to escape, or steal back the data and then escape.

In another, I had to protect an allied, giant capital ship from getting destroyed while it was not able to move at all. I finally figured out that it could deal with most threats from its front and that I should let it do its thing while I protected its rear, sometimes throwing my own cruisers in between it and enemy torpedoes just to keep the immobile capital ship alive longer.

Failing a mission also does not end the campaign. It makes the rest of the campaign harder, and probably even changes the story around. Being a tryhard like me, you can make a lot of save files to retry, but this process is not super quick, and there is no “restart mission” option in the pause menu. I feel like this kind of sucks. I know the devs sort of want you to live with your failures, but being a completely new player to this type of RTS, the friction in learning and the difficulty curve is massive enough. People will respond differently to this kind of thing.

The game’s interface is rough, and actually hard to read in some ways (text is tiny, sometimes in that really obnoxious “gothic style” font, and in some cases awkwardly cut off). I find myself using the bullet-time mode just to read various stats in the interface. There are hotkeys but you cannot rebind them.

It totally gets the WH40K stuff done very right. If you’re in for that atmosphere, look no further. All the voice-acting is over-the-top as it should be (a line from a commissar: “YOU HAVE BEEN PROMOTED TO FLEET ADMIRAL—THAT MEANS YOU’RE IN CHARGE OF THE ENTIRE FLEET!!!”), the cutscenes are almost all beautifully grim concept art pieces that are subtly animated, and the ships are intricately detailed in Unreal Engine 4.

As for performance, I was surprised to find that my Radeon HD 7870 runs the game very fine on Epic (the highest graphics setting) with the latest AMD drivers, even though my card is almost 4 years old. I was sure that it was just past the “minimum” requirements. However, before I updated my drivers, the game did crash twice on me, but not during critical moments.

tl;dr Real-time tactical space naval battles are great but very hard to master even if you are coming from games like StarCraft, the Warhammer 40K setting is perfectly done, game looks gorgeous and performance is better than expected with my four years old graphics card.

reviewText:
Pros:
+Campaign so far is a blast especially the part where you kill Heretics.
+Game can be VERY mico-intensive however is still easy to learn thanks to the tactical cogitator which slows down time for you to make decisions while killing Heretics.
+Lots of customization. Like A LOT. It’s pretty awesome how you can have 1 ship and outfit it for so many different uses, such as a close quarters Heretic killing machine or a long range Heretic harasser.
+The amount of detail on these ships makes the game very fun to look at especially after you beat the Heretics.
+Custom skirmish mode which allows for you to practice the scenarios you want to such as kicking Heretic @#$ over and over again.
+ You get to kill Heretics. ‘Nuff said.

Cons:
-Ork Fanboys… that’s probably the worst thing you’d have to deal with.
-Skirmish mode can feel a bit grindy at times. You have to play the same modes over and over again to level up to get bigger classes of ships and better modes. (At least that’s how I think it works, I never got some of the modes until I got much higher level… this could be bad luck or how it’s designed.)
-No standalone tutorial. The campaign slowly explains things as you go. But for people who want to jump right into skirmish and multiplayer this would have been nice.

Tl;Dr- This game is a fun and fast RTS with matches that range from 5-20 minutes. It’s mechanics are very interesting and has a deep depth of strategy involved. It still has a skill based component of micro-management that varies between races. If you like 40k and like RTS games, I highly recommend it. If you only like one of the two, I’d recommend watching some gameplay videos before trying this out.

reviewText:
Battlefleet Gothic is an excellent representation of 40k as per the Tabletop game bearing the same name. The ships are gorgeous to behold, the action frenetic and fairly distinct from race to race.

The lore is well represented, but with some concessions to gameplay, Nova Cannons (thanks to foolish people) have been nerfed to near-uselessness. But Torpedoes feel like they should, and the tactical and strategic options available are extensive, though people more interested in the meta" probably ruin the fun for themselves concentrating on mechanical elements instead of simply playing for fun.

But let's be honest
date: the Competetive folk seem to go out of their way to make a game 'work' as opposed to a fun diversion."

reviewText:
Ok lets start out with the simple question first.
Is this game a good Warhammer 40k game?
The answer is yes.
So now let me just say that for me at least everything has worked out fine with few to no bugs (mostly cosmetic) and only one hard crash during the beta and I am enjoying this game. Now I will say this is not a game that can compete with the Dawn of war series, but it does way better than any mobile games and any other games that has been released as of late in the warhammer 40k series. With that out of the way let me talk a little bit about the game. Now first this is a very strategic game and can get a bit complex if you are not prepared, but once you have gotten use to what you need to do the game gets pretty instresting. The four races that you will have are the Imperials, Chaos, Orks, and Eldar. Now single player (campaign/solo skirmish/custom battles) is ok. The AI is challanging in every mode except for easy and as a side note to this as of right now the AI ships seem to be slighty more powerful than yours( which I hope they will fix in the future) Other wise than that the AI can provide you with some what of a challange compared to other stratagie games. The story mode is lore friendly and I suggest if you don't know much of the warhammer lore to go look it up( I would recommend valuts of terra and archwarhammer on youtube), otherwise than that you might get a tad bit confused about what some of the cutscenes are refering to. Solo skirmish is like multiplayer where instead of people you play the AI to unlock ships for both solo shirmish and custom battles. Then finally comes multiplayer which again can be challanging but fun. Other wise than that the ships look fantastic and represent what they would have looked like on the tabletop game and other wise than that I would recomend buying this game.

reviewText:
(Review as of the last day of beta)
Tindalos has delivered a marvelous gem to the gaming community. This is by far the most fun I've had playing a WH40k RTS game. I'm awful at explaining things, so heres a list of neutral facts, pros and cons.

Neutral:
-Game has a STEEP learning curve. You have to learn most of the game on your own. Prepare to lose horribly for your first 10 or so multiplayer matches.
-Singleplayer and Multiplayer have fleet progression, up to unlocking your first battleship at level 8 for beta.
-Your ships can be destroyed, and prevent you from using them in the next few games. This mechanic isn't so much a con in my point of view, just a mechanic to make the game less casual and more challenging
-You gain renown (spehss monies) from matches. You spend renown on upgrading your ships and getting new ones, however renown must be spent wisely or you could suffer greatly.
-The higher the level matches, the bigger the battles get.
-Your ships can (and will) disobey you mid combat, attempting to flee their doom. Without the proper upgrades, this can be a huge problem.
-Each race (Imps, Chaos, ORKZZZZZ, and Eldar) have their own playstyles, each with glaring advantages and disadvantages, enabling wild play style variations.
-There's a good amount of objective based game modes that you will participate in other than the usual kill everything".
-2v2 matches with friends are supposedly going to be in full version. Awesome
-Also a greyed out option for custom matches. Not sure what that is but may be awesome

Pros
-Although only 3 missions long for beta
date: the campaign shows much promise with a huge map
recommended: good cutscenes and solid dialogue (No SPEHSS MAHREEN speeches froml here)\n-The combat is INTENSE. I've had a lot of buttpuckering moments that made my heart pound.\n-Plethora of customisation options for your ships such as different weapons
hoursPlayed: abilities
voteText: upgrades and favours
helpfulPercent: offering a crapton of combinations available for each ship.\n-Speaking of which
votesHelpful: favours give your ships massive upgrades to stats
votesTotal: abilities and coolness factor.\n-Epic soundtrack
votesFunny:
albeit short. Hopefully longer in the full version.
-Each race is a lot of fun to play as. I've maxed an admiral for each race and still have a hard time figuring out which I prefer.
-Stealth is perfectly viable if you have the patience for it.
-Bot skirmishes for those who don't wanna play against players.
-The community is friendly and talkative
commentsCount: with butthurt at a low.\n-While not in beta
column16:
theres a greyed out option to paint your ships Dawn of War style.
-ORKZ ORKZ ORKZ ORKZ ORKZ
-Buying the game within the first two months of release gets you a SPEHSS MAHREENS fleet and a mystery fleet for free.

Cons

reviewText:
Ok lets start out with the simple question first.
Is this game a good Warhammer 40k game?
The answer is yes.
So now let me just say that for me at least everything has worked out fine with few to no bugs (mostly cosmetic) and only one hard crash during the beta and I am enjoying this game. Now I will say this is not a game that can compete with the Dawn of war series, but it does way better than any mobile games and any other games that has been released as of late in the warhammer 40k series. With that out of the way let me talk a little bit about the game. Now first this is a very strategic game and can get a bit complex if you are not prepared, but once you have gotten use to what you need to do the game gets pretty instresting. The four races that you will have are the Imperials, Chaos, Orks, and Eldar. Now single player (campaign/solo skirmish/custom battles) is ok. The AI is challanging in every mode except for easy and as a side note to this as of right now the AI ships seem to be slighty more powerful than yours( which I hope they will fix in the future) Other wise than that the AI can provide you with some what of a challange compared to other stratagie games. The story mode is lore friendly and I suggest if you don't know much of the warhammer lore to go look it up( I would recommend valuts of terra and archwarhammer on youtube), otherwise than that you might get a tad bit confused about what some of the cutscenes are refering to. Solo skirmish is like multiplayer where instead of people you play the AI to unlock ships for both solo shirmish and custom battles. Then finally comes multiplayer which again can be challanging but fun. Other wise than that the ships look fantastic and represent what they would have looked like on the tabletop game and other wise than that I would recomend buying this game.

reviewText:
I am updating my review as I go through campaign. The campaign is extremely repetitive in missions, with only a few custom maps here or there, and for the most part theyre boring.

The only thing driving the campaign is the dialogue in between turns, which I will admit is great dialogue. I just find myself more and more frustrated at the campaign because I may as well be playing solo skirmish.

What prompted this edit was the emergence of special enemy ships in my campaign game. I recieved a mission that had the Terminus Est, a 10,000 year old Chaos flagship that once housed Mortarion himself.

The game doesnt say this, I just happen to be a 40k geek. This is a big deal to a 40k fan to fight this ship and actually be able to kill it. There was almost no preamble to how serious this ship is other than it has claimed billions"

The mission it emerges in? DATA RECOVERY. I got the terminus est to 2 bars of hp and another chaos cruiser stole the data and warped out. Anticlimatic doesnt even begin to describe this epic battle I was having.

I still recommend the game but only just barely. Theyre still updating it and adding more fleets
date:
so I am yet hopeful for a better quality game. Right now it cycles through about 5 game type mini matches and tries to build the entire plot around those battles.

reviewText: A very solid and faithful adaptation of the classic boardgame. They have massively improved on balancing from the actual boardgame. Four different fleets currently, all of which play slightly differently, Imperials are slow, tanky ships that fight similar to a style from the 19th century. The Eldar are hit and run experts with deadly pulsars, torpedoes and mobility. Chaos is a little in between, with a mix of mobility, firepower and armour that does not really match either. Orks are slow, short ranged, heavy hitters with customizable ships. There are a number of game modes that keep it from being the same skirmish match again and again, data collection for instance is basically tag with battleships and boarding parties. The promise of future fleets also looks interesting, Space Marines are announced but potentially we could also expect more ships for Chaos and Imperials, a fleet for Dark Eldar, Tyranids, and Tau (two actually, the latter is by far the better one though).

reviewText:
Naval combat... in SPESS. (MUHRENS coming later)

It fits in the Real Time Tactical niche alongside older games like MechCommander or Blitzkrieg, where you control small numbers of units in tactical combat and progress them over the course of a campaign (including multiplayer). Instead of mechs or WW2, however, this is essentially space naval combat, with big line ships that trade broadsides.

Balance issues are to be expected in a game like this, so be careful about jumping straight into multiplayer. If the beta was any indication though, the devs are pretty good about balance patches to get things where they need to be.

That said, do expect a bit of a learning curve if you're new to this sort of game. Most strategies can be dealt with, and if you haven't learned how to deal with a particular type of enemy they can certainly seem overpowering. Ships control like... well, ships - expect them to move sluggishly, with a lot of intertia and that desperate HARD TO PORT!" feel as you  slowly try to bring your guns to bear. Starcraft APM need not apply here
date: though there is nevertheless quite a bit of micromanagement.\n\nIt's addictive (especially if you like progression mechanics) and it's fun
hoursPlayed: 000's colossal cathedral-boats annihilating each other with gigatons of exchanged firepower."

reviewText:
UPDATED

Score downgraded: 7/10 (from 8/10)

Edit: Single player is a good bit of fun. Each turn has a set number of deloyments (each fight counts as a deployment). Although prone to repititon, you are in a constant battle to keep the gothic sector from being overwhelmed by orks, eldars and chaos. The fights remain dynamic as the enemy upgrade their ships too and bring out heavier ordinance. Even on normal diffculty you'll find yourself coming down the wire often.

I've also been having crashes recently (after full release). In one situation, I lost an entire turns worth of progress since the game auto saves after each turn. Three nail biting battles gone down the drain, I have to redo that turn.
---------------

I haven't played the board game that this is based off but I'm guessing this is a lot more fun :D

Each race has its own set of unique looking ships starting from transports to destroyers, light cruisers, cruisers, battlecruisers and battleships (each class a set point value).  All of them pretty and intricately designed.

Depending on the kind of mission you load into (nope can't choose your missions in solo skirmish) i.e. cruiser clash, assassination, convoy escorts etc. you will be given a point cap. You will have to decide your fleet composition according to the opposing enemy race.

The battles are super fun, quick (lasting about 5 mins on average) and are visually stunning (pwetty explosions and sweet sound effects). You are expected to fight within a limited tile set or boundary (in real time) and use your races advantages to secure victory. Each race has its own specialty which allows for different play styles.

However, some mission types favour certain races, for example, one such mission type requires a ship to approach a randomly spawned marker on the map in order to bombard the planet below. The eldar have the upper hand in such missions are they are fast and agile and difficult to catch even after using your ships abilities to slow them down.

As you win battles you can upgrade each ship class within a limited number of slots available for upgrades (passive abilities) and special orders (active abilities). You may even adopt a favour by paying renown (in-game currency earned for both wins and losses) which attaches special abilities to individual ships. One such example is the inquisition favour for the imperial fleet which grants +1 crew points to all your crewmen (yup, you will have to upgrade your crew) as well as grant you the ability to reveal an enemy ship from infinite range (which would otherwise be hidden or masked as a blip).

Get the right combo going on for your fleet and you can turn those frustrating losses into wins.

The races are not so balanced in my opinion. The orks and imperials have the upper hand, i'm not very fond of the Chaos fleet, and they are average in every way. However, the eldar are super powerful (yet fragile) and are tough to catch, this can be hard to counter even with stasis bombs that slow ships.

The biggest selling point is the ship navigation. Depending on the race, your ship will have x number of prow mounted weapons (torpedos, lance cannons) and starboard & port mounted cannons. To get the most damage done, you'll have to line up your attacks in way that you would expose the most weapons at a single time towards the enemy (kind of like an old school ship battle). A combination of tactics can be used: lining up a perfect torpedo salvo (prow), a quick swing to the port side for a burst of macro gun fire followed by a frontal ship ram is extemely statisfying to pull-off when done right. You can even set up ambushes in gas clouds which will hide your ship from radar detection.

I'm not sure why you can't pair up with your friends in 2v2 games as opponents (private matches). I hope they implement that soon.

Other than that, expect more races, space marines are coming soon with the promise of another race (no idea which one yet, seems like necrons are getting the popular vote).

To summarise, get it, there is tons of replayablity. You'll feel like a proud father once you see your entire fleet put together, each with its own favour and colour scheme. Be prepared to get your ♥♥♥ handed in multiplayer. It ain't easy but it sure is fun.
voteText: 14 of 26 people (54%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
This game....Wow. If you love 40K and love space battles....then you will love this.

In Battlefleet Gothic: Armada, you take command of a fleet of one of 4 races. As you do battle, your commander levels up, unlocking more ships with different abilities and loadouts. Not only does your commander have levels, but each of your ships have levels as well. Which each level, you are able to select improvements to the ship, whether it be active abilities, passive increases, or more guns! Each ship has a loadout that can be directly affected by what you choose to improve. So not only is the strategy in the battlefield, but also in fleet composition as well.

Now onto the battles...This is where the game really shines. Before the battle starts, it has a Total War deployment phase. You place your ships how you want, select their firing options, optimal firing range, and start the match. When playing, the enemy ships aren’t shown, but their location is. So if you decide to head to a target and it ends up not being their flagship, you may have to watch your flank for them, because if you are caught out of position, you could be in trouble. Each of the races’ ships have different attributes and skills which changes your strategy depending on which race you are in battle with.

This is definitely a fun and challenging game!
voteText: 15 of 28 people (54%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
As a fan of not only the Warhammer 40K universe, the table top games (Armada included), as well as other Space Battles games....I am in love.

The game simply overflows with a working knowledge and more for the souce material.  The way ships move and fight is loud and bombastic with a flair for each faction being applied well.  Watching Imperial ships blast topedoes into thier enemies hulls as they close to fire with thier broadsides is simple awesome.

Note that the game plays on a flat space unlike something like Homeworld wich has a full 3d combat area.  However this works well in both representation of the table top game as well as for its own game mechanics.


The review is quite marred by previous loves of the genre and the source, though I do belive there is a lot to love here even without that background.

And dont forget, try to have a great day.

reviewText:
I haven't really dipped into Multi-player at all so this is a review exclusively of the single player campaign.

Summary:

Blowing up spaceships feels weighty and is addictive and fun. I've probably not been this hooked on an RTS since Command and Conquer, I love the fact that a campaign fits into bite sized scenarios of 5 minutes a piece. This fits much better with my schedule these days, yet you can still binge on a bunch of missions in quick succession.

I've made it to chapter two so far, in about 30 hours of play time. I suspect I've still got quite a lot more to see but even if what I've discovered is the entire depth of the game I feel like it was value for money.

Overview

The structure of the single player campaign is pretty simple, you get a map showing several different systems. You start off with a couple but quickly ramp up to 5 or 6 in chapter 2.

Each system has a number of planets you must defend and these planets are attacked at random by the various forces arrayed against you; Eldar, Orks, and Chaos.

You have to take randomly generated missions to reduce the threat, with most mission types being playable from the point of view of the attacker and defender.  A few examples of such missions are: a straight forwards fight to the death, stealing info by boarding a capital ship, assassinating an admiral,  running a blockade, and laying siege to a planet.
Failing a mission generally increases the difficulty and whilst you have the short term effect of the loss of the world you were defending it also increases the likelihood of that particular foe stepping up their attacks.

Also n any given turn you also might have a story mission. Failing these have long-term effects beyond just making the game harder, so far artefacts I've rescued have proven valuable, although how valuable would be a spoiler :-)

What I didn't like:

I'd have liked the option to play as different races in the campaign, even if it was just a generic campaign without the story missions.

What I think needs improvement:

It would be nice within the vanilla mission types if you could get a twist occasionally that changed the objectives. It'd keep this from getting too same-y.

Explosions sometimes look a bit disappointing.

Short range warp jumps can't position the ships on exit and seem pretty short distance.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
So far this game has me 4/5 interested and 1/5 frustrated.

I absolutely love the RTS space-combat mechanics. It gives you a very wide ability to go OCD or let the AI take command of your fleet while you focus on your flagship. The combat is very engaging and heavy in strategy, forcing you to always look at the big picture, and you cannot allow yourself to ignore even the smaller ships.

Another great feature is how widely a battle can swing with a well placed hit or an inopportune time for one of your ships to mutiny, forcing you to immediately deal with that ship else have it flee from battle. The ability to focus-fire on core targets such as weapons and engines is also a key feature that I do enjoy. Plus on the other end of the spectrum the customization of your fleet and individual ships appears very appealing.

Importantly, from what little I have seen of the campaign, it seems to have a good story being built around it and seems to have a rather open-end style of growth where actions can change later outcomes, rather than a linear on the rail" method of storytelling.

The downsides of the game is some of the matches that it has to offer
date: namely the defense matches. I find that the objects I have to defend never survive the battle as the AI is entirely reckless in its attempt to kill the objective
recommended: and the platforms/convoy ships have hopeless amounts of armor/HP. I find that when I play the matchups
hoursPlayed: its almost easier to just let them win so I can try a different match. This fault may ultimately be a fault in my gameplay style
voteText: but it also may be the fault in the game itself
helpfulPercent: that is for the player to decide.\n\nOverall
votesHelpful: its a very solid space-based strategy game compared to most that is presently on the market. The only other ding I could give it is that its visuals seem a bit last-gen for the price tag
votesTotal: but I can live with it."

reviewText: Its fun to play, really fun. Campaign is fun. Multiplayer is great and plays like a rts with the matchmaking speed akin to those familiar with games such as modern warefare. Matches are generally quick lasting from anywhere from 5 minutes to the few drawn out ones that last nearly 20 minutes. Progression rate feels like it is in a good place. Customization is fun and meaningful and i would like to see it expanded upon.  Has a lot of bugs though from my experience which include random disconnects, camera bugs out often followed by a fatal crash,  campaign buging and becoming stuck with the button that you have to press in order to advance becoming unpressable, Also, there are severe balance issues that need to be addressed.
