reviewText:
Very fun skirmish mode. You create a fleet, and your ships gain experience with each game you play. The missions are short, and have a twenty minute timer. Although most missions are usually over in ten minutes. There are also several types of missions including: a death match, capture the data, convoy escort, and a 'break through' where one side is trying to escape after destorying space stations.

The graphics are superb. The UI could use a little bit of work, but this game is solid.
8/10.

reviewText:
Yes. But with caveats. Disclaimer: I've not played the game all the way through the campaign, but I have put about 30 hours into to so far with about 10 of those being on the release.

It all seems to be a very thorough adaptation of the original game. The graphics are incredibly detailed and everything is accurately reproduced from GW's original art and descriptions. I can't say that I find fault in any of the features, ships, or races. I want to like this game.

But there are problems as I see them, the game as a whole very much needs help with in-combat micro-management.

1: There is no ability to set formations. If I setup a group of ships in a line formation - - - -  then they will eventually all shift to abreast as they move | | | | . If I set them up in a line formation they damn well better stay in formation or I'm shooting a captain that breaks rank. It doesn't matter if I set 6 ships 2 abreast in a line or what. They should maintain it unless I say otherwise.

2: There is no ability to set 'wingmen'. I should be able to link two or more ships together that have standing orders to not drift more than, say 3000 units from one another. This is important because ships left to their own devices tend to wander off on their own, and it requires constant attention from the player to monitor and give new orders. I should be able to say to one ship, 'this ship in your lead....follow him and attack his targets always.

3: Both A and B are important because while you can set priority targets the option for doing that is extremely cumbersome, and the player only has the ability to prioritize 4 targets at any given time, and you can only do it by clicking on each target one at a time. There is no 'panel' window that allows you to set them all on one pane. You can also only prioritize targets you've identified. This is kind of STUPID because if you have missions where you have to assassinate a flag ship or transports, or capture data, then the flag ship and/or the transports/data should >always< automatically be #1 and they aren't. This leads me to complain about the fact that all transports should be considered equal priority, and that would be #1 starting with the closest.

4: Ships, by default, probably should never full stop on their own. This isn't to much of an issue if you're telling a ship to use it's port/starboard weapons primarily, because they will always just circle each other then, but if you tell a ship to focus on prow weapons they just come to a dead stop once they get in range. This, particularly, is a problem when playing Eldar, whose only defence is speed. Once an Eldar ship gets within range, and it's set to focus on it's prow weapons, it will just become a sitting duck and die. Bad Eldar.

5: I should be able to chain movement orders. This isn't an issue (much) in combat, but if I want to pilot a transport around a minefield or asteroids, I shouldn't constantly have to go back every so often and issue new orders.

reviewText:
I love it more than I thought I would (I am still playing Campaign only)

I am not big fan of WH 40k, but played several related games. I enjoyed DOW 2, so after I watched some peoples' Beta play, I thought, well, I should like it, since it has similar core concept. For example, each game we have small killing team (ships or space marines) under control.

However, it really worked out better than I thought. I am still a newbie, still learning, but I have already relised it is more than what I thought. I am playing campaign at the moment. It takes time to get how to deal with different enemys and situations. I got kicked very hard when i started but I am better now. It surpises me how changing the fleet formation can dramatically alters the results. I guess it is right, since in navy warfare, formation plays critical role. As I said, I am still learning, but so far i really enjoyed the game, even though I am still kicked from time to time.

reviewText: I don’t think I’ll forget how playing through Battlefleet Gothic: Armada’s campaign felt. That’s not to say the multiplayer is negligible; far from it as, for many people, it’s where the real value of the game lies. It’s just that from the way the ships look, to the voice acting, sound design and cutscenes, everything is exactly how a Warhammer 40k title should be. The people over at Tindalos Interactive have done their homework, thus providing an excellent Warhammer 40k experience and the first proper 40k game we’ve had in quite a while. Furthermore, they’ve promised continued support, especially in regards to balance, which is the biggest gripe I have with the game at the moment. Knowing that a Space Marine fleet DLC is on the way and keeping in mind a particular detail from the campaign cutscenes, I’m already getting excited at potentially getting to play more races and at the thought of a possible expansion somewhere down the line. This being said, it’s pretty clear that, while there are some things that need fixing, Battlefleet Gothic: Armada is a game you don’t want to miss out on. As for me, I’m going back and painting those transport ships red in hopes of getting them to go faster. Full Review[noobfeed.com].

reviewText:
This is just the first iteration of my review.
I have played the first handful of missions from the campaign and some battles in multiplayer.
I liked the campaign very much. Everything works and the story is interesting and reflect the setting of Warhammer 40,000 very well.
My multiplayer experience was not as well as that of the campaign. There are two reasons for that. The first is that the party system of the multiplayer has some bugs. If you change your general and/or your faction, you cannot rejoin with your former member of your party. The only thing that helps is to restart the game.
Also you cannot choose which kind of mission you want to play in multiplayer. It is chosen randomly. Most of the time is Cruiser Clash.
The last thing is balancing. I am not experienced enough to judge how balanced the different factions are. But I can judge that I am playing against players that have a lot more experience than me and therefore are able to destroy me and my teammate hard. I guess this results from a bad matchmaking system in combination with the fact that there was a multiplayer beta in which a lot of people could already train their skills in this game. I guess this problem will become more irrelevant if I play the game more, but it should not happen anyway.
Graphics, sound and gameplay are good to very good. The setting is a matter of taste. If you like Warhammer 40,000 or dark/gothic science fiction you will like it.
All in all I review this game as positive, but it has some flaws, too.

reviewText:
I've been a huge fan of the Warhamer 40k universe since it was introduced to me by my friends who played the tabletop game back in middleschool. Ever since then I've been collecting my own tabletop army (Space Wolves-For RUSS AND THE ALLFATHER) as well as reading numerous novels. I've also played both Dawn of War games and felt they superbly captured the feel of ground combat in the universe. Before this game I've been dreaming of what it would be like to take command of the massive fleets of the 40k univererse after reading such awe-inspiring descriptions of them in the novels I have read. This game is like a fantasy come true.

I'd reccomend this game to anyone who is a fan of the W40k universe or a fan of Battleship/Combat/RTS Sims". reviewText:
Like blowing up ships? Yes? Then why dont you have this? Get this.

Ok, real review time.

Issues this game has; Lack of Co-op, Simplistic AI, Multiplayer is iffy, and unintuitive.

The lack of co-op is a big hinderance on this otherwise solid game. Custome game lobbys exist where you can play vs AI, but without being able to add friends, its a rather limited feature.

The AI is quite simplistic. They use their ships skills, take into account range and some basic tactics, but ultimately they just run at you. Due to that, you can easily cheese the AI and find an win.

Multiplayer is where the game seems to be aimed at for its lifespan. However, any sort of matchmaking system they use is rather unreliable. You dont know if you will get a first time player, or a person whos broken their fleet down to a science. That aside, there are a lot of reports of lag.

The game is overall unintiutive. You have to learn how to play the game, how to use the UI and just what all the little things on your ships do. Because of how the games combat system works, you dont really know a lot of whats happening. Is the next volly going to do damage? How much will it do to this target? When is its next volly? Those are all questions that are manditory, but the games system make damage a chance and you need to keep track of attacks mentally to know when the next attack will hit.

But to get more in depth about that, I'll need to get into the positives of this game. So, here they are.

High learning curve, quick games, satisfying campaign and a good representation of Warhammer.

The high learnin curve is one of the main aspects thats good, but also bad. Going into the game from a non-Warhammer 40k fanboy, theres lots of weapons ships and names of skills and effects that will need to be learned. This can be daunting at times. However this same depth also ensures that the better you know the game, the better you will be able to perform.

Matches typically last between the 5-10 min mark making its widly available. Get home from work/school, play a game or two, then get on with your life. Or you can sink in hours at a time and fully enjoy quickly learning the ins and outs of various ships and fleets.

The campaign is satisfying. Wont go into details about it for spoilers, but it clearly wasnt a patched together story.

It is the 40k universe (not really, but essentially is) and you do feel it. From the races to the Factions" that you can have your ships represent
date: you can clearly see the the iconic visuals of the 40k universe. Names and skills are also very 40k
recommended: like the auto naming of your ships (that can be changed) that give them a very uniquely sounding 40k name.\n\nOverall
hoursPlayed: this is a solid 7/10. If/when co-op is added this will easily be an 8/10."

reviewText:
Battlefleet Gothic: Armada's a great Warhammer game, but not that much of a great Space RTS. Its very micro-managment and stat based, and manages to keep the feel of the tabletop game despite it being played with a mouse and keyboard. Battles are small, and usually have between 2 and 5 ships a side in a game but this actually works given the micromanagability of it; any more ships and doing the manouvres the game expects you to use would be impossible.

Space RTS wise though its not great. As I said before, battles are small. Really small, to the point your ships take up a few dots on an otherwise mostly empty map. Battles are engaging, but the combat looks visually samey. A shot form one ship will impact another ship the same way no matter where it came from. Then there's the micro management which I enjoy, but can make the game feel too complicated for a PC game. This is a game where micro management is a must (Even in the campaign), unlike other games where its an option to be used to get an upper hand on your opponent. Because of this you will lose most of your early battles, and you will rage quit far more than you'll be proud of.

Should you buy this game? Only if you enjoy stat based games with a space skin. If your looking for a fun RTS buy a game like Warhammer: Dawn of War instead since you'll enjoy it far more.

reviewText:
Great game!
I havent seen such a quality and dedication for a very long time.
The music is perfectly fitting and attends the situation perfectly.
The cinematics. There are 2 moments that look a bit off, but the rest of them is a masterpiece. Espectially the exterminatus scene. As good as DoW 2 Exterminatus video. The voicing, the small details, its all awesome and well-made.
The development of the story and the gnawing sensation of the loosing war and a desperate necessity to save as much people as you can, beating away the Heretical army and alien pirates who keep screwing things up. Chaos plots, Traitors, Ork Looterz and Eldar corsairs. And Spehhs Mrheens are also present.
Preventing planets from exterminatus is a great option too. All game modes are great and fun to play. Exept Data recovery, but thats because im horrible at it.

Its a very good Warhammer 40.00 game, bonus for those who enjoy space battles.

reviewText:
Ill make this short and sweet: I love this game and it can be pretty addicting. But to help with figuring out if you'd buy it or not, ill just do a giant pro/con/neutral point list and a quick conclusion.

Pros:
-Unreal 4 engine
-Warhammer 40k setting
-Decent balancing between the races
-Highly customizable fleets (esspecially with orks.)
-Beautiful epic chior music
-Very satisfying battle sounds and fantastic voice acting
-Good option menus
-hotkeys for abilities
-Clear objectives on each gamemode
-AI is compitent enough to enjoy the game (can cheat in certain gamemodes, see cons)
-Can create your own games that will not punish your fleet in order to test strategies with randomly generated fleets or your fleets from skirmish or multiplayer mode.
-Campagin is very well constructed and present a lot of choices
-Option for Ironman mode" for campagin which prevents saving for hardcore crowd
-Easy to find a game in multiplayer
-2v2 co-op in multiplayer
-Tactical cogitators that put the game in slow motion and allow planning and strategy in order to keep up with the action
-Dev team plans to add more content and new races (space marines will be dlc in 1 1/2 months and then another race that hasn't been announced is planned sometime after)

Cons:
-Certain races need particular ship upgrades and weapons to defeat other races (Ex: Chaos will kite your ships with long range weapons while they move at fast speeds which make them difficult to catch if you do not have nova cannons

reviewText:
Just completed the Campaign and have spent 60 hours in the beta doing Skirmish and Muti so i thought it be a good time to give a review.

Firstly the graphics look fantastic and the game runs very well on my rather average PC. All the ships look just how they do in table top. The imperial ships look so beautiful with all the tall spires and cathedrals. The map designs look gorgeous with planets, suns, asteroid fields, ice crystals and my fav being the blackhole map that reminds me so much of the movie intersellar. I've experienced 2 crashes in my 85 hours of playthrough and both instances happened during the beta so im happy that they have dealt with the little problem.

Secondly the campaign is brilliant. I think the voice actors done a very good job and speak in the way you expect people in the 40k universe to speak. The campaign was long and took me just over 40 turns to do but every turn had some form of speech by someone of some incident happening or some big bad coming into the system. The cinematics are truely awesome and really keep close to the lore. i really love the art design and music with chapter 2 entering the warp" scene where the crew are praying being a masterpiece.

I did the campaign on normal and i can say its just about the right difficulty (For someone like me that likes hard games) any higher and i could see myself throwing the mouse or keyboard at the wall mainly due to how random the campaign can be. The problem being is that every time you replay and load the same mission your enemy will have a completely different set up and be in completely different location on a completely different map (asteroids
date: mines and gas being in different locations). This can pretty much make you win or lose automaticly depending on the mission and it can be incredibly annoying when everything is stacked against you because of the RNG. All you can do is restart and load the mission up. This really is the only bad thing i can say about the game. Hell
recommended:
i even lost the first mission because the first shot the defence platform did after the shields went down critical hitted me and took my generator offline and then took double the time to warp out as abaddons 100 ships slapped me down hard.

Thirdly the balance of skirmish and multi is completely fine. For those of you who were not in the beta you have no idea how bad it was back then. You had Eldar Holofields that worked even better then they do now.  You had insanely OP Assault boats that at the time made Chaos the go to race. You had insanely OP Taunt that was auto win when playing Orks. You had Nova Cannon that didn't even show up on the map and fired alot faster. There was alot of things that have been sorted out and balanced and right now things are pretty much good. Some work probably has to be done on Eldar but for everyone else it is near enough perfect. Literally all it comes down to is "Git Gud" for the most part.

The Micro in the game is perfect balance of not requiring to be a korean SC2 God and good enough that the game isn't a "a" and left click game. You can choose all the options that you want the computer to do for you by right clicking on all the skills you don't want to personally control yourself. Boarding and lightning strikes is usually a good one to do for new players. Ships are very slow even as Eldar so i can say that game is rather slow paced and not that many ships you have plenty of time to do all your skills and planning. If the game is still to micro intense for you? Just press space bar and it slows the game right down for everyone. There is literally no way i can see people complain about micro in this game. The only theory i have is that they are LOL kiddies that are so use to playing just 1 character with 4 abilities that when they come to a game where you have control 3-4 "characters" they instantly get anal prolapse.

8.5/10 - Campaign battle balance rather off as its pure RNG. Alliance battles and data collecting are awful. If you get Both in the same battle.. Pray to the Emperor. Tiny bit of race balancing needs work. Other then that a brilliant game. A must buy if you love the 40k universe. You won't be dissapointed. Can't wait for the space marine DLC."

reviewText:
I haven't played the campaign at all, I play online only. So I am only reviewing that..
I will get to the bad stuff first At the moment the Eldar are really OP, so if you are playing any other faction you should probably surrender every time you face them so you can save your ships. Seriously they have weapons that can kill any ship in 2-3 hits. But I expect that will all get fixed soon and the game will be much better for it. There are a few other bugs, but they are constatnly fixing them. However, other bugs seem to pop up as they fix old ones. But they do seem to be less bad each time. The other thing that gets a bit boring is the lack of factions to choose from. With eldar being so crazily OP, there are only really 3 fun factions and not 4. It isn't even fun to play as Eldar, waaaaay to easy unless you against other Eldar.

Now on to the good stuff. The ship customisation is pretty fun. You don't get completely free control over your ship customisation like it says in the description, but it is good enough. The graphics are awesome but I have to run low otherwise my FPS drops, but thats just my setup. The audio and music is awesome, really atmospheric and very nihilistic. Some people say there isn't much strategy in this game, or that it is confusing. I think they couldn't be more wrong. There is a lot of skill to be learned in this game, making it fun and very replayable. Overall I would recommend this game, but not to anyone that doesn't like strategy games. If you don't learn from your mistakes you will keep losing your ships and it will get very annoying. (But you never lose ur ships for good.) :D

reviewText:
Most negative reviews seem to focus on the multiplayer aspect of the game. I've played only the single player portion of the game to date, so I will only comment on that.

In short, the single player campaign is fun as hell!

I've yet to finish the single player campaign and I'm almost 30 hours. Maybe I'm slow, but who cares, the story is pure WH40K goodness and almost every mission in the single player campaign has left me cheering at the end when I win. Plus the defeats hurt deeply, which just makes the wins that much better.

Even watching some let's play videos on youtube have gotten me excited at the close wins. It really does leave you with a rush and feeling good. What more is there to say. If you want the multiplayer side of it only, well I can't say if it's any good. But the single player game? It's all good. My only complaint is that it's going to end.

Well done.

reviewText: I've been looking forward to this game for awhile. I haven't played a good space RTS since the first two Homeworld games and I do enjoy the 40k mythos. While this game doesn't play out like Homeworld it is fun and exactly what I wanted it to be. The graphics are great and the ship design is top notch. Controlling your fleet is pretty simple with enough nuances based on your play style and use of the special manuevers for ship placement. The ships themselves feel like heavy starships slogging it out like battleships of old. I can't wait to see the Space Marine Fleet.

reviewText:
Single player campaign short review only:

I dont care about the multiplayer aspect in games and thus this is campaign review only. I would not recommend the game for its singleplayer campaign alone due to reasons I am about to explain, however I can under no circumstances give this game a thumbs down due to my own gameplay limitations.

The Warhammer 40K vibe is definately present in the game as far as the story goes and it is presented well, however it is the gameplay that detracts from my enjoyment of the campaign.

This is a space game and you get a limited amount of vessels within each category to customise with certain skillsets. These skillsets are bought with honor points your earn throughout the missions on the campaign, however these skillsets quickly narrow down the strategical options due to specialisation, be it brawling by using ramming or long ranged weaponry. You dont build bases, you dont get reinforcements in battles and you are stuck with a limited number of vessels which you better know how to handle, the campaign story missions can be very unforgiving and thus the specialisation needs, you really need to know your fleets capabilities. Its extremely easy to fall into a certain rotation if it works, improvisation is better left for the easier missions.

Be it defensively or in offense I find myself doing the same over and over with a limited number of ships. This could be due to self imposed restrictions based on my personal skill level. If you buy the game for the campaign alone I would only recommend it at a cheaper price.

Multiplayer offers many more choices and human opponents, it most likely offers a very different game experience, for that I would recommend the other reviews on the game or youtube.

reviewText: Single Player - This part of the game has been extremely enjoyable for me. In many ways it reminds me of XCOM where it creates difficult situations in which you cant save every planet. Not to mention the Iron Mode" setting making any ships you lose unable to be repaired. This really creates what feels like an intense multi-front war for survival. Complaints about high difficulty even on low difficulty settings are largely exaggerated. I suspect many people aren't taking advantage of various mechanics (not to mention the fact that you can save and retry as many times as you like).\n\nMicro Management - I was somewhat concerned about this
date: as there are so many abilities across your fleet. I have yet to run into any real intense micro management due to the games "Tactical Cogitator" mechanic that allows you to slow the game down to very near a stand still
recommended: allowing you to aim skill shots and target abilities with ease. This in combination with auto-cast functionality on pretty much every skill (things like silent running and "Micro-warp Jump" aka blink don't seem to auto cast)
hoursPlayed: an auto target option so your ship will always attack something even if not commanded to
voteText: and various other behavioral settings

reviewText: I got this game during the beta phase and I was happy to pay for it. This game is worth the money on it's multiplayer experience alone. The strategy's required to win consistently are varied and often complex. The upgrade system adds depth to your fleet choices and allows for wildly divergent strategies using the same race. The combat is satisfyingly visceral. There is nothing better than ramming an enemy just before they warp out.\n\nThe campaign is compelling and mixes single-player only game modes into the pre-existing multiplayer modes. It has a feel similar to the Dawn of War 2 campaign map with some of the better aspects of the later expansions for Dawn of War 1 added in. The voice acting is good and the animation style is perfectly 40k.

reviewText:
Review in brief

+ Great gameplay

+ Just one more turn mentality

+Good balance of ships

The only thing i would say is that i wish this game was married with some ground combat, like Star Wars: Empire at War that game would be incredible.

This game as it stands is still well worth it 8/10.

reviewText:
I really like the game, mainly playing for Chaos and Eldar fleets, graphics really good if you turn anti-aliasing off, not sure, if they fixed that yet, maybe they already did. They were some issues in the beta in multiplayer balance, but overall the launch was good compared even to some established game developers and publishers. Mechanically it is really well thought out and the customization keeps me like in XCOM getting attached to the ships. The favors are awesome in their aesthetic and traits.

I havent played the campaign yet to the end, but seems to be good and with a formidable AI. As a grand strategy fan I would have wished for more strategic play, but I understand the standards of RTS. The fleets are very different and you have to learn how to use them. That is something very remarkable for the current market of RTSes, where in multiplayer even when there are different races and units, they are mechanically similar. It is not as much variable as Starcraft, but nevertheless. In the department of art and design and gameplay, this game really shines. The opinion on customisation and RPG elements is a subjective one, I think it is a good idea to implement it in an RTS, Im okay with it, I liked it in King Arthur and like it now, I dont mind that it is like a battle between wizards. Subjectively, I enjoy the gameplay very much and even more the owning and tailoring of my ships.

To some valid criticism:
The main thing is balance, matchmaking, speed and grind. I dont know how matchmaking improved since the beta, but in the beta, it was pretty painful and degraded an otherwise awesome experience. It is also valid to point out that there is a lot of micro-management in the more chaotic battles and the grind for skirmish and multiplayer is a little bit too time-consuming. I would reduce the time to get to the full admiral in skirmish and multiplayer and give players more tactical cogitator debit in multiplayer. And the upgrades are a little bit unbalanced. In the crew department, the navigator could have a turning bonus and the boarding mechanic is I think overpowered, so that I always pick upgrading the troop level. I always go for the disruption bomb and the recon skills are pretty unattractive. I personally think, the stasis bomb is useless unless you are fighting against a dumb enemy or the Orks and the only use of it is in catching some coward in breakthrough, data retrieval and assassination, who you cant overrun because of the different speeds of the fleets. After they nerfed the nova cannon, it became also useless.

Overall, it is a very enjoyable game and a dream come true for even people, like me, who are not familiar with 40K, but who are fans of steampunk, this is pornography for this genre and for fans of space and naval RTS.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
BLUF: Buy it.  It is a good purchase, on sale / discount; it is an ok purchase at full price $39.99 (23APR16).

There are some very large flaws that make this a great buy or even a great game.  Graphics are fairly good, a little bland; there is some graphical card tearing/skipping on some of the non-scripted cutscenes and I hope they are working on them.  The size of the small vs med ships so far is not impressive; but I am only a few missions in and there are a few more classes to see, so that might change.
Voiceacting, terrible!  Local highschool plays and SciFy movies are done better; way to over the top and evertime you change from tactical to non-tactical mode during the game play, it screams at you.  First time ok, but twenty times in a single game, no go.
My biggest complaint is not game related, it is the map mode (not durring game play) where you select the next mission, selection of a mission, or going to the upgrade screen.  Each section feels like they are different modules or programs.  The game stops goes to a loading screen with the loading bar concept and you have to wait.  It is not fluid and makes the game feel as if different teams (which I am sure did) developed it and then at the end they tried to put them together.  It is hard to describe...

I am a 40k fan as I am sure more buyers will be and I feel that you will like this game, but not love it becuase of the bad voice and bland graphics.  However you, like me will forgive it and move on.  Hopefully with more patches the devs will resolve some of the issues.

Lost in the warp or something???? Hmmm. You know, the one promised in the advertising.(That Navigator is gonna get shot) Other than that bit of cheek I rate this 10-10. I have had a couple crashes, nothng game breaking. The autosave faeture is solid. The sounds of Battle top notch. Ram the enemy & listen to the sreech of metal on metal. I love the sound of Macro cannons in the mornig,,, Sounds like,,,, Victory.The voice acting is excellent during the cut scenes. Custom games are a sweet addition & I love the multiplayer. This is a well polished game. Now,,, Wheres my damn Space Marine fleet ?????? FULL AHEAD !!!  FOR THE EMPOROR !!!

Game is out and I can finally review this.

I was in the beta for this for a while and streamed a bit of it at twitch.tv/travis440.  Can possibly see it in some past broadcast.

Game is fun and has a great story line.  Three factions currently with a fourth one coming out.

Like in good ol Warhammer fashion, it's just pure badassery!

Pros:
Amazing Graphics
Great designs
Different Tactic options
Ship level up system (sort of)
Warhammer!


Cons:
May be difficult to get into
Don't think it'll run too great on lower end comps

reviewText: Awesome game! A real-time strategy game with surprisingly tense space battles. reviewText:
A fanboys dream of 40k.

++Basically like the table top but in real time, so if you are familiar with the table top this should feel like home.
+Great customizations of ships, perfect for making a fleet for any/all situations.
+strategy galore, there is always hope in the light of the Emperor! Battles can turn around in fantastic ways in your favor with quick thinking and knowledge of your ships.

-Can be an incredibally hard game, but this could be a positive on some notes. (Personally I find it like a Fire Emblem/Xcom love/hate difficulty)

BONUS ++
ALREADY ADDING MORE FLEETS!!!!

reviewText:
Ive been playing since the Beta adding of the Orcs have played IMP and Chaos, there is a bit of a learning curve here as there was no real explanation of game mechanics in the tutorial, that said i watched a fiew videos got some tips then smashed the pvp. doing so i played against some experienced playes evolved my tactics and won a good 60-70% of my battles.

I have read allot of complaints about mission dificulty in the campaign this is merely atributed to a lack of in game mechanics and simple tactis. This game has been beautifully rendered by the devs, its still got some work to do but as far as RTS gies this is a really great title another 40K hit, i reccomend it to anyone who enjoys space battle, navy battle and game requiering thought and tactics to win. For people new to the game go watch some vids on battles you will quickly learn that you can use the games ai to assist with your play while you focus on movement and positioning.
Then hit pvp for some good tactical experience and learning.

reviewText:
Wow. I'm glad to say that the tone of the game is very true to the dark 40k universe, and in particular the well documented struggle in the Gothic Sector. The portaits, voices and attitudes of the characters are some of the best I've seen for a 40k game.

The single player campaign appears well balanced, missions are hard and mistakes are punished. Upgrading and deploying ships is a joy, which adds an RPG element to the game. You'll find yourself caring about ships under your command in the interesting and varied battles. Ships can be customised for particular roles as well.

Combat itself is a lot of fun. After the first few struggles you'll begin to get the hang of handling the fleet. Having a genuine tactic appears to pay off, which is nice. Some missions may seem impossible until you hit on the correct tactic.

Graphically the game is beautiful. You don't quite get the sense that the ships are as big as they are however. Probably because you'll be zoomed out a wee bit most of the time.

If you like strategy games or 40k, this is a must.

reviewText: I would like to start off by saying that this is a great game and should be deeply considerd, not just cast away like Fenris. This game, in my opinion, should have spent a little more time in development, Example of why: In one of the very first trailers, it states that you can warp out, repair the ship, then warp back in to continue fighting, this ability has yet to be shown. It still has bugs, but are getting sorted out as the go along, and the only down side as an early adopter, still no space marine fleet, which they worded incorrectly, (like GW itself does occasionaly,) implying it would be a few weeks, (By definition 2 or 3 weeks) but it has been one month and 2 weeks (This was posted on june 3rd). It also implied that the early adopter would recieve it before the non early adopters. P.S., if any staff read this, please reccomend the space wolves as a favor for the space marines, as they have the largest known fleet of all space marines chapters, please do not act like Matt Ward with Ultramarines and make them overpowerd if you make them a favor (PLEASE DON'T USE THEM, they dont really like many ships or big ships any ways).

reviewText:
I've been part of the Beta since day one, and have been playing the campaign since it was released. I must say I'm very, very pleased about what I've bough, and I highly recommend it not only to every fan of Warhammer 40,000, but to anyone who likes tactical RTS games, naval games, spaceship games, and sci-fi in general. Let me list the reasons.

- A great port of the tabletop game to the RTS genre. It is highly based on the rules of the original game, namely ship positioning, fire arcs, manouvering, space hazards, special orders... while at the same time adding new functionalities.

- A beautiful depiction of the inmensely rich Warhammer 40,000 universe. Attention to detail is everywhere: descriptions, UI, voice quotes... It represents the setting as no game has done since the original Dawn of War, about 10 years ago.

- Graphics and sound are just impressive. You will see shields rippling from impacts, chunks flying off hulls, destroyed parts of the ships' hulls (which also means losing equipment on the ships: yes, you can target specific ship systems), gorgeous space landscapes, boarding parties boring into ships...

- Gameplay is deep and can be quite competitive. Make no mistake: this is a Tactical RTS game, which means lots of micromanagement, and where each ships' position and orientation is key, not to mention the abilities. It takes some time to learn, but it's quite intuitive once you do. Also, by pressing spacebar, you can slow down the game's pace to a crawl, which can help you to react to very complex situations if you need it. This feature is also available in Multiplayer, although with a time restriction to avoid trolling.

- The single-player campaign is lengthy and rich as well. You will have to defend a whole sector (star cluster) against several enemies: the Chaos forces, local rebellions, and Ork and Eldar pirate attacks. You decisions will matter. Those players who prefer playing campaigns over MP will enjoy it a lot.

- Both in SP and MP you will be the admiral of a fleet. There is a progression system: you start as a lowly new admiral, but as you earn renown, you will get more ships and upgrades for your ships. You won't lose ships permanently (unless in super-hard mode in the campaign), but destroyed ships will not be available for 2 games unless spending points on priority repairs. Personally I like this mechanic, as it forces you to think like an admiral. Is it worth losing your entire fleet if the enemy overwhelms you? No! Better warp out: you will earn points by losing as well. This also means you should carefully select your upgrades, and which ships to bring to each battle depending on the objectives. It encourages tactical thinking, and I appreciate that.

- The support the developers (and even the publishers!) have given to their game during the Beta stage (and before that)  has been enormous. They have worked really hard to make the game as good as possible for release. They've listened to the players' issues, both technical and of gameplay, and have updated the game many times before release. Such dedication to their playerbase and the game they've created is much respectable, and something sadly unusual these days. Rest assured that their support will continue: in their own words, release is not the end
date: but the beginning". They will be adding more races and factions from the W40k universe via DLCs
recommended: and I'd say they also want to add more campagins.\n\n- To continue the previous point

Oh and by the way...\n\n- ... that 6th faction was not originally devised to be free too. It was once the devs/publishers realised they couldn't meet the original release date (March 23rd) without releasing a half-baked game. So they swallowed up and postponed release a month later

votesHelpful: only a few.\n\nSo that's it for my review
votesTotal: for now. Again I say: I highly recommend this game.\n\nNOTE: make sure you buy the game either on Steam or at the official webpage. reviewText:
Finally a game that does justice to the 40k universe, and is just a good game in its own right. I've put over 70hrs in since the beta launch and am really enjoying the SP campaign now release is upon us.

If you like RTS games, and like 40k, you'll love this. It's a great balance of micro and macro management, and tactics are key, not APM or any of that elite RTS stuff (although you do have to be quick to handle the Eldar faction).

Buy with confidence

reviewText:
Why isn't this a multiplayer game, with the ability to choose w/e race you want? This game and its storyline has the potential to do what eve online failed to do. I want to play this as an MMO and have a living universe that can fluxuate territory and manage worlds that isnt a pain in the ♥♥♥ to recover from a loss. The UI would have to be revamped, but with the unwritten future storyline, the devs could be active players, the faction leaders driving the storyline in an mmo.

As a single player game its amazing too, i just think it would be a shame to limit the potential of this game to a single player storyline.

Thank you for a great space game, this is only the second one i would recommend out of the 100s i've blow looking for some fun in space from the comfort of my couch :)

reviewText:
Great game for all 40k fans and for fans of tactical space combat. That said its not like Homeworld, but more like Nexus: The Jupiter Incident. No base building, just managing your fleet mission to mission.

graphics: Game is very pretty and ship models are very well done.

Gameplay: While there is a learning curve, anyone can get the hang of it with enough practice. I have found that the auto use feature is a must for skills. Helps out hugely on the mirco so you just have to worry about torpedoes and nova cannons. There is a decent amount of grinding in order to lvl up your admiral and ships, but battles are pretty fast, so you can get to battleships pretty quickly. For now, we can only use 4-6 ships per battle, so we don't get overwhelmed trying to control so many ships and all their abilities and skills.

Campaign: If you played Dawn of War 2 and enjoyed it, you will enjoy this. Similar mission structure with a limited amoutn of deployment per turn, making us choose what benefits we want to keep. I have yet to finish the campaign, but I have been enjoying it immensely.

Skirmish: Here we get to try out all 4 fleets (for now) against the AI. AI is decent to play againts and will provide a decent enough challange on normal.

Multiplayer: Can't say anything here, I generally don't play online.

Overall its a fun game. Some features are still missing, but the devs have been putting out huge patches every single week since the beta started fixing bugs and tweaking the balance. We have 2 new fleets incoming in the next few months, so I see plenty of future support and content from the devs. So give this game a chance. It might be difficult at first, but once you get past the learning curve, its tons of fun.

reviewText:
A fantastic RTS experience that offers a promising base to build from.

At present the game offers an interesting single player campaign as the imperial navy, on a large scale world map (think dawn of war soulstorm). Unlike so many recent RTS games the AI will beat you! I have lost a number of missions on the harder difficulty settings. Instead of this resulting in a game over and thus encouraging 'save scumming' the story line evolves, building your defeat into the narrative and leading to a more nuanced and engaging single player experience. While the story line itself isnt going to win any oscars, and the twists can be a bit telegraphed the way in which it incorporates your defeats makes up for this.

The battles themselves are smaller, personal affairs - think company of heros but with spaceship. With you controlling from 2 - 6 ships in fast paced, ship to ship engagements where facing, positioning and appropirate use of abilities is key. An active pause" button allows you to slow down time both in single player and mutliplayer ensuring that players of all abilities have the time to effectively micro (and also to appriciative the graphics and explosions).

Multiplayer involves 4 races that each play very differently. Everyone will find a race that appeals to their play styles but you will need to be adaptably as there is always a race that will hard counter your advantages - so adaptability is key. Games last from 3 - 10 minutes
date: with a hard 20 min time limit. Mission structures are a little hit and miss
recommended: particularly convoy missions that involve transport defence BUT this is NOT an e-sport. Games are short
hoursPlayed: you can easily get in 10 in an hour. Much like a game like hearthstone
voteText:
you will lose just as regularly as you win but the fast pace and short game time negates any hard feelings.

Balance is being continuely worked on - with patches in the BETA coming regularly.

While the game is a great stand alone product - providing hours of enjoyment (30 hours and still going for me) I am most excited for its post launch dlc and potenial as a platform for further expansion.

The introduction of new fleets
helpfulPercent: the potenial for extended single player campaigns
votesHelpful:
the potenial for an army painter introduction. All these offer exciting opportunities to extend the life of this game. While only the former is confirmed this game has a huge ammount of potenial for further development. More importantly none of these things are currently in the game and hidden behind a pay wall. It is clear that the developer is actively working on expanding the experience post launch and for this reason I would be happy to pay for DLC to cover the costs for the time and effort in creating these. UNLIKE WARHAMMER TOTAL WAR where races are being INTENTIONALLY locked off despite being in the game! The only pity is that mod support is not inbuilt - think Xcom 1 rather than Xcom 2.

My advice - buy it and try it. The game provides both bite sized RTS single / multiplayer missions for when you only have 30 minutes to spare AND a lengthy single player campaign / mutiplayer ship development for those with more time.

Anyway enough typing - I am off to play and forge a narrative for my mutiplayer fleet. DEATH TO THE HERETIC! FULL AHEAD AND BRACE FOR RAMMING!"

reviewText:
Destroyed a traitor imperial ship with a ship that was half damaged, and lost half of its main guns.  Stopped Traitor ship from escaping through the warp like a little ♥♥♥♥♥ and destroyed him.

11/10 would destroy traitors again.

Serious ReviewThe game is actually a really good RTS.  Runs fine on my 750ti and AMDFX6300 at Epic settings. The ships themselves are really well made, although I feel the textures aren't as good as what I saw in the preview videos on YouTube.

I'm enjoying the campaign, it feels like an actual campaign and not just something tacked on. I also like how some missions are designed to have you be defeated which is great as lets be honest we've had far too many campaigns in games where you win every battle.

Great thing though is that defeat doesn't end the campaign nor does it make you restart the battle.  The campaign continues regardless.

Victory however is really well rewarded.  You can get upgrades for your ships, favours from different factions which gives ships different bonuses, abilities and awesome paint jobs.

In short the campaign is probably one of the best I've played in a long time.  One thing I would have liked to have seen is a campaign for different races as not everyone is a fan of the imperial navy.

In terms of gameplay its a solid and complex RTS. I don't want to cover everything here, but lets just say you have a lot of control over how your fleet moves, how and what it attacks and so on. This is the first time I've seen an RTS have mechanics like this and they are a welcomed addition and I hope other RTS games implement these types of mechanics.

OverallBattlefleet Gothic Armarda is a solid RTS with robust mechanics and a great campaign mode. If you've played games such as Empire At War or are a W40k fan then you have no excuse to not get this game.

reviewText:
Do you like strategy games? Do you like giving orders to gigantic golden floating snowploughs with guns strapped to the back? Do you just really like beating yourself over the head with a Games Workshop hammer every three years, and haven't had a Dawn of War game in so long that you're beginning to get withdrawal symptoms?

Don't worry, Tindalos Interactive has you covered.

For those of you who may have tried Battlefleet Gothic: Armada during its beta test - don't worry, it's a lot better now. This game is actually surprisingly well polished (barring the occasional egregious typo), and while I can't claim to have played any multiplayer yet, I can promise you, the campaign is tippity-top quality. Golden and bedazzled with two-headed eagles, from start to finish. In fact, I'd argue it's better than the Dawn of War campaigns ever were - it completely negates the old irritation that DoW campaigns fell prey to - that of allowing the story's interesting material to congeal at the beginning and end. This is one well-paced story mode.

The only real criticism I can make, beside the occasional crash at the start of a battle, is that the game's friendly advice and some of its tooltips (particularly where regards convoy missions) are utter tosh. Don't split up your transports - keep them together. I've never lost a ship that way. Not much of a criticism, huh? I guess the game could use more fleets and factions to play with - but then, Tindalos has that in the works. Check back in six months.

I'm writing this review in the full and complete knowledge that you have probably already long since made up your mind about whether this is the kind of game you'd enjoy. If you like playing ship-versus-ship line battles (in space) (with snowploughs) this is the game for you. If you don't, go read another positive review. There's no shortage.

reviewText:
Sweet Zombie Jesus this game is good!

It's not for everyone.  You need to understand that it's age of sail, in space.  Don't go expecting homeworld with massive capship battles.

If you ever played the tabletop game, I honestly can't think of a better way to represent it other than vassal - the ships match their roles and the game has captured the feel of BFG - I should know, I maintained the datafiles for Army Builder for years.

Get this game - play something different, and accept that it's hard at times.  The biggest guns won't always win - the best strategy and positioning will.

reviewText: This is a wonderful adaption of a table top mini game to the computer.  As far as that class of adaptions go, its one of the best i've seen.  Gameplay is challenging and fun (hard and very hard are true to name!).  The learning curve is definitely steep initially, but levels out quickly.  Different mission types actually require different play styles (smash and destroy is not a tactic that works for everything!).  The story line and ending of the single player campaign were excellent.  On of the best RTS campaigns i've played in a long time.\n\nThe only negatives at this point are bugs, which mostly exist in multiplayer.  2v2 multiplayer for me bugs out in 1 out of every 3 matchs.  The devs have stated they are working on this, and as long as they fix it, I really would say I can recommend this game without reservations.

reviewText:
Many people seem upset over how this game plays. This is a rts/moba translation to a turn based tacticle table top game. Some things are just core to that original source and other things are adaptations in order for it to translate correctly.

The game is not without flaws but it is enjoyable and once you begin to understand how things work it becomes and adventure.

There is a grind to some degree but it is far less punishing then some games I have played and with the support we are seeing from the devs  in terms of balance and new fleets, this game will have a healthy life.

I only hope they introduce new campaigns for the other factions as well as global campaign metaverse where the actions of players in the faction can help determine the campaign.

reviewText: Loving it so far, minus a few crashes and bugs with matchmaking. The detail is excellent though i had to manually go to my nvidia control panel to enable the GPU, game was using my integrated card by default. The detail on the strike craft leaves something to be desired and fighters/assaultbarges/bomber squadrons feel tacked on and lacking in visual creativity. the real star of the show, ive found is the maneuvering of your ships. your weapons will for the most part auto engage, leaving it to you to set enemy priority and target subsystems in the crucial seconds before a battle, (unless you have early intel from probes, which give you additional time) but steering and turning your ships to bring weapons to bear, engage the brakes/speed boost to avoid torpedo volleys and bombs, and ramming smaller ships feels weighty and solidly done. The metagame which involves customization of your ships and ship and crew leveling in multiplayer encourages sound tactical moves as opposed to blind rushing by punishing you for losing ships to a (temporary) extent, this sees players attempting to judge whether they should commit their ships final seconds to a last ditch effort attack, or a tactical warp-jump retreat from the field to preserve their favorite capital ship and captain. The depth of customization is varied enough as it is, that when seeing an opposing fleet for the first time, it is difficult to judge what special abilities the opponent may be fielding so every battle feels different even if the ship lineup is currently a little anemic.

reviewText:
Many people seem upset over how this game plays. This is a rts/moba translation to a turn based tacticle table top game. Some things are just core to that original source and other things are adaptations in order for it to translate correctly.

The game is not without flaws but it is enjoyable and once you begin to understand how things work it becomes and adventure.

There is a grind to some degree but it is far less punishing then some games I have played and with the support we are seeing from the devs  in terms of balance and new fleets, this game will have a healthy life.

I only hope they introduce new campaigns for the other factions as well as global campaign metaverse where the actions of players in the faction can help determine the campaign.

reviewText: Loving it so far, minus a few crashes and bugs with matchmaking. The detail is excellent though i had to manually go to my nvidia control panel to enable the GPU, game was using my integrated card by default. The detail on the strike craft leaves something to be desired and fighters/assaultbarges/bomber squadrons feel tacked on and lacking in visual creativity. the real star of the show, ive found is the maneuvering of your ships. your weapons will for the most part auto engage, leaving it to you to set enemy priority and target subsystems in the crucial seconds before a battle, (unless you have early intel from probes, which give you additional time) but steering and turning your ships to bring weapons to bear, engage the brakes/speed boost to avoid torpedo volleys and bombs, and ramming smaller ships feels weighty and solidly done. The metagame which involves customization of your ships and ship and crew leveling in multiplayer encourages sound tactical moves as opposed to blind rushing by punishing you for losing ships to a (temporary) extent, this sees players attempting to judge whether they should commit their ships final seconds to a last ditch effort attack, or a tactical warp-jump retreat from the field to preserve their favorite capital ship and captain. The depth of customization is varied enough as it is, that when seeing an opposing fleet for the first time, it is difficult to judge what special abilities the opponent may be fielding so every battle feels different even if the ship lineup is currently a little anemic.

reviewText:
This game at the moment gets an 8/10 when it was released. This game is literially a rip right from the table top version of battlefleet gothic but this is a real time strategy game. No dice. Not a turn based game.

It is a fantastic game which was a surprise to me as it is better than what I thought this game would be. The story is split into 5 chapters and a prologue. The prologue consists of you learning the game along with following the story. Over the course of the 5 chapters, several events in the story line and lore of W40k occurs. Each chapter consists of events that occur during the years that each chapter covers before and during the 12th Black Crusade.

Story/Campaign:
You play as Admiral Spire of the Imperial Navy Battlefleet Gothic. It is your job to defend the systems and it's planets of the Gothic Sector from Traitor forces, Chaos forces, Eldar and Ork pirates during the events that take place during the 12th Black Crusade as Abbadon the Despoiler decides to attack the Gothic Sector.

I loved the campaign but there are very repetative missions (at least they are quick. But seriously playing Data Retrieval over and over and over again is repetative). The cutscenes are amazing! The music, voice acting and sound is amazing. The choices and mission results in some cases have an impact to the game!

This game consists on a space battles on a 2-D space using several ship types - escorts, light cruisers, cruisers, battlecruisers and battleships. You as an admiral of one of four factions get to select these ships and upgrade them.

More Information:

Micro Management Hell People are Talking About:

This so called micromanagement hell" people complain about seriously makes me question if they have ever played the original Dawn of War series or Star Craft 1. Micro management in this game isn't entirely perfect
date: more on that later when I've finished this game's campaign
recommended: but it works! You are only controlling at best 12 ships maximum and can work with them.  This game is a really good strategy game that literially rips the board game the difference really is at least on the table top version you can think about what to do each turn. This game "solves" this the special feature that makes all of the statics and strategy in this game possible... It's called Press the Space Bar to slow down time... A lot of these people complaining about the "micro management hell" really don't seem to understand this concept. In all honesty
hoursPlayed:
this game has much less micro management than Star Craft 2 and I prefer this for casual play and enjoyment.

2-D Space:

Umm... for people complaining.. It's a rip from the table top... Stop complaining. If you don't like it don't play it. Simple as that. This game is designed to be like this not because the game developers can't comprehend 3-D space or space comabt in games

reviewText: Do you like W40k? Do you like space combat? Then this game is for you. It is very true to the lore, while still being very fun. Lots of replayability, randomly generated maps. Very diverse factions, each faction has their own gameplay. Plenty of customization options for your fleet. Over all, this is a fantastic RTS. This being said, the multiplayer is wonky, in my experience. The greatist sin of this game is that there is no co-op. This game is built for a fun coordination experience between ship captains, yet they only restrict that mode to PvP. I would also like to see higher ship customization, perhaps even captain customizations like in XCom. It could also benefit for bigger and more varied maps, neutral factions, per haps?

reviewText:
An incredibly faithful rendition of Games Workshop's specialist game Battlefleet Gothic, if you loved the tabletop game, buy this now.

If you never played the tabletop game, you're looking at the following

Space RTS
4 Factions (at launch) - Imperium, Chaos, Ork, Eldar
2D fighting arena (a la the tabletop game)
Single player campaign (Imperium)
Solo Skirmish
Multiplayer
Mission types

Cruiser Clash (destroy all enemy ships)
Assassination (destroy enemy flagship) (or make sure your flagship escapes)
Escort (escort cargo ships across the map, (losing 1/2 your cargo ships loses you the round)
Data Retrieval (Using teleporters or boarding parties, steal the data and warp out)
Solo Skirmish
Custom Game
Multiplayer
I've found the game a lot of fun, enjoying the campaign and multiplayer. I think some balance issues need to be worked out as certain mission types are far easier for some races than others. (an Ork player trying to steal data from an Eldar player is virtually impossible).

I'm going to continue player and will update this review if I need to, but I'm looking forward to the Adeptus Astartes (Space Marines) and upcoming mystery race to further enhance the game play. I've really enjoyed my first 30 hours and I hope you will too. Good luck, Admiral!

reviewText:
You know, I came into this game expecting less than what I got. It wasn't a base building, 'send out ships and have them fight' RTS that I'm used to. Instead, it has customization of ships before battle with a variety of different game modes that are randomly chosen in the solo skirmish mode with epic battles between ships of colossal sizes. I am thoroughly enjoying what I paid for, surpassing all expectations I had for the game. I've clocked in 20 hours on the beta alone.

The gameplay is fantastic, with each race having it's own strengths and weaknesses. Each race presented so far is beautifully represented with their ships. The abilities constantly mix up the combat. You rank up and gain access to more ships as you progress. The campaign, from what little they've shown, is undoubtedly going to be fun.

This is truly a gem of a Warhammer 40k game. This is the first videogame I've encountered or even heard of that does Warhammer 40k space combat, and it is a beautiful representation of it. The first step into this realm is a glorious one and one that I have been waiting for for a long time. Thank you developers for all the work you've put into this. I have a feeling I will enjoy this game almost as much as I enjoyed Dawn of War.

Just make sure those modders have some tools to play with in the future. It's never a bad idea. Hell, it's kept Dawn of War and Sins of a solar empire going for quite a long time :)

reviewText:
First of all, allow me to say that I am a massive Warhammer 40k fan, so the things you'll read below will come with a certain bias, though I will try and thread the middle of the line.

So what is Battlefleet Gothic: Armada? Its a Warhammer 40k themed RTS that pits four distinct factions against one another, each one with ridiculously large weaponry mounted atop of even larger ships, as well as abilities and playstyles that represent the original lore surprisingly well. In the case of Orks this means yelling, shooting, and literally stuffing crewmen into torpedoes in order to get them to the action as quickly as possible, sanity or safety be damned!

But even if you ignore all of the Warhammer 40k elements I would still say that Battlfleet Gothic is one of the most interesting RTS games I've played in recent years, though its not without its faults, most notably the rather shaky multiplayer balance.

But first, allow me to briefly go over a couple of elements that make Battlefleet Gothic an enjoyable experience for me:

* The main reason I find the battles so compelling is the customization system which allows you to specialize your ships in a variety of ways, all of which play similarly enough to not be confusing, but also distinctly enough to offer a unique way of handling any situation. For example, if you ever get bored of playing with the standard Imperial loadout that focuses on heavy frontal armor and powerful broadside attacks, you can invest some resources into swapping around weaponry to create a fleet of fast-moving carrier ships that prefer to attack indirectly through the use of bombers and boarding parties.

* The second reason is quite simple, the battles are a bundle of quick, chaotic fun. Since most of them last 10 minutes or less its hard to get angry if you're losing, and any victory you secure won't get dragged out for so long that it stops being exciting. All of this combined means that for me personally Battlefleet Gothic has that magical ability to vacuum free time, the same way games such as Civilization IV capture their victims. The temptation to start up another match right after winning the previous one is deceptively attractive, and most of the time results in me having a completely messed up sleep schedule.

And speaking of messed up, here are the two main issues I have with Battlefleet Gothic:

* If you're not a fan of Warhammer 40k, or if you simply don't care about the lore, you're most likely going to be extremely disappointed with the campaign's story as its comically cheesy, melodramatic, and often downright ridiculous. I had a good bit of fun with it, mostly because the voice acting and overall themes are spot on, but its well worth mentioning that those of you that aren't Warhammer 40k fans might have a less than stellar experience. The campaign gameplay, however, I have very little complaints about, so if you don't give a rat's tail about the story, you'll be perfectly fine.

* The bigger issue is the problem of balance. There doesn't seem to be any matchmaking available to separate new and experienced players, which as you might imagine results in a complete and utter stomp. The secondary problem is that some matchups are inherently imbalanced, especially the early game Eldar vs Orks one. The issue stems from the fact that Orks are slow and inaccurate while the Eldar are nimble and mostly long ranged, so almost every single match ends up the same way - the Eldar run away, and the Orks pointlessly chase after them until they inevitably get whittled down. There are ways to counteract this, but in the early game where Orks only have one type of ship available they are completely out of luck.

Closing Thoughts
Battlefleet Gothic: Armada is a great RTS, but more importantly, it is a great Warhammer 40k game. It has managed to not just capture the look and feel of the universe, but also use its key elements and lore to further enhance the gameplay, and make the whole thing an immensely enjoyable experience.

It is currently in need of some balance-fixing in order to reach its true potential, but outside of that I have very little issue with saying that Battlefleet Gothic is well worth your time, especially if you're a Warhammer 40k fan. If not, I would suggest doing a bit more reaserch, or simply waiting on a sale as I can't really guarantee that the campaign will be up to snuff if you aren't a lover of Warhammer 40k branded cheesiness.

Finally, if you're interested in a more detailed review that includes actual gameplay I welcome you to either check out the written review[www.gamesear.com], or the video version I've done:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1gz6s2u2m1Q

Thank you for reading

reviewText:
Ah battlefleet gothic, never i've seen a game so faithfull to the warhammer universe . The campaign ,if repetitve by the end  is well though and engaging .Its a bit hard cause of  lack of manual and ifo. The tutorial will teach you how to move your ship but the important stuff you will have to figure it by trial and error. I spent quite a few dozens of hours on it
So its some great fun, why am i giving a tumb down ?

Thats simple, the game was clearly rushed out , the multiplayer part is really poorly thought and even primitive. Primitive as you cant  have a team channel for 2v2 , most often the number of ships fielded is 4-5 by side, very few points allowed to build your deck, you wont be tired due to heavy micro.

Unbalanced,to say the least. Theres different missions possible , similar to the campaign:
Cruiser clash, all good kill the other ships simple enough ,if you dont face eldars.
Data collection, steal some data from the opponent, the one with the fastest ship will win, remember its randomized so your slow ♥♥♥ ork ships might enounter eldar, then theres absolutely no way for you to win.
Assassination , same problem your opponent can just run away and quickly warp if he has the fastest ships
Planetary defense, it was already a poorly thought mission in the campaign its even worse in multi. You have to reach some part of the map , a circle appaearing randomly on the map . Again you better be really fast and lucky , as it highly favor the defender who as same amount of ships +4 defense platform to help.
Blockade same problem, you need to take down 4 defenses platform and reach the end of the map, but wait your opponent has still the same amount of ships than you ,good luck..
Transports,, pray to not be the one to have to guide those fragile butterflies through the map.

The matchmaking ? Wich matchmaking ?Your level 1 ship can face level 10 ships fully upgraded with favors . So you lose badly and your ships are unusable for one or two turn punishing you even more while the other guy will rake in favors.

That is when the game works, theres countless bugs, crash to desktop, camera view bugging , ship commands blocked, network problems...It really happens often now.

It could have been much better , it sounds like it was not tested at all , or by random hobos they took in the street to not pay QA costs.

reviewText:
I focus mostly on the single player; as such, I don't have much to comment on the balance of the multiplayer.

However, as someone who is a fan of the 40k universe and of naval combat in general, I really enjoy this game. It is a RTS game that is easily picked up, but also has the depth to have a meaningful experience. I organically learned the best tactics for naval combat- combat that has been used in the real world since the time of Napoleon.

It's incredibly satisfying to see enemy ships explore after a long fire fight and to hear the metal clash and grind following a last ditch ramming action.

Overall, I am very happy with the game. It's definately a 'budget' game, but I like being able to just pick up the game adn play it for a few skirmishes. There isn't a huge time commitment.

reviewText:
Why am I recommending against buying? Well lets divide up your area of interest.

40K Fan?
Well in the very first mission you have a Navigator helping your ship to navigate in real space, make sense? Only if you are grossly unfamiliar with 40K. Navigators are hybrid mutants that assist ships in transit through the warp, they couldn't care less about what happens in realspace, except of course the politicing of the Navis Nobilite. Oh, and the Navigator has no third eye, just a glowy patch on their head (with no cloth blocking it! Don't look too closely or you'll die), and they look like a freak, when every lore instance of a navigator describes them as aritocratic humans. I could list more examples, but no-one wants to read a story. Did the devs even do any research on 40K lore?

Gameplay?
Unbalanced as hell. It's not just that each faction has different archetypes and all are ultimately unbalanced, but mission types are unbalanced as well. Are you the Attacker on a Breakthrough mission? You are at a disadvantage. Are you the attacker in a Cruiser Clash (basic kill all enemies) using Eldar while your oppenents are Orks? Hope they don't hide in a gas cloud! If they do you pretty much auto-lose! Are you the Ork attacker fighting Eldar in a cruiser clash? Good luck doing any damage, their engines will see them out of your range pretty much permanently.
In addition the game tends to be more about spamming abilities, kiting endlessly, and tons of micromanagement. If this game had been turnbased it would have worked perfectly, but in real time (even with the slow time abilities) it ends up being a click fest.

Advancement / RPG elements?
You start with 3 light cruiser slots, with 2 different types of Light Cruiser. Both are almost identical, the Imperial for instance has all the same armor and weapons, except one has torpedoes and the other has a forward facing Lance. The Chaos have one with broadside lances, and one with launch bays (fighters, bombers). They are almost identical, and it takes 3ish missions to get a Cruiser slot. I've done 15ish missions and haven't unlocked any bigger ships yet, so the Gods of the Warp alone know how long it will take to get Battleships. It is a huge grind, and you are punished for losing. If a ship is destroyed in battle you can't use it for the next two battles. Sounds fun right? You lose one mission and then are at a huge disadvantage for the next 2 missions, making it more likely to lose those missions, in turn punishing you further. So what ends up happening? People will go into missions with ships they don't care about, and immediately warp out, just to ignore this 'feature'. It ends up being super fun!


All-in-all:
The game is fun, but not $40 worth of fun. I'd suggest waiting until the Steam Summer Sale, get it for 50% off, with the benefit of a few balance patches evening things out.

Edit: After playing for a few more hours the game does get more fun. However, it is really only when you get access to Battlecruisers (the second to last ship tier, which takes many, many hours to achieve) does the game really expand. Additionally if you unlock Battlecruisers with one race that does nothing at all for your other races, you need to sink even more hours in to unlock it with the other races. Even with battlecruisers the races are still very limited, Chaos BCs don't get above 50 armor for any facing, Eldar never get shields, Orks are slow tanks with no range regardless of the ship class, Imperial ships are always jacks-of-all-trades. In addition the further in you get the more annoying the destroyed ship, lost in the warp, and heavily damaged modifers become. With a 700 point game you are often using more than 50% of your capital ships, if it goes very poorly and you cannot warp out injured ships you may have very few capital ships for your next 2 battles.
Even after more time my recommendation doesn't change, wait for it to go on sale, and wait for some patches.

reviewText:
I'll start with the negatives first. The game needs balancing. Plain and simple, it needs balancing. In the single player campaign it's not as glaring, but in multiplayer it is. The fleets are not evenly matched. The game does have bugs, but it's a brand new title. That will happen. Finally some of the missions that you run are horribly unfair and stilted in favor of one side or the other. The destroy the defense platforms is nearly impossible from the defender's side. And easy as pie from the attacker. The transport mission can be a royal pain. You don't get a chance to recover, on either side. If the enemy gets lucky and wanders onto your transports, you lose. But if you're attacking and you wander onto the enemy transports? You win. But it's nearly impossible to catch them if they get past you. The data recovery mission is a shambling mess of see who can board who's ships the most. It's a mess.

Now, the good parts. The game is fun. It is a very well done tactical space combat game. It's set on a 2D plane, which makes sense given the intricacies involved in trying to run a fleet in a 3D environment. The controls are solid, the ships respond well, and the progression through the ships feels like an achievement. You can feel and see the difference in raw power between a light cruiser and a regular cruiser, and between a regular cruiser and a battle cruiser. Down the road the light cruisers replace your escorts as expendable ships because you've got big nasty beasts to slug it out with your foe now. The environments are well done, with mines, asteroids and nebula all littering the fields and complicating the battles, giving them more depth. This is a game that requires some thought and some planning. You need to keep in mind the strengths and weaknesses of your other ships as you build your fleet.

All in all, for me this game is very much worth the price at launch. But if you're still unsure? Just wait till the summer sale and snag it for 20 to 30 percent off or whatever sale they put it on to sell more copies.

reviewText:
Battlefleet Gothic: Armada is the RTS videogame adaptation of Games Workshop’s classic tabletop game, pitting the Chaos, Imperium, Eldar, and Orks against each other in visceral space-battles.

Developed with Unreal Engine 4, Battlefleet Gothic: Armada offers deep management of every ship composing the player’s fleet, both during and between battles. From the fastest frigates to the gigantic, miles-long battleships, the player will customize all aspects of his ships: weaponry, defense and support sub-systems, but also crew, captains, and more... each customization affecting the very performances of the ship and the special abilities available during battle. From battle to battle, the admirals and crew of surviving ships will gain experience and promotions, improving the battle-readiness of the ships for future, bigger and more dangerous battles.

Additionally an extensive multiplayer mode with persistent fleets where up to 4 players can battle simultaneously, Battlefleet Gothic: Armada also features a big story campaign, taking place during the 12th Black Crusade and putting players in the middle of the Gothic War that raged between the Imperium and Abaddon the Despoiler. Players will be at the centre of every fight, commanding fleets of gigantic ships as the Chaos unleash a sequential chain of surprise attacks on Imperium worlds – the start of 20 years of warring in the sector.
