reviewText:
So even though I never actually played the Battlefleet Gothic Table Top game, I did play Warhammer 40k, and I've always loved the ship design from the franchise. Now, at long last, we finally get to see them come to life in a game that does them justice. So this is a space based, ship to ship battle RTS game. I Played this game during beta and even then I was impressed. So let's go over the pros and cons of this game, because this is one alot of people have been watching closely.

Pros-
Ship design- The models of the ships are 100% faithful to the franchise, and they all look gorgeous.
Factions- Each faction, though they all share certain common features such as upgrades, feel unique in the way they play. Imperials are about up close, powerful broadside barrages. Chaos are fast long range raiders. Orks are tanky, close range brawlers that love to ram other ships. The Eldar are fast and use hit and run tactics. Each playstyle makes perfect sense in the context to their race. And given that this is 40k, you can bet other factions are on the way. Space marines are already confirmed, along with a mystery faction following that.
Voice acting- Although it's pretty apparent this wasn't a big budget title and they did have a huge variety of voices in the game, the ones they DO have are spot on and feel perfect for the 40k universe.
- Very strategic and challenging- I was actually surprised at this. The AI will actually kick your ♥♥♥ if your not careful. You actually have to manage and position your ships to prevail. Also remember what I mentioned about ramming? This game has full collision physics, that means you can actually crash your ships into each other if your not careful.

Cons-
Mission Variety- It feels like the mission types really aren't as diverse as they should be. I feel there are several mission types that reward bum rush tactics too much. I also rarely find there's an actual advantage to deploying your ships in different ways.
2d- Although the game is very much visually in 3d, the gameplay is 2d. In many ways this isn't actually that big a deal, as properly doing 3d gameplay in a space rts can be very difficult to do.
Soundtrack- Although the music they DO have is very good and appropriate, there's zero diversity. There's no special theme's for Chaos, orks, or the Eldar, which I think is a bit of a shame.
Bugs- Although the game is in pretty good shape for on launch, I have encountered a couple bugs ingame that WERE present during the beta.

Bottom line is, if you're a 40k fan, absolutely get this game. It more than does the source material justice, and it despite it not being perfect, it more than delivers, especially for only $40. Plus, buying within 2 months of release will get you the next 2 dlc factions for free, so not only did the devs make a good game, they want to reward you for buying it with free stuff. So just go and buy the damn thing already you wretched heretic!
voteText: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Stunning.
An absolutely faithful real time recreation of the fantastic tabletop fleet game.

The graphics are on point and do exactly what they need to which is unsurprising given they are using the Unreal 4 Engine.
Dialogue is campy, but that is to be expected for anything with the 40k License so can be forgiven. But the audio in general is really nice, especially the groaning and creaking of these titanic space vessels.
The different races feel mostly balanced with only maybe a small amount of tweaking needed.

Ultimately the feel of the game is spot on.

reviewText:
While the Warhammer liscense has been thrown around to some bad devs before, this is not one of those times. The Gameplay is fantastic, variety and customization is nicely done aswell.

Singleplayer
-A lot of RTS games usually have campaigns, but they're usually boring or just too slopily thrown together to enjoy. This game's campaign is nothing like that. It has great cutscenes, ones that warhammer fans absolutely love with that imperial touch. The game makes you feel like you're really part of the story. On the first playthrough you can't wait for your next turn to see what cutscene and priority mission comes next. Failure in these missions is not like most games. If you lose you don't just restart, you lose those ships and have to wait for a turn if damaged or two if destroyed. If you fail a priority that just means Abbadon will have more at his disposal to use against Humanity. After completion of the first playthrough you may end up playing again trying to pull victorys on missions you had previously suffered defeats.

Multiplayer
-The Multiplayer is a lot of fun and can keep you entertained for hours. The randomly generated maps make things a lot more interesting because it allows you (And a teammate if you do 2v2) to strategize and prepare for engagements around various gas clouds (which give you camoflauge.) and asteroid fields. (which damage you if the proper upgrade is not installed.) I found that even if I was losing, I could still grin as I would have caused so much destruction that I would feel the victory was well earned by the other player.

All factions play quite differently and allow for plenty of variety in playstyle.
-Imperial Navy ships are heavily armored and are generally covered in macro cannons for devastating broadsides yet lack the speed some may wish to have.
-Chaos ships are quite fast and have weaker armor but still enough to survive some of the broadsides that the imp navy can throw at you. Their extra launchbays and long range assaults make hit and run assaults somewhat viable.
-Ork ships are massive and are extremely resilent to damage. While Imp navy is tough, they can't say they're Ork tough. Ork ships have massive healthpools and strong armor aswell has having lots of ramming damage. While their accuracy is not the greatest, their weapons hit the hardest in the game aside from Eldar pulsars. An Ork battleship is one of the hardest things to kill in this game.
-Eldar has quite the weird playstyle and can have a large learning curve. While Orks have their best weapons on their prows, Eldar have ONLY prow weapons meaning you must always face what you want to shoot. Eldar also lack shields and instead have holofields and allow you to dodge and absorb incoming fire as long as you move. Eldar ships are also very fast and can turn extremely fast. This combined with only forward firing weapons mean you only have so much time to fire else you ram what you're shooting at, something that is lethal for the fragile eldar ships. Things like Vauls maneuvre (allows you to instantly do a 180) make this much easier to perform however.

I have to say things were shaky during the Beta but things are quite balanced and tweaked now. All in all, this game is a great experiance and a must get for fans of the Warhammer series. I can only hope there is only more to come with space marines on their way and a mystery fleet already announced. So what are you doing? Buy this game! For the Emperor!

reviewText:
I strongly approve of Battlefleet Gothic: Armada. This is an excellent game.

Ever since I got into Warhammer 40k, Battlefleet Gothic has always been the one aspects of the franchise that really interested me but I felt would never be represented anymore. This computer game is very true to the general feel of Battlefleet Gothic, and one of the best things about it - it's *hard*.

You can't just zerg-rush people in this game or you're gonna die. Battlefleet Gothic: Armada requires planning, tactics, long-term thinking, and is a real challenge. Kudoes to Tindalos for doing the franchise such justice.

I hope that the armadas of the other races are fleshed out as much as the Imperium, which I suspect they will be, and I'm really looking forward to upcoming expansions, which I will gladly purchase if they are reasonably priced.

I'm normally a strong proponant of saving your cash because entertainment is cheap these days, but buy Battlefleet Gothic: Armada. Tindalos Entertainment deserves to do very well for this, and I am seriously going to be paying attention to their future titles. Bravo devs.

reviewText:
I was hoping Custom games would be an ability to play against my friends but it is not. It is just solo skirmish with no additional perks outside of you can choose which game mode to play.

I find the grammar and editing hilariously wrong in some instances during the campaign.

I bought this game to play 2v2 inhouses with my friends, it appears I cannot even do that. This is bad enough that argueably I would like to get a refund, but alas I have 80 hours already in the game.

If you are looking at destroying your opponent in matchmaking I would recommend this game.

If you are looking for a visually stunning game I would recommend this game.

If you are looking for a game to play with and against your friends this game is not it.

If they were to implement the ability to play against your friends instead of just teaming up for 2v2. I would fully recommend this game.

reviewText:
This is my first foray into the 40k ish universe. Being a huge fan of Strategy and Tactical games I of course had to get this game. The devs hit the mark I'd say in capturing the spirit of 40k.

Things I Like:

- The music, my god
- The lore is awesome for each race and 40k as a whole
- The cinematics and the campaign story
- Customization options
- The background visuals and overall artwork
- Broadsiding an enemy at point blank and boarding them

Cons:

- Steep learning curve (but when you get over the hump it's a thrill)

Conclusion:  I was playing the game and looked at the clock and it was 3am. So you can definately lose yourself in the game.  Buld your ships to the play style that suits you. Go to all the forums you can and ask questions if you get stuck.

Buy it and have fun.

reviewText:
This game is great, I will attempt to summarize the game based on what I've expereinced.

Pros:
- Stunning Graphics
- Sticks true to the lore
- Stricks true to the table top of the same name
- Mechanics for each playable race are different [aka not cookie cutter with different skins]
- Campaign is lenghty and challenging
- Each race currently in the game is filled with diverse models
- Each model has 4 different varations with their own bonus'
- Delvered what they promissed

Cons:
- The game has a steep learning curve
- The campaign starts off easy then becomes impossible
in the campaign your allies don't do anything to keep themselves alive aka. you fail alot of allie mission do to their incompetence [eldar sitting stil on chase cannon mode basically]
- the above is very fustrating
- The AI seems to be able to bring far more points to the battle then you
- The ships get stuck on space objects to easily
- The game is HUGE on the micro
- The above means you have to play in their slow mo mode in order to feel like your in control
- The graphics on my Titan X don't seem to be like the developers, can't seem to figure out why
- Community on the disscuion boards is toxic
- No ETA on early adopters content
- No ETA on adding the non base game models from the TT
- Most of the game modes are basically a cat and mouse chase

reviewText: I've played through a few chapters of the campaign and run a few skrimishes as the non-Imperial races and so far I feel the game is pretty good. One of the stumbling blocks for me getting started was expecting the game to play at roughly the same difficulty as most RTS I've played through in the past, but in Battlefleet Gothic you really can't just mass your ships and just point them at the enemy and hope to win most of the time. Positioning and knowing how your ships perform compared to the enemy are really important to the point where you might breeze through the first few missions only to find yourself losing mission after mission until you adjust your fleet comp and tactics based on your foe and the objectives.\n\nSo, I guess if you're looking for a C&C type RTS this probably isn't it, but if you're looking for something more micro intensive with a bit of a learning curve this might be the game for you, That said, if you're into multiplayer I can't make any recommendation on that yet as I haven't delved into that part of the game at all.

reviewText: Staunch believer in the almighty power of the God Emperor of Mankind. This game stays sincerely true to the warhammer 40k universe. However, you will either love this game forever or completely hate it. There's RNG involved, and honestly plenty of micromanaging especially when fighting the mutant and the alien. It's not turn based, and there's no pay to win system. This game requires actual planning in advance and choosing the right ships for the job. I just hope the dev's keep this game updated constantly and fix certain matchmaking issues.\n\n9/10 for me.

reviewText:
Awesome game.  Rather ambitious in scope, and not fully polished yet, but the devs have said they're going to keep working on it for some time.  Even if they didn't, the games still one of the best I've played for  several years.

The gameplay is fairly unique,  quite different to other space games.  If you're not a hardcore WH40K fan it might be worth watching a few youtubes before you buy, as I guess it might not be for everyone.

Has 4 difficulty levels.  So on easy casual players can mostly  just leave their fleet to do their own thing, perhaps just controlling one ship. They can enjoy the great story in the campaign, the well created WH2k atmosphere and the games's near perfect voice acting.  Whereas on the harder settings or against a good opponent in multiplayer,  a lot of intricate micromanaging is needed.

For the emperor!

reviewText:
Let me start off by saying I am addicted to this game. But I still would not recommend it now. I may in the future, however.

Pros:
-Stays true to the 40k universe. Both in the story and atmosphere of the game, and the gameplay. Imperials are sturdy, resolute, and have the ability to crush their enemies like the hammer of the emperor. Chaos are like a twister dagger, fast and deadly, but can't take the punishment of the imperials. Eldar are swift and lethal, but their ships are made of wet tissue. And orks are wild and deadly. They are insanely strong, but also insanely hard to control, more like holding a pack of hungry pitbulls on a leash than controlling an amry. Any 40k player should be happy with this.
-Strong story that stays true to the original tabletop campaign.
-The campaign is long and unforgiving, exactly as a void war should be.
-Good mix of gametypes in the multiplayer
-Decent community
-Challenging and rewarding gameplay
-THE BIG RED BUTTON
-The orks. Seriously too damn fun. You can get a giant snotling teleporter for a weapon. Freebootaz are the best damn thing in the void of 40k.

And here is why I would not recommend this game, for now at least
Cons:
-Gamebreaking bugs. The game was in beta for a month and has been out for a month now. Two months to fix the game. It has gotten better. But between 25-50% of my multiplayer games end with a fatal error crashing the game. Somewhere around 10-20% of campaign missions end with the game crashing. This is seriously ruining the game. There should not be this many errors.
-Balance. I wouldn't expect a game to have good balance shortly after release, but its still a serious issue. Any game besides cruiser clash against eldar involves the eldar skating around the map and the other player driving in circles. The nova cannon was OP, killing escorts in one shot, but they nerfed it into the ground. Its is innacurate and is so weak it can only take the shields off an escort. Orks lost their best upgrade, the engine boost, giving them no way to compete in speed. Balance is not horrible, but its not good or even okay
-There are no different maps. There are different backgrounds and different amounts of space debris, but overall there is very little beside generic space. This is 40k. You can do so much in space. Live a little devs
-No way to choose gametype in multplayer. If you don't like escort games, suck it up buttercup. You still gotta play them.
-You can only play with one friend
-In 2v2s, games are either 600 or 700 points. This is annoying because you're always stuck with light ships. I know the game can run more ships on the map, they do so in the campaign. I don't know why they felt the need to limit this.
-Finally the minor bugs, that aren't gamebreaking. Stuff like not being able to issue special orders or use abilities in multiplayer.

Its a fun game but in its current state, it is not good. If the updates fix it to the point I no longer I have to worry about constant crashes, I'll change this review.

EDIT:
This game has an awful community of fun-hating, spite filled cry babies. The worst is a large percentage of eldar and chaos players. When they've lost the battle but they still have ships, they decide to run. Not warp away and end the game. No, they decide to run away for 20 minutes, knowing that they cannot win. They know they have no hope of winning but they know that you can't catch them and they are intent on wasting your time.

If you think about, this horrible community just puts it closer to the real tabletop one. Just like the 40k tabletop scene, this game is filled with spiteful meta drones. I'm done with this game. Not the devs fault this time.

reviewText:
Why am I recommending against buying? Well lets divide up your area of interest.

40K Fan?
Well in the very first mission you have a Navigator helping your ship to navigate in real space, make sense? Only if you are grossly unfamiliar with 40K. Navigators are hybrid mutants that assist ships in transit through the warp, they couldn't care less about what happens in realspace, except of course the politicing of the Navis Nobilite. Oh, and the Navigator has no third eye, just a glowy patch on their head (with no cloth blocking it! Don't look too closely or you'll die), and they look like a freak, when every lore instance of a navigator describes them as aritocratic humans. I could list more examples, but no-one wants to read a story. Did the devs even do any research on 40K lore?

Gameplay?
Unbalanced as hell. It's not just that each faction has different archetypes and all are ultimately unbalanced, but mission types are unbalanced as well. Are you the Attacker on a Breakthrough mission? You are at a disadvantage. Are you the attacker in a Cruiser Clash (basic kill all enemies) using Eldar while your oppenents are Orks? Hope they don't hide in a gas cloud! If they do you pretty much auto-lose! Are you the Ork attacker fighting Eldar in a cruiser clash? Good luck doing any damage, their engines will see them out of your range pretty much permanently.
In addition the game tends to be more about spamming abilities, kiting endlessly, and tons of micromanagement. If this game had been turnbased it would have worked perfectly, but in real time (even with the slow time abilities) it ends up being a click fest.

Advancement / RPG elements?
You start with 3 light cruiser slots, with 2 different types of Light Cruiser. Both are almost identical, the Imperial for instance has all the same armor and weapons, except one has torpedoes and the other has a forward facing Lance. The Chaos have one with broadside lances, and one with launch bays (fighters, bombers). They are almost identical, and it takes 3ish missions to get a Cruiser slot. I've done 15ish missions and haven't unlocked any bigger ships yet, so the Gods of the Warp alone know how long it will take to get Battleships. It is a huge grind, and you are punished for losing. If a ship is destroyed in battle you can't use it for the next two battles. Sounds fun right? You lose one mission and then are at a huge disadvantage for the next 2 missions, making it more likely to lose those missions, in turn punishing you further. So what ends up happening? People will go into missions with ships they don't care about, and immediately warp out, just to ignore this 'feature'. It ends up being super fun!


All-in-all:
The game is fun, but not $40 worth of fun. I'd suggest waiting until the Steam Summer Sale, get it for 50% off, with the benefit of a few balance patches evening things out.

Edit: After playing for a few more hours the game does get more fun. However, it is really only when you get access to Battlecruisers (the second to last ship tier, which takes many, many hours to achieve) does the game really expand. Additionally if you unlock Battlecruisers with one race that does nothing at all for your other races, you need to sink even more hours in to unlock it with the other races. Even with battlecruisers the races are still very limited, Chaos BCs don't get above 50 armor for any facing, Eldar never get shields, Orks are slow tanks with no range regardless of the ship class, Imperial ships are always jacks-of-all-trades. In addition the further in you get the more annoying the destroyed ship, lost in the warp, and heavily damaged modifers become. With a 700 point game you are often using more than 50% of your capital ships, if it goes very poorly and you cannot warp out injured ships you may have very few capital ships for your next 2 battles.
Even after more time my recommendation doesn't change, wait for it to go on sale, and wait for some patches.

reviewText:
Amazing Real Time Tactics game! If you're a Warhammer 40k fan, it's a must have. If you're a lover of space warfare, this is the best in it's class if you like fleet warfare focused on a large variety of warships. My favorite aspect of this game, is it has that Dawn of War feel to it (the design, atmosphere, music, and voice acting).

Between the lengthy campaign, and the sp/mp rpg-like fleet progression system, this game will keep you playing for many months, and years to come.

To top it all off, the Developers have long term support planned, and we'll be getting two major races for free in the next few of months (Space Marines, and Tau Empire). They are really a great developer to support, and they have done justice to the WH40k universe.

reviewText: Amongst the sea of garbage that is early access" on steam
date: this game has been a gem. I enjoy it for several reasons. Its one of the few games I can access in short spurts and get some satisfactory gaming time in. My schedule does not allow me to sit down for more than 15-20 minutes to play. This game allows that. I sit down and can play a mission or two and get that fix. Or I can play for hours because its fun.\n\nThere are more than a few modes to play in. You have a single player campaign which has you playing the Imperial faction. You have multiplayer where you play against other people in 1v1 and now 2v2 player battles where you can choose to play one of 4 different factions. Eldar
hoursPlayed: Chaos
voteText: and Orcs are the current factions available. Each faction plays in a unique style as each faction has different strengths and weaknesses. And then you have a solo play where you pick a faction and create an Admiral. Then you random solo mission as your admiral and fleet levels up.\n\nEach mission you do
helpfulPercent: be it solo or multi play
votesHelpful: gains you experience. Your admiral and your ships all gain experience. You then use this experience to buy different skills and abilities to customize your fleet. As your Admiral levels up
votesTotal: you open up more ship options as larger ships become available along with more smaller ships.\n\nThe battles themselves play much like an x/y single plane flat surface where your ships manuever. There is only left right forward and back. There is no up and down. You do not have a true space experience in being able to move in all directions. I believe this is due to it being inspired by a board game. Its still fun. Your ships are fitted with different weapons which have firing arcs. This means in order to fire off say your macro cannons which only fire broadside in a 90 degree arc
votesFunny:
you have to move your ship so its left and right faces your target. You have weapons which fire from either the front or the sides in different degrees of firing which add to your depth of strategy and make it so you don;t just bring your ships in range and see what happens.

The graphics are ok. They don't appear to be cutting edge but they aren't too old either. The sound is ok as well. There isn't a large variety in the little voice acting bits but they are there. They can get a bit tedious to hear every time your make a movement with a ship as there aren't a great variety.

Bottom line is its a finished game that works as intended and delivers on its promises. It also appears to have a strong multiplayer community and the developers have already promised more factions in the future to add to the depth of play. Its worth the purchase price."

reviewText:
I bought during the Beta and I really like it so far.  The game has a lot of depth and requires study of the ship tactics and abilities.  However, it's best to learn as you go and play in AI skirmish to prepare for the Campaign, or go multiplayer if you are up for a serious challenge against skilled players.

I am going through the Single Player campaign on Normal and finding it immersive and challenging.  The characters in the storyline really take their 40K roles seriously.  I have heard there are some AI issues in some missions but that's to be expected (just reload if the AI goofs on you).

I'm not a fast-twitch RTS player but I like the combat.  The game offers an immediate slow-down mode via the spacebar (called Tactical Cogitators) if the gameplay gets to frantic.  You can use it all you want in AI skirmish, but it's frowned upon to abuse it in multiplayer.   The combat is on a 2D plane but even then the battle action can get complex (you can view the combat in 3D, of course).

I've found myself engrossed in studying the game's tactics the past four weeks.  The last time I was engrossed in game this much was with the Earth Defense Force series (that's more of a 3rd person shooter/arcade game).

I like the Warhammer 40K Fluff and this game has a ton of it for the Imperium, Eldar, Orks and Chaos.  Also the developers are going to add the Space Marines faction and the Tao as DLC.

There are some technical issues with this game just to get it to run.  I have two Win 8.1 machines and it ran fine on my primary computer but had issues on the tablet (Surface Pro 3).  But I eventually got the version working on the tablet after going over the Technical FAQ posted in the game's Steam Forums by the developers.

The only thing missing for me is a way to go back and rewatch my battles using a free-roam camera.  So far you can't see any of the battles up close unless you go Tactical Cogitators and zoom in on the action.  I hope the developers add a battle recorder soon.

Anyhow, if you are a WH40K fan then I highly recommend the purchase, and if you have never heard of 40K this is a great way to experience it the first time.  Just be prepared to use the trouble-shooting FAQS on the forums if you are the small percentage that run into technical issues.

For reference I'm running Window 8.1 Enterprise on my primary system with an i7 cpu, 16GB ram, and a GTX 980 ti GPU, and the game runs great and with no issues.

My secondary system, a Surface Pro 3, has Win 8.1 Professional and an i5 processor, and an intel GPU.  That system had problems running the game, not due to hardware, but improper install procedures and missing some DirectX files.  Going thru the Technical FAQ resolved my issues and I was able to play BFGA on a plane trip (though it ate up a lot of battery power).

reviewText:
Battlefleet Gothic: Armada is a real-time tactical game where you control voidships from the various Warhammer 40000 factions and battle it out in brutal naval duels in space. Simply put, this game is wonderful.

Tindalos, the developers of Battlefleet Gothic: Armada love the Warhammer 40000 universe and it shows in their game. BFG:A captures the Warhammer 40k universe to a surprising degree. The gameplay, the writing, the art, voice overs, general sound design, the interface--all of it feels right at home with the 40k universe.

The gameplay is incredibly fun. Each faction (Imperial Navy, Chaos, Orks, Eldar with Space Marines and Tau forthcoming) has distinct gameplay strategies, skills, and upgrades that set them apart and make them feel distinct. In addition you can customize each of your ships to a large degree--name, skills, upgrades, subfaction favours, and soon even it's appearance. It manages to capture the feeling of having your own Tabletop fleet and brings it to the digital realm.

There are a lot of different mission types to keep the game from feeling stale. There is an enjoyable single player campaign as well as 1v1 and 2v2 multiplayer. The community is simply one of the best I have ever encountered in an online game.

Tindalos is continually updating the game to add new features and remove any bugs. Their level of engagement with the community and dedication to improving their game is really nice to see in this age of Early Access then abandon." I'm really looking forward to the future of this game.

In short
date: if you like Warhammer 40000 or sci-fi naval combat then buy this game. Buy it now."

The bad:
The factions are not balanced appropriately. Currently, Chaos has a tough time even if their fleet build is optimised. To a lesser extent, the same is true for Imperial. I've found Orks to be really strong, but every faction burns when fighting Eldar.
The Eldar are built so that they are either an absolute pushover (new players) or maximized - you won't touch them and your ships will be evaporated. It's not fun to play alongside them or against them because of how two dimensional the results are.

The bugs: Matches failing to load, hard crashes, menu lockups, server login issues, visual bugs, etc. I believe these will be patched but they are here, now.

The good:
It looks super pretty. The ships feel massive and powerful. The factions play differently and have a reasonable amount of options, though more balance is needed. The voice acting is strong and cheesy. Gaining a victory feels like an accomplishment and there are unique satisfactions to be had in these matchups.

The specific:
The game is real time, with a 'slow' function that you can use to micro manage your units. Expect to lose, and to win. Matches are between 5 and 10 minutes long. Players with more experience will have more options and more effective ships than you. No custom matches for multiplayer. 2v2 is current maximum, party size is limit 2 so you cannot set up a match with 4 friends. Mouse and keyboard only, I wouldn't recommend setting up a controller for it. Better with friends.

reviewText: An amazing game, truly some of best gameplay for a RTS in a long long time. You can feel your ships weight as they float through the void, the power that is thrown out of their weapons, and the terror that awaits them in the warp. In terms of gameplay I'd say there are very few downsides, except that at the time of writing the Eldar are considered maybe a tad OP. A very fun game. The game does have its downsides unfortunately, it is filled with a lot of bugs. The game crashes a lot, sometimes you can't use abilities, and sometimes it'll stick you in a match that doesn't start. However I'd still recommend buying the game, as it is otherwise phenomenal, and the devs are actively updating and working on it.

reviewText:
One of the biggest surprises in my gaming history and deffinitely the best computer game set in Warhammer 40k universe ever made. Guys from Tindalos - previously known from a horrendously bugged space MOBA and horrendously bugged wannabe-innovative RTS - completely outdid themselves in bringing the Gothic War to life, recreating battles from rulebooks, novels and comics, clearly understanding the world they are recreating better than many before them. With great mechanics, diverse factions and a marvelous single-player campaign - prepare for a bizarre experience of gothic cathedrals clashing in XVII - century naval combat, with plasma and pulsars, in space.

It is an RTS crafted by fans, for fans, and a truly beatiful love letter to both fans of the genre and fans of W40k.

Some people are bragging about balance in multiplayer - it's way more balanced than oh-so-splendid DoW, and, to be honest, way more balanced then any GW tabletop ever hopes to be :P

reviewText:
Game is amazing. I can not say this enough. So let me tell you the only issues with the game.

You can in fact jump in and start playing and do pretty well without a tutorial. Which is good because there really is no tutorial.

Theres the obligatory tutorial built into the first few min of the game. Click with this button to go here
date: click on this and it will do this
recommended:
click on that and it will do that"

But the parts of the game that you will really need to do well are not explained. Every gamer at this point knows you either right or left click to move and click and drag to multi select units. HOW the game works is way more important to explain.

Things like what exactly is a boarding action. And how additional boarding actions work. What weapon type something is if its ambigous. Like are torpedoes Macro Weapons or not?

But the biggest problem is the language involved in the tool tips. Basically instead of saying you have a X% chance of something working under certain situations
hoursPlayed: it instead says "you have X% chance" of something happening and then you have to know enough about the mechanics of the game to know if that means chance of it happening the way you want it
voteText:
or doing a quick mathematical formula in your head and knowning that you have to work backwards with the numbers to figure out if its the chance of it failing.

This is mostly having to do with boarding actions and most specifically dealing with being boarded by or boarding Orcs

I also find that lightning striking which is only supposed to be successful when an enemy's shields are down will work when they are not and sometimes not when they are.


So I give it a 9/10 because it pretty much forces you to go find a wiki to explain how you really should be loading out a ship to fit your individual play style

it basically sets up a scenario where you either play the game over after completely screwwing your first game up because you loaded out and played wrong. Or you make multuiple saves so that you can try things over and over again and only save the games where you did well.


TLDNR....

Good game. Go read wikis because the tool tips are over simplified. And understand that the English language can be used in multiple ways and not always the way you interpret things.

reviewText:
Not exactly the best 40K video game, but it's certainly better than what we've been getting recently. A great single player campaign that functions along the lines of XCOM in which you must make decisions that hurt you the least. The campaign is well voice acted and quite a lot of fun, albeit a little unbalanced at times with some unpleasent difficulty spikes. Overall a positive expierience

If you're still looking to ram enemy ships into tiny pieces after crushing Abaddon's 12th Failed Crusade, the persistant skirmish mode is quite a bit of fun and is certainly something you can put down and pick up over time.

An RTS game that rewards chin-rubbing thinking a little more than twitchy high APMs.

reviewText:
[Single player review only]

Positives:
- Combat is visercal and satisfying:
Getting the fleet set up right and pounding some xeno cruiser into scrap feels like it should - righteous before the Emperor.
- UI is clean and effective:
Took all of 30 seconds to figure out what everything is and how it works. Speaks well of the design team.
- Tone of the game is about right:
Campy grimdark 40k universe? Check. Not taking itself that seriously? Check. Purging xeno scum? Check!
- Nice variety between races.
The red one do indeed go faster.

Negatives:
- Campaign is a little grindy:
You fight a series of engagements that are repeated variations of the same formulas - deathmatch, capture the flag, escort, capture point. Could have done more with special maps/ship etc. Advancing becomes a bit of a chore and you know for each battle you win you're going to have to do the same thing over again two or three times per turn.

Overall?
Worth picking up. I get the feeling the devs are going to run with this one. Couple of DLCs and balance passes down the line and this is going to be a neat little number.

reviewText:
A game worthy of the Warhammer title. It really captures the feel of the WH40K universe.
Battles are short, intense, and brutal; the campaign provides a decent amount of playtime hours, and multiplayer does the rest, though there are still some balancing issues (looking at Eldar)

Definitely recommended for al Warhammer fans

reviewText:
Well then, battlefleet gothic: Armada, here we go 'sigh'.

to start off i feel like this game does justice to the universe of warhammer 40k, especially the tabletop game it was based on.

but...well...it's just something of a mess at the moment, even though the game itself plays well, has great textures and has a ok campaign, it's very reminisant of that RTS vibe 40k has for games on pc, yet it also fails on alot of points, and it's very sad for a veteran 40k player like me to see that it's kinda going down the pan like alot of other 40k games.

The grinding:

leveling in battlefleet gothic is mind numbingly slow, i'd get it a good 11 hours to get everything for a SINGLE faction in skirmish/multiplayer and the harder you put it on, the longer your going to have to grind, your going to spend WAY to long on each faction, and for just the 4 factions there are at the moment it feeling very pointless, it's almost like they made it that way so you can buy your way to get the best ships. there is also the very silly ship damage system, to put it simply, if you lose a ship in a battle your not getting that ship back for probably 1-3 missions, unless you give the game your well earned ingame money to make it repair quicker or just repair it completely which can be quite hefty if you have lost alot of ships.

the micromanageing:

'sigh' this is a major problems, i have never played a game with so much micromanageing, the put it in a big picture, you HAVE to be the npc to be able to perfectly manage your fleet, when your fleet has almost a dozen ships all with special abilites, turning menouvers, weapon ranges, ship angle or side checking, 'click this button to fire' weapons, and watching the battle aswell, you start to realise that the game is completely over the top for a person to do, and if you mess up you will probably end up ramming your own ships or hitting them with your own torpedos and cannons and never mind the fact that your fleet goes limp when they say destroy an enemy ship that you told them to destroy and then just do nothing (EVEN THOUGH THERE IN THE MIDDLE OF A BATTLE GETTING SHOT AT).

The ability system:

see, in the tabletop game you only got to use 1 ability per turn, but in this you can just spam abilites to your hearts contempt, then just wait a bit and start spaming again, this wouldn't be a problem if the abilites wern't so overpowered, throw a load of stasis bombs and watch the entire enemy fleet just freeze while you shoot the hell out of them then watch all your shots pound into them as they can avoid them and end up totaling there capital ships or escorts, this is even worse when combind with plasma bombs or lance turrets, then there the fact that EVERY faction has the same abliltes which make no sence considering that some of those abilites don't need to be in certain factions.

and finaly!

The ungodly unbalancing:

here's the thing, the beta was meant to sort out the overpowered from the underpowered, for instance, the nova cannon, also known as 'the critical existance failure cannon' which was nerfed into the not very used territory, then there was the fun perk of WMP or micro warp jump, in the beta you could jump a ship literaly into another ships path and smash then into each other like as if it was navel warfare in the greek times, but yet that was nerfed to, now you can only jump at a certain distance near another ship, so no more super warp ramming, but you see, thats just ablities and weapons, the worst part is that the stuff that needed balancing never got balanced.

see, in the multiplayer, lets say you play the imperial navy and your opponent is playing eldar corsairs and the mission is data recovery, which is basicaly nick the important stuff off each other then run away, normally this would be a balanced fun and alos quite tense game, but in reality you will get outrun, out menauvered and in some cases, out gunned, you can micromanage all you want but there is almost no way your going to win, you spend all your time running after their ship and when you finally catch up to it your opponent will just boost his way out and warp to saftey because he is outside of your striking range, or in the case of ork, just ram the crap out of your ships, and if that doesn't kill you then his torpedos or boarding assaults will cripple you to hell, then in the case of chaos, just sit out of your weapons range and send a baggillion bombers the blow up your ships, which is the same as what eldar do. but lets not forget about the imperium, just meh, there good but to be honest you'll be out-everythinged at some point.

look, im not saying the game is bad, it's just....well....not enjoyable, the problems seriously damage the fun aspect, not to mention that the trailers are VERY missleading.
there are no massive space battles, just small scale mini battles.
there is no team or friend joining, it's all random.
and it's very hard to get used to, especially the keybinds.

what i'll say is, the game is ok, it's not anything special, it's not really that enjoyable and it can seriously annoy you at points the multiplayer and skirmish.
but for a game of it's type it does quite well, the campaigns fun, the ships look FANTASTIC and look even better with a special skin which gives you a few extra skills or upgrades and i think this could be the best feeling FPS i've played in a long time.

so...final verdict....what i'd say is, save your money untill they fix the major problems, at the moment it's not good, but keep checking up on it because it will eventually get sorted one way or another...but like i said, save your money for now, or get homeworld 2 remastered for roughly the same price.

i'll give battlefleet gothic: armada at it's current state 5/10.
voteText: 33 of 67 people (49%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
To my knowledge this is the third game from the developers Tindalos Interactive. I would encourage people to look at Steam reviews of their two previous games Etherium and Stellar Impact.

Battfleet Gothic is well presented with excellent details in the cut-scenes, and the graphics are very good. The gameplay is different to typical strategy games and involves selecting ships for a fleet to undertake a variety of different mission types, which scale in diffucluty very sharply, depending on what faction you play as or against.

I really wanted to like this game after spending considerable time on the Beta. The game was originally supposed to be released on the 21st March but when the beta went live it was riddled with 'Fatal Error' bugs and crashes to desktop. The beta, which consisted of multiplayer 1 vs 1 and the first three missions of the campaign was extended to the new release date of 21st April. As things went on many of the bugs seemed to be ironed out.

However, once the game ws finally released it became apparent that it was still riddled with bugs. I would still encounter random 'Fatal Error' crashes while playing the campaign. In addition, when trying to play multiplayer 2 vs 2 with a friend practically every other game would result in a crash to the game's main menu, or back to desktop.

The problem is that all too often I don't get to play it due to all the bugs and crashes. Just getting a multiplayer 2v2 set up with my friend takes several tries as the invite system just doesn't work. Then once in the game the chances of finishing the match are far too slim. All in all a good concept but let down by poor coding.

After trying to play multiplayer with my friend we both decided to request Steam Support for a refund, which I hope they will honour as this is the only game I've ever requested a refund on. I would strongly suggest you save yourself the bother and avoid this game. Based on the history of Tindalos Interactive I cannot see anything changing as they never fixed the bugs on their previous two games either if you look at their reviews.

Positives:
Graphics look great
Fun gameplay

Negatives:
Too many bugs
Cant play private matches against a friend

reviewText:
Despite some fun ideas the game runs afoul of repetative boreing missions.

Data theft, assassination (attacker) and planatary assault are all variations on raceing around the map trying to get an objective on a timer. This leaves Space Station Assault, Curiser Clash and Convy as the only game types that aren't raceing around the map trying to manage a stamina meter to shepard akwardly manuvering ships on a timier.

Almost all missions are randomly generated, with only a few in single player not being loosly connected skirmish maps.

Every ship you command comes with fiddly, micro-management encourageing triggered abilites that are the core to victory.

The game faithfully recreates the look of the Battlefleet Gothic game, perhaps too well as with no sense of scale the ships feel more like tiny models then giant ships. For those hopeing for the whole range of BFG ships, they will be disspoitned. Every Imperal curiser is a variation on the Lunar class, while every light curiser is Dauntless class.

reviewText:
TLDR; First of all, compared to a lot of games. This is a good game, nevermind the nice and true rendition of the Warhammer 40k / Gothic universe. Secondly, in my mind a game should be rated on its own merits, not how it is compared to others. The game is fine, and somewhat cheap. I wouldn't recommend it at the current state as there seems to be some minor issues, which I personally feel leads to a lot of frustration.

Missions
There's several different missions you can play. Each mission is divided into the defender and the attacker possition. There's; Breakthrough, Planetary Assault, Cruiser Clash, Data Revocery, Asssasination, Station-Assault and Convoy.
My biggest issue is that these missions clearly have a faivored race, meaning that some races are a lot better in specific missions. Some players argue on the forums that it isn't unbalanced, but rather a question of skills- If you're one of those elitist gamers, you'd problably agree and you should ignore this comment (and the rest for that matter).

Campaign
I've been waiting like a small child anticipating christmas, once I got to the end in the beta version. The graphics are great and all that, but what it comes down to is basically the issue with the missions. In the campaign you play an imperial commander and slowly advance in their order. On the mission table you then have to chose which planets you'd like to travel to and then complete a given assignment. Each round you have a given number of deployments that dictate how many missions you can take. Each misssion (win or loss) uses a deployment, and you end turn" in order to get more. All assignments come in the form of the previously mentioned mission-types. This clearly leads to a lot of frustation
date: when you realize that some missions are close to impossible (atleast for a mortal-gamer). This means you can either take the "easy" missions or use your deployments to try and complete a specific task. Since the chances for losing a ship is increased by a substantial amount in the tricky ones
recommended: you also have to take into account that you might have to ignore remaining deployments since your valuable ships are all destroyed
hoursPlayed:
lost in the wap or repaired.

Multiplayer
The game finds
voteText: and starts multiplayer games quickly
helpfulPercent: that's a pro. But my personal experience constantly matches me with higher level ships

reviewText:
Not quite ready for release, but the positive reviews won't tell you this. A purchase now is buying an incomplete, and in many ways horribly broken game.

The main issue is that the campaign uses the unit balance for Multiplayer, and that is horrendously out of whack currently. And as the Imperium of Man tends to suffer the worst of this, and you only get an Imperium campaign, this ensures that immediately after the tutorial ends the average player will have to save-scum constantly to beat incredibly unfair fights because the units used against them are faster, have longer range and more assault capabilities.

As you only get a limited amount of fights you can take per week, and already by Week 5 even with a perfect save-scummed game you have to allow a system to be lost, this means that the campaign can literally become literally unwinnable very, very quickly indeed.

The campaign itself has some lovely cutscenes, but because it really is just the multiplayer re-skinned with the odd stationary objective added in, it doesn't currently have any real gameplay feel that would make it compelling to grind your way through it's poor balancing.

Multiplayer has proven more fun for me, because I don't play as the Imperium, but rather as Orkz. And now it's been patched in, only in 2v2 as having team mates averages out the imbalance issues. But even here, the poor state of release is blatantly obvious. There's no ability to type only to your team mate, for instance...

But the big one, and one which will absolutely destroy the online community, is that it's possible at any time for a team mate to concede the match on behalf of the entire team, with no vote mechanism or way to keep playing. I've actually been winning a match, but because my team mate died and didn't want to sit and watch until I finished it, he threw the game and gave us both the loss and took away my rewards for the destruction I had and would have finished wreaking. It's a perfect trolling mechanism; you can join teams just to frustrate others if you wish.

And sometimes the game hangs even trying to start a match. And the races the players are using at the team set up stage aren't the ones they actually have (so you can choose the wrong fleet set up to tackle them). And the text box is duplicated in the middle of the fleet set up screen for some reason.

That's not to say when the game works, is fair, and played in good spirits it isn't great fun... I've loved the roleplaying and rammin' head bangin' battles I've had online with people. But the game just isnt READY yet. When it's balanced, patched, and given a few more months love, I'll come back to this review and change it.

But that gets into the last issue I need to bring up; because they've chosen to declare that it's launch now, that means that in a few months when the game may be much more polished, you won't get the DLC for free any more. Also even if you purchase the game now, unless you do so from specific vendors, you won't get the DLC for free at all. The currently confirmed stores are the official Focus store, Steam, Gamesplanet and Amazon.de  I find this constant degrading of the respect for the public, and the ever increasing manipulation of them to squeeze ever more profit out of them highly distasteful.  I do not regret buying in early, because I've had hours of Orky fun online in my own way, but there's no denying that as an all-round product here and now, it's just not complete enough or polished enough to justify either a full price release and especially not to deny people the chance at content because of an arbitrary financial decision to claim it's now launched.

For now, just be very aware of what the game actually IS if you wish to risk purchasing it; it's still effectively an incomplete beta product at this point. The campaign isn't working very well, online support is flakey at best, and whilst there's fun to be had, you have to focus on a very narrow viewpoint to find it.

reviewText:
So, played this a bunch. Bought it at Beta, been playing it since.. Launch fixed and broke a lot of things..

The Good:
--The critical system is a little less random at high health now. (believe me, this is good.)
--Ships for each race move and feel very unique.
--Chaos got buffed.
--Good art.
--Ships are wonderful to look at, shoot with, and blow up.
--RAMMING.
--Ships have inertia, so turns are almost always MUCH wider than you might expect.
--Story Follows the 12-13th Black Crusades from GW's Eye of Terror World Wide Campaign
(good story)

The Bad:
---EVE-Online AI Move options ('go here then stop and shoot' or 'circle and shoot with broadsides only.')
this doesnt help anyone that has forward firing guns, which is good because...
---Eldar. They got nurfed hard. This isnt totally a bad thing as they were nearly unkillable during beta, but now they are fragile and take significantly more damage from macrobattery ships even with full defence buff, and since they are insanely fragile, they have become insane glass  cannons.
---Truely horrible player-side AI. Some of the AI's pathing choices are down right awful, especially when playing less tanky races like chaos and eldar where stuff needs to be doing the right thing, or its dead.
half the time you will be babying your line ships only to find an escort found a minefield and still decided to fly though it, or, instead of turning AWAY from a closing enemy ship, it will turn towards it while on auto, or worse, toward a near by ally, creating evil micromanagement hell. Thank god for bullet-time, but even that wont save you all the time.
---Strike Craft. these are.. not great. worse, only a few ships carry them and they are kinda dedicated to it.
-Fighters are redundent.
-Boarding Pods are good but iffy.
-Bombers are lackluster against anything other than escorts.
With No counter to keep track of reamining craft so its kind of a crap shoot how many runs they will get before they are out (yes very much like the tabletop, just bombers are way less rewarding).
---Would really have liked to see ships that are assigned a numbered group sticking in formation - moving the same way, changing facing the same way, staying together, while not smashing into each other, and being able to fire similar weapons at the same time..
---They got rid of hotkeying groups?

TL;DR

Its not a bad game, but its not a great game. Its based heavily on awesome movement mechanics but there are very few options that allow you to make use of them effectively, and as you scale into larger and larger fleet battles simply making your fleet do what you want gets compoundingly more brutal.

reviewText:
So far I only played the single player campaign. The game is good for the most part: good tutorial, easy to understand, epic voice acting and atmosphere. The thing that ruined it for me though is the timed mission objectives.

Let me explain: the game is basically slow-paced with meticulous movement control of the ships. I mean just turning ships around takes like forever. The thing about timed objectives (like planetary bombardment, data recovery, or assasination) is that they need you to move too fast. For assasination or similar missions, at least you kind of know when the timer for the warp will start (when you damage the target ship heavily or steal the data or whatever), so you can kind of plan for it. But even if you do, there is no guarantee your abilities to stop the warp would work, and if it fails you kind of need to have a second ship in range with it's ability cooldown ready, and even then there is no guarantee. As for objectives like bombardment, you kind of need to know where the objective will appear before it does, else you probably won't be there in time.

Also unskippable in-game cutscenes are a problem, especially when you fail a mission..which is most of the time for me. For a game of such a slow pace and limited tools, the mission objectives feel like they're from another game..they're really not compatible.

TLDR: cool game but missions objectives often contradict game philosiphy and design.

reviewText: This game is the eqiuvalent of warm ♥♥♥♥ being poured into your ear slowly. It is a hyped up piece of trash, with unbalanced factions (especially chaos as usual because they're the GW neckbeard fan boys favourite) and get ready to expect boring manouvering across the map where enemies like chaose, continually avoid you to shoot you with their long ranged weapons in the most underwhelming battles you can imagine. Forget the trailers because nothing like that actually happens in game and versing the same 4 factions becomes completely boring. Weird planets, glowing scenery and ♥♥♥♥ becomes annoying to your eyes especially when they are placed underneath a grid map (which looks like a rip off of the battle ships board game), becoming distracting. Get ready for the in game currency called reknown, to be completely hard to gather, only to pick an ork favour realise you spent it on the wrong favour, unfit it , and lose all of the reknown spent on the favour.... Nice! And furthermore get ready for your ships to be continuously damaged for 1-2 turns or being lost in the warp forcing you to run escort fleets! Overall would highly discourage the buying of this game, its a let down save the 40 odd dolars and get something worthwhile. Once again GW abuses the customer's loyalty to their franchise (40k is awesome not gonna lie) hyping up a game made by devs on crack falling short of what we all expected.... disappointing.

reviewText:
This is really a nicely done game but there is one utterly frustrating element to it that pretty much kill it for me. Warping out of a battle. A couple of game modes are basically just a race to warping out and once your opponent begins you don't have very goods odds of stopping it, even on easy. To even have a chance you must reserve your boarding actions because the cool downs are so long you won't even have an opportunity to try to stop the enemy ship from warping out. That puts you at a real disadvantage, and makes several game modes an absolute drag to attempt.

Campaign starts of well enough but doesn't do a great job of explaining everything involved.

This game isn't terrible, not at all, but the balancing of cool downs and mission objectives just make it a grind.

reviewText:
I'm sad.

This had the potential to be a very good game.... but its not.

Repetative, unintresting game-play. The game is pretty much all about kiting. You take the speed mods/teleporter because you have to, otherwise you'll just get kited on any defence mission.

The ship variants have practically no difference between them other than a single gun swapped.

Bigger is always better, there is no to-hit penalty for attacking smaller/faster ships for example.

Most of the ship-designs are illogical and would have their designers shot into the sun.

Quite a few of the listed details on a design are actually wrong when you get into battle.

Nova-cannon - Just to further make light ships useless, this one-shots them. Again, no difference in damage to a very large ship or a small ship.

Expected a game of massive broadsides? Nope, this is more about teleporting bombs/statis bombs in front of the enemy.

If I thought I could get a refund, I'd go for it.

reviewText:
Ok SO I've put a few hours into BFG:A now.

While there are far less bugs than before, it's gets a bit stale after a while. Single player campaign is over quickly, leaving only solo or multiplayer, which would be fine, except that the Eldar as still remarkably OP. Pulse lasers and extreme speed make them incredibly difficult to defeat.

If it wasnt for that, really, the game would be pretty fun.

I'd suggest it needs more varied ship designs, a better UI, more viable tactics, way more fleets (which are being worked on apparently), more ship options, the ability to design your own ship loadouts (not just skills).

It's fun, but lacking at the moment, it doesn't really have any longevity.

reviewText:
Do I recommend this game? I think I neither do or don't. But if I was forced to pick one over the other, I'd slightly lean more towards yes, because it is the ONLY BFG game out there. Now, Battlefleet Gothic has plenty of great experiences don't get me wrong, however there are some experiences that are not so good. Let me tell you all about it.

The game is based on small fleet management where you can upgrade your vessels one by one at the cost of renown. To get renown, you win or lose battles by playing a match. However if you lose, there will be a cost at the same time rewarded (rewarded by failing? I like!). Eye and ear candy is everywhere to be seen. However, your brain will hurt at times as this game requires too much thinking and upgrading your ships from the shipyard is actually not how it should be. Dive into semi decent gameplay where half of the controls are missing, but it's ok as you just watched epic cutscenes. Popcorn required.

Visuals/art/animations/graphics: - 12/10
Immersion: 10/10
Voice Acting: + 1 (bonus)

GINORMOUS EFFORT! Mind blowing wows with extra points. Just throw a trailer into that intro ALONE. HERE! TAKE MY MONEY! By the love of gawd epic. And the cutscenes throughout the campaign maintains same level of quality. Skippable. Voice acting is god.

Campaign: 10/10
Tutorial: 3.5/10

Now here is why the campaign is almost perfect. You can die and still be rewarded. The campaign is tough, tougher than side missions, and if you fail them, you'll pay the price and don't need to start over at the same time. You don't need to replay anything. You can continue with your failures or load up the last game where you succeeded. On top of this, the devs included both failure and success cutscenes for dynamic plot. And you can choose where to attack or what planets to save. If you fail, you get one more chance to succeed! I'm not done with the campaign, but I see me finishing it in the future.

So the campaign is great except for this one little catch: An unskippable tutorial! The tutorial in this game is scary. You must complete this mission to move on. Or else

reviewText:
I want to love this game, and there are many good things about it. I played Tabletop Battlefleet and I loved that too, so I was excited for this game.

Unfortunately here's the big issues:
-The bugs in this game make it almost unplayable. Skills bug, renders your ships useless, screen bug so you move your screen around to see your ships..etc
- Pairing up in PvP ends in someone always quitting, even if you have a chance to pull it out 1v2, nope they just want to play the next game and force you to forfeit, even if they aren't on the map anymore.
- Eldar players get the battleship, then pick nothing else and theres nothing you can do. it turns into a MOBA for them and a strategy game for you. Goodluck trying to fight your way out of that.
- Battleships dont have their own Mission point requirement, in other terms If I wanted I could just run a BS the whole time. Your cruisers and light cruisers get crushed, and I kinda just take damage. GG, this can be balanced out by mandating you need a cruiser or above before you can field a battleship, otherwise its just broken, Especially vs two eldar in PvP....uuugggghh.
- Orks need taunt on all their ships to be effective, this should come passively....they're Orks.

After the basic glitches actually get refined out, this game will be worth it. Otherwise, I'd hold off.

*Edited*
adding to the list of things they still need to fix:
- A Team chat
- 5 out of 13 matches end in Fatal game errors due to a screen glitch, but might be different per person.

reviewText:
I'm amazed that there are no reviews for this game. Unless they're all blocked until the beta is over.

This game is fanatastic, while I haven't played the multiplayer, and stuck to the solo skirmish, I can honestly say that the mechanics are solid, I haven't experienced a single bug.

The ship customisation is solid, with numerous upgrades to the ships performance; although a limited number to each ship, forcing specialisation, but hey, no ship should be the ultimate upgraded beast form which you can deliver the Emperors Light in a competitive multiplayer game that also has a fully fleshed out campaign much like dawn of war 2's and dark crusade.

The ships, and the races (Imperium and Chaos as of the beta) are true to the lore and TT game for the most part, and they certainly have different play styles.

To win a battle you need strategy and tactics, as well as a good understanding of each ship in your fleet, and playing well to it's role. The battles are surprisingly fast, and hectic, a lot can be going on, and you need to keep track of it all. Which comes to point, the tactical cogitators" the ability to slow down time

reviewText:
Ok SO I've put a few hours into BFG:A now.

While there are far less bugs than before, it's gets a bit stale after a while. Single player campaign is over quickly, leaving only solo or multiplayer, which would be fine, except that the Eldar as still remarkably OP. Pulse lasers and extreme speed make them incredibly difficult to defeat.

If it wasnt for that, really, the game would be pretty fun.

I'd suggest it needs more varied ship designs, a better UI, more viable tactics, way more fleets (which are being worked on apparently), more ship options, the ability to design your own ship loadouts (not just skills).

It's fun, but lacking at the moment, it doesn't really have any longevity.

reviewText:
I want to like this game. I really do.

Multi player is just ♥♥♥♥ed. It has all the ballance you would expect from something with Games Workshops name attached to it.  Oh and its less of an RTS than it is just another moba game with heavy use of activated skills rather than movement and placement of your ships.

The single player is fun for a bit but quickly becomes pointless and drawn out. I found myself not really interested in winning or lossing game as much as just wanting to see some of the cut screen animations.

Might be worth it on sale later on but for now give it a pass. GW seem willing to slap its IP on anything these days so its only a matter of time before we get another better version of BFG more true to setting of the game.

reviewText: This is really a diamond in the rough.  If you love RTS this is the game for you.  All of the ships progress throughout the game, and you can upgrade them to fit your own game style.  This reminds me of Dawn of War in Space.  There's a lot of micro-managing, all of the powers and movment boosts feel powerful, dynamic, and fun to use.  The ships may look small on the map but the way they move, and interact with eachother gives them a feeling of immense weight.  I love this game, and will be enjoying every minute of the campaign!

reviewText:
Not really sure about any of the bad press this game is getting. First is bugs (which I haven't run into a single one) and the second is difficulty(which isn't a bad thing, but there is no problem as you can set most abilities to auto-fire which helps you to keep up).

Anyway, onto the review. (I have never played the tabletop version but) this game is brilliant. Naval combat in space with incredibly cinematic gameplay, which hasn't detracted from the strategic element at all. Not sure how long the campaign is, but is shaping up to be a good length and there are mini randomised campaigns for all the factions so you can play around their ships too.

It is relatively straight forward to get into, but there where a few things that I learnt the hard way (do not take the eldar head on, or they will savagely ♥♥♥♥ you, hard turn and continue to ♥♥♥♥ you).
There are a several ship varieties and variants within those to choose from which threw me a little to begin with, but with after playing a bit more I am catching on.

(For all you 40k fans, there is plenty of 'By/For the Emperor' and all that good stuff too.)

Easily a 8/10

reviewText: This is really a diamond in the rough.  If you love RTS this is the game for you.  All of the ships progress throughout the game, and you can upgrade them to fit your own game style.  This reminds me of Dawn of War in Space.  There's a lot of micro-managing, all of the powers and movment boosts feel powerful, dynamic, and fun to use.  The ships may look small on the map but the way they move, and interact with eachother gives them a feeling of immense weight.  I love this game, and will be enjoying every minute of the campaign!

reviewText:
So me and a friend played the game together for about 3 hours tonight. Had a blast....until some issues started popping up.

1 - After winning 6 or 7 matches, our party was dropped, and we couldn't team back up. Restarted client, rebooted steam, tried everything we could. No dice

2 - If one players drops out of the game (i.e ragequits) then NO ONE gets anything for the match. Happened when I got DC'd from a match. Had a chaos player rage quit twice, 1 ship left, had destroyed 5-6 ships, got zero renown and xp for a 10 minute fight.

3 - No team chat? Maybe I'm just being stupid and missing it, but it's very hard to coordinate with pugs when you can't talk to them directly.

So far, the core game seems solid. But these issues make it really un-enjoyable. It's extremely frustrating to be chasing a chaos or eldar player around the map for 5 minutes, and when they realize they can't win, it's alt+f4 and I get nothing in the match. I want to enjoy my time, but when I waste 45 minutes and get NOTHING for it, makes me not want to play. Devs need to take a look at some things. It still feels like a beta.

reviewText:
The single player story is weak and uninsprring and locked into an imperium only view. But I didn't purchase the game for the single player  experience, I wanted multiplayer ship battles against my friends and new foes on the internet. After paying my 40$ I'm not allowed to have a multiplayer experience.

There is no way to play against your friends.  The best you can do is team up and get half the usual points and ships just to  fight two random opponents on the internet.

You cannot jump in and play this game in multiplayer. You are forced to grind for 20+ hours to unlock all the content and ships for each race. That will be 80+ hours of grinding to unlock all the races. If you want to fight the AI you are still forced to grind again for each race, and again for each difficulty level.

When the developers were questioned about this they affirmed there is no intention to allow you to play multiplayer without being forcing grinding to unlock the content that you've paid for.

reviewText: Beautifully realised recreation of the tabletop game, which creates an immersive experience - whether playing solo or multiplayer. A sweeping soundscape combines with beautiful deep space backdrops and detailed ship models and ordnance animations. I totally love this game.

reviewText: Yes, it has some issues right now related to balance, repetitive mission types, and the Eldar (although honestly this has as much to do with their lore than anything else), but in the stream of bad and half-hearted Warhammer games this is truly one of the good ones.  They went out of their way to capture the feel of the grim dark WH40K universe, the artwork and models are loyal to the source material and really beautiful, the different factions do actually play differently and aren't just reskins, the tall ship style combat is very enjoyable and satisfying, the harder difficulties are legitimately challenging, and the campaign is superb.  I don't really do multiplayer, but I've played a lot of solo skirmish and have been through the campaign twice (have all the campaign achievements).  The campaign is excellently done, the scripted narrative and free play are mixed seamlessly and really makes you feel like an Imperial Admiral desperately fighting a long losing war.\n\n8/10 if you're a Warhammer 40K fan, maybe a point or two lower if you're not.
voteText: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Very novel system of escalting challenge that reflects the 40k universe! Obvoiusly your ships and crew improve.. yada yada.. But, you already control the sector you are in, so it is yours to lose. As the hordes and fleets decend against the sector, you can't be in every place at once on the grand strategy map. Every loss is a penalty and basically you are choosing how bad it is going to get for you and where. It makes you feel deep into the lore as vital worlds fall because you were off defending another (also vital) planet.  And that's just the grand strategy! Ship to ship combat is superb and requires thoughtful calculations. At least the ships improve as the sector is going up in flames!\n\n10/10 Will sacrifice billions for the Emperor again.

reviewText:
I was  looking forward to the release of this game, I mean who wouldn't want to play battleships in space with Orks and Eldar?

I played a bit during the beta when only skirmish modes and multiplayer were available and I found the game to be fun and ran well but really wanted to know what was there in the single player campaign.

So far I believe I have spent around 14 hours playing this game and I can say that the single player campaign has plenty to do and even though the missions available to play at first feel limited in number you soon find that with being able to play attack or defence and a few other tweaks thrown in for the single player game it does not start to get boring indeed.

Minor spoiler alert as the single player campaign puts you on your back foot almost immediately and loosing a single mission sees the ever creeping enemy fleets taking more of your planets you do start to feel the pressure as you have to plan each move carefully to optimise your wins, limit casualties, and take back your planets in the most efficient way.

I would definitely reccommend this game to anyone who loves space combat, strategy, or the Warhammer 40K and Games Workshop universes

reviewText:
(+)'s: Great cinematics, classic warhammer aesthetic, quality voice acting. True to the lore, solid UI, multiplayer if you need more after. Excellent balance between factions and ships, as well as upgrades. Campaign has a good flow, with story missions every few turns and multiple different mission types you pick from in the interim to decide which resources you want to save in your sector.

(-)'s: Some of the battles feel a little small. The story is constantly reminding you about the grand scale of the war with dozens of ships being lost in battles, but the actual battles you're in have 5-6 ships at the most in them. Even in the final battle, the entire fleet of both sides is laughably puny. There also comes a point in the game where you realize that most of the skills can be set on autocast and all you have to do is focus down enemies, which takes a lot of the tactics out of it.


I loved this game, and I already can't wait for BFG2 or any expansions they make.

reviewText: This is a good game if you are just going to play it by yourself; however, if you just want to play multiplayer with your buddies, like I did, then don't bother. The multiplayer in this game is, at this paticulair moment in time, a complete joke.  You can only invite one friend to your game, and you can only take that friend into a 2v2 with other, randomly selected, online players. There is also no Elo/matchmakeing system, so the players you get are truely random (Meaning you could be just starting out, and end up playing against people with maximum ranked ships and admirals).\n\nThat said, this is still a good game, and an update to the multiplayer is an easy fix. Untill the multiplayer is updated though, I cannot recommend this game for its current price of $39.99. Overall, I give this game a 4.8/10, but that is only because I bought it to play with my friends. If there is a multiplayer update for this game that allows you to play custom games with friends, my review for this game will most certainly change. Untill that time, steer clear of this game.

reviewText:
This game is a 2d capital ship RTS.  Don't let the 2d put you off, as I believe it is pulled off perfectly!  It looks and plays fantastic, and I have yet to have a single crash with 13 hours of gameplay.

With attrition based mechanics in the game, I would absolutely love to see a galactic conquest eventually, but for now a campaign, instant action and multiplayer is enough to keep me sated.

Additionally, each of the races play VERY different from each other.


All in all, this game earns a 9/10 from me.  I would recommend this to anyone who likes space RTS's.

If this game had some form of galactic conquest, I could easily see myself playing it for upwards of 300 hours.

reviewText: I really want to like Battlefleet Gothic: Armada, but I just can't.  The premise sounds cool, I love the Warhammer 40K universe (even though I've never played the tabletop games), and the game hits W40K's style exactly.  The ominous organ music, the range of excellent voice actors, and the meticulously designed battleships are all top-notch.\n\nHowever, the gameplay is very lackluster.  In short, it's rage-inducing.  Game modes like Data Recovery are just annoying to play, and combat is far too slow.  It feels like I'm slogging through mud.  I don't like games that make me angry, and Battlefleet Gothic makes me pretty angry.  Maybe if they shortened the time to kill and made fighting more engaging, I would revisit it for a positive review.

reviewText:
As a life-long Warhammer 40k fan I love this game! I played the old table-top version of BFG and the game has been adapted well to the PC.

The battles are fast-paced and allow for multiple approaches and strategies. The ships are customizable and have a diverse range of abilities and play style. The mission types are also diverse and keep you guessing.

The cons are few. The voice acting is terrible (no surprise there). There's very little feel of immersion, too.

Overall, I'd say an 8 out of 10. I can't wait to play the Space Marine and Tau fleets!

reviewText:
Few games have captured the 40K universe like this does, from the voice acting and music, to the beautiful ship designs and weapons. Certain compartments of the ships can be crippled (weapons, command deck, engines) which will limit it's effectiveness throughout the battle. The unique abilities and upgrades you can provide the ships and their crew are always fun to explore and experiment with: such as stasis bombs which trap everything in a bubble for about 15 seconds (torpedoes, ships, even fighters and cannon shells) and teleportation drives to instantly manouver around enemies.
Positioning is a major part of the strategies, similar to 18th century naval warfare and being caught in a bad location can be tricky to overcome.
The game's 4 factions: Imperials, Chaos, Orks and Eldar are all unique with their own playstyle and capture the tabletop game beautifully. As somebody who sadly didn't have the chance to play that before GW ended production (god knows why) I can't thank these guys engough for this. Most of the devs are long-time 40K fans and truly went out of their way to do the IP justice
I would highly recommend this to any warhammer fan (if they've not played this already) and to anybody who is interested in space combat strategy games.
10 / 10
